Secs. 2-68-2-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - VILLAGE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-08-23, §§ 1, 2, adopted April 3, 2008, amended article III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article III, §§ 2-91-2-95, 2-111, 2-112, pertained to board of trustees, and derived from Code 1963, §§ 2.101, 2.102, 2.201, 2.207, 2.208; Ord. No. O-64-149, § 2, 3-12-1965; Ord. No. O-70-10, § 1, 5-7-1970; Ord. No. O-71-25, § 1, 6-17-1971; Code 1975, §§ 2-57-2-59, 2-68, 2-70, 2-79, 2-86; Ord. No. O-80-38, § 3, 8-21-1980; Ord. No. O-80-53, § 1(a), 12-4-1980; Ord. No. O-81-11, § 3, 3-5-1981; Ord. No. O-94-38, §§ 2, 4, 7-21-1994; Ord. No. O-99-71, § 1, 12-16-1999; Ord. No. O-07-12, § 1, 4-5-2007. 
State Law reference- Board of trustees, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-45-5 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-90. - Form of government. 
(a)  The Village of Hanover Park operates under the managerial form of government adopted by referendum. The village board shall consist of the village president and six trustees. 
(b)  The village board shall be the legislative and policy-making body of the village and shall have the powers and duties prescribed by statute and by ordinance of this village. Such powers and duties include: 
(1)  Select and appoint a village manager as the chief administrative officer of the village charged with the powers and duties set forth in article V. 
(2)  Adopt, amend, and repeal ordinances as allowed by statute. 
(3)  Determine and review the village's property tax rate on an annual basis. 
(4)  Fulfill the village's vision by setting the strategic plan and developing annual goals. 
(5)  Approve the village's annual operating budget in pursuit of the village's mission statement. 
(6)  Promote the maintenance of the quality of life in the village through establishing intergovernmental relationships. 
(7)  Establish a comprehensive plan for the village's zoning and land use. 
(8)  Approve the five-year capital improvements plan annually to efficiently maintain the village's infrastructure. 
(Ord. No. O-08-23, § 1, 4-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-91. - Finance committee and ad hoc advisory committees. 
(a)  There is hereby created a finance committee to advise the village board on matters concerning finance. The committee shall consist of three members, two of whom shall be members of the village board. The chairman (who shall be a trustee) and all members shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the village board. If practicable, at least two weeks prior to the budget being presented to the village board, it shall be presented by the budget officer to the finance committee for its review. 
(b)  Ad hoc advisory committees may be created from time to time by the president and board of trustees with such members, terms, purposes and functions as are established by its creation. 
(Ord. No. O-09-28, §§ 1, 2, 8-3-2009) 
Sec. 2-92. - Rules of order and procedure. 
    The president and board of trustees shall adopt rules of order and procedure governing the functions of the president and village board which shall be available for public inspection and review at the office of the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. O-08-23, § 2, 4-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-93. - Disturbing meetings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any meeting of the board of trustees or of any committee thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-08-23, § 2, 4-3-2008) 
State Law reference- Rules of expulsion, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-15. 
Sec. 2-94. - Village board meetings. 
(a)  The regular meetings of the village board shall be held at the village hall on the first and third Thursday of every month at the hour of 7:00 p.m. If the regular meeting falls on a legal holiday, the meeting shall be cancelled. Adjourned meetings may be held at such time as the village board may determine. 
(b)  Special meetings may be called by the president or by any three trustees of the board by written request or notice together with the agenda for the meeting being filed with the clerk at least 48 hours prior to the time specified for such meeting. At least 48 hours written notice of such special meeting, except a meeting held in the event of a bona fide emergency, shall be given by the clerk, which notice shall specify the time and purpose of such meeting and include the agenda and shall be delivered to each member of the village board into their respective village mailbox or to such other location as the member may provide in writing to the village clerk or personally. Notices to members of the media as provided in the Open Meetings Act, 5 ILCS 120/et seq., shall also be given. All meetings of the village board, including special and adjourned meetings, except closed sessions thereof, shall be open to the public, as required by statute. 
(c)  Any agenda required under this section shall set forth the general subject matter of any resolution or ordinance that will be the subject of final action at the meeting. The village board shall ensure that at least one copy of any requested notice and agenda for the meeting is continuously available for public review during the entire 48-hour period preceding the meeting. Posting of the notice and agenda on a website that is maintained by the village board satisfies the requirement for continuous posting under this paragraph (3). If a notice or agenda is not continuously available for the full 48-hour period due to actions outside of the control of the village board, then that lack of availability does not invalidate any meeting or action taken at a meeting. 
(Ord. No. O-14-15, § 1, 5-1-2014) 
Secs. 2-95-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES 

Sec. 2-111. - Number, election, terms; powers, duties generally. 
    The board of trustees of the village shall consist of six members elected according to the method provided by statute. Each trustee shall be elected and serve a four-year term and until his successor is elected and qualified as required by law. The term of office of each trustee shall commence at the first regular or special meeting of the village president and board of trustees during the month of May following the proclamation of the results of the regular municipal election at which the trustee was elected. 
(Ord. No. O-08-23, § 2, 4-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-112. - Oath. 
    The members of the board of trustees shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute. 
(Ord. No. O-08-23, § 2, 4-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-113. - Compensation. 
    The salary of village trustee shall be established at $650.00 per month. The salary shall be increased at the rate of three percent per each following year. 
(Ord. No. O-08-23, § 2, 4-3-2008; Ord. No. O-12-28, § 1, 9-6-2012; Ord. No. O-18-35, § 1, 10-4-2018) 
State Law reference- Compensation of members of corporate authorities, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-50-15. 
Secs. 2-114-2-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PRESIDENT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal officers generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-5-5 et seq. 

Sec. 2-141. - Election; term. 
    The village president shall be the president of the board of trustees as provided by statute and shall be elected and serve a four-year term and until his successor is elected and qualified as required by law. The term of office of the village president shall commence at the first regular or special meeting of the village president and board of trustees during the month of May following the proclamation of the results of the regular municipal election at which the village president was elected. 
(Code 1963, § 1.001; Code 1975, § 2-97; Ord. No. O-81-11, § 4, 3-5-1981; Ord. No. O-07-12, § 2, 4-5-2007) 
State Law reference- Election, term of president, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-10. 
Sec. 2-142. - Powers, duties generally. 
(a)  The village president shall be the chief executive officer of the village, and he shall perform all such duties as may be required of him by statute or ordinance. 
The village president shall be recognized as the official head of the village by the courts for the purpose of serving civil process and by the governor for all legal purposes. 
(b)  The village president shall have the power and authority to inspect all books and records kept by any village officer or employee at any reasonable time. He shall preside at all meetings of the village board and on all ceremonial occasions. The village president shall be the liquor control commissioner of the Village of Hanover Park. 
(c)  The village president, from time to time, may, and annually shall, give the corporate authorities information concerning the affairs of the municipality and may recommend for their consideration measures the president believes expedient. 
(Code 1963, § 1.002; Code 1975, § 2-98; Ord. No. O-08-23, § 3, 4-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-143. - Settling disputes; delegation of duties. 
(a)  Whenever there is a question as to the respective powers or duties of an officer appointed by the village president, such question shall be settled by the president; and he shall have the power to delegate to any such officer any duty which is to be performed when no specific officer has been directed to perform the duty. 
(b)  Whenever the village president determines that any board or commission of the village is unable to conduct a hearing as a result of the inability of such board or commission to create a quorum of the members thereof, he shall have the right to direct that such hearing be held before the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1963, § 1.003; Code 1975, § 2-99; Ord. No. O-83-7, § 1, 1-6-1983; Ord. No. O-08-23, § 3, 4-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-144. - Powers during state of emergency created by transit shutdown. 
(a)  When any of the following conditions exist, there exists in the Village of Hanover Park a state of emergency: 
(1)  Cessation of commuter transit operations by the Regional Transportation Authority; or 
(2)  Cessation of operations by other rail or bus operator serving the area. 
(b)  Whenever the village president shall determine that a state of emergency exists, he shall sign, under oath, a statement of finding that such standards have been met, setting forth facts to substantiate such findings, describing the nature of the emergency, and declaring that a state of emergency exists. Such statement shall be filed with the clerk of the Village of Hanover Park as soon as practicable. 
(c)  After declaring a state of emergency the village president may declare the state of emergency at an end by giving written notice to that effect to the village clerk, but in no event shall a state of emergency extend beyond the adjournment of the first regular meeting of the village board of trustees after the state of emergency is declared. 
(d)  When a state of emergency exists under this section, the village president shall have the authority to order such action as may be deemed necessary to alleviate that traffic and transportation problems of the community, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Suspension of the ordinances of the Village of Hanover Park (chapter 62, article XI, division 2) relating to parking; 
(2)  Imposition of such traffic and parking rules and regulations as are provided by the village ordinance relating to snow emergencies; 
(3)  Imposition of rules and regulations to provide for emergency licensure and inspection of any transportation service available to the public for hire. 
(e)  Notice. The village president shall cause notice to be given of the calling of the state of emergency and the time at which he signed the declaration by every and all available means reasonably known to him at the time of calling such a state of emergency. 
(Code 1975, § 2-99.1; Ord. No. O-81-35, §§ 1-5, 6-18-1981; Ord. No. O-81-39, §§ 1-5, 7-2-1981; Ord. No. O-94-38, § 6, 7-21-1994) 
Sec. 2-145. - Bond; oath. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his office, the president shall give a bond with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties, in the sum of $3,000.00, the cost of which bond will be paid by the village. He shall take the oath of office as prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1963, § 1.004; Code 1975, § 2-100) 
State Law reference- Oath or affirmation, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25; bond of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30. 
Sec. 2-146. - Deputy president. 
(a)  Creation of office; powers and duties. There is hereby created the office of deputy village president. The person appointed to such office be and is hereby authorized to lawfully perform all functions and duties the village president is empowered to perform, but only when the village president is unable to perform same as a result of the temporary absence from the village or the disability of the village president. 
(b)  Qualifications. No person shall be appointed to the office of deputy president unless he or she is a duly elected trustee of the Village of Hanover Park. 
(c)  Appointment. Appointment to the office of deputy president shall be an appointment of the village president, which appointment must be confirmed by a majority vote of the duly elected and acting trustees of the Village of Hanover Park. 
(d)  Term of office. The term of office of the deputy president shall commence on the day of appointment and terminate on the annual anniversary thereof, unless the office is vacated by removal, which will be done in the same manner as required for appointment, or by the holder of such office no longer qualifying to continue to hold such appointment. In no event shall the term of office of deputy president extend beyond the term of office of the village president, who made such appointment. 
(e)  Bond; oath. Before entering upon the duties of his office, the deputy president shall give a bond with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties, in the sum of $3,000.00, the cost of which bond will be paid by the village. He shall take the oath of office as prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1975, § 2-101; Ord. No. O-78-63, § 1, 12-21-1978) 
State Law reference- Bond of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30. 
Sec. 2-147. - President pro tem. 
    In the event of the temporary absence or disability of both the village president and the deputy village president, the board of trustees shall elect one of its number to act as president pro tem, who during the absence or disability of the village president, and the deputy village president, shall perform the duties pertaining to the office of village president. The authority vested in the president pro tem shall cease upon the termination of the temporary absence or disability of either the village president or the deputy village president. 
(Code 1975, § 2-101.1; Ord. No. O-78-64, § 1, 12-21-1978) 
Sec. 2-148. - Compensation of president. 
    The salary of president of the village is hereby established at $1,500.00 per month. Additionally, the president shall receive a salary of $250.00 per month as liquor commissioner. The salaries shall be increased at the rate of three percent per each following year. 
(Code 1963, § 1.006; Ord. No. O-64-149, § 1, 3-12-1965; Ord. No. O-72-2, § 1, 2-3-1972; Code 1975, § 2-102; Ord. No. O-80-53, § 1(b), 12-4-1980; Ord. No. O-99-71, § 2, 12-16-1999; Ord. No. O-12-28, § 2, 9-6-2012; Ord. No. O-18-35, § 2, 10-4-2018) 
Secs. 2-149-2-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MANAGER[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Managerial form of municipal government, 65 ILCS 5/5-1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-171. - Office created. 
    The office of the village manager, as defined by Illinois Revised Statutes, is hereby established. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 1, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-114) 
Sec. 2-172. - Appointment; qualifications. 
    The village manager shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees for an indefinite term as provided by law. He shall be the administrative head of the municipal government and shall be responsible for the efficient administration of all departments. He shall be appointed without regard to his political beliefs and need not be a resident of the village when appointed, but during his tenure of office, he shall reside within the village. He shall be chosen on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications with special reference to his actual experience in or his knowledge of accepted practice in respect to the duties of his office hereinafter set forth. Neither the village president, village clerk, nor any village trustee shall receive such appointment during the term for which he has been elected or within one year after the expiration of his term. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 2, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-115; Ord. No. O-08-23, § 4, 4-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-173. - Bond. 
    Before taking office, the village manager shall furnish a fidelity bond in such amount and with such surety as may be approved by the village board of trustees with such bond to be conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties and shall be considered to indemnify the village for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty or any act of the village manager. The cost of the bond shall be paid by the village and shall be filed with the clerk after being approved by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 2, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-116) 
State Law reference- Bond of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30. 
Sec. 2-174. - Removal authorized. 
    The village manager may be removed by the president and board of trustees by majority vote of the entire board at any time. A vacancy in the office of village manager shall be filled within 90 days after the effective date of such vacancy. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 2, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-117) 
Sec. 2-175. - Designation of acting manager. 
    In case of the absence or disability of the village manager, the village board may designate a qualified administrative official of the village to perform the duties of the manager during such absence or disability. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 2, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-118) 
Sec. 2-176. - Compensation. 
    The village manager shall receive such compensation as the board of trustees shall establish from time to time. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 4, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-119) 
Sec. 2-177. - Office. 
    The village manager shall maintain an office in the Village Hall. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 15, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-120) 
Sec. 2-178. - Job to be full-time. 
    The village manager shall spend his full time in the performance of his duties. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 15, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-121) 
Sec. 2-179. - Powers, duties-Generally. 
    The village manager shall be the administrative head of the village government, and he shall be responsible for the efficient administration of all departments. The powers and duties of the village manager shall be as follows: 
(1)  To enforce the laws and ordinances within the village. 
(2)  To appoint and remove department heads. 
(3)  To appoint and remove all department heads and all appointed officials and employees except when the appointment power is vested in the elected officials of the village under the statutes of the state, or under village ordinances. No appointment shall be made on any basis other than that of merit and fitness. 
(4)  To exercise control of all departments and divisions thereof that may be created by the village board. 
(5)  To attend all meetings of the village board unless excused therefrom by the village board. The manager shall have the privilege of taking part in the discussion of all matters coming before the board but shall have no vote therein. He shall be entitled to notice of all meetings, regular and special, of the board. 
(6)  To recommend to the board of trustees for adoption such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient. 
(7)  To have all the powers and exercise all the duties granted to the village clerk and the treasurer with respect to the preparation of a report of estimated funds necessary to defray the expenses of the village for the fiscal year for the consideration of the village board prior to the preparation of the budget. 
(8)  To prepare and submit to the board of trustees a monthly report of activities of all departments under his jurisdiction. 
(9)  To provide for independent audits of all accounts of the village, which audits shall be conducted independently of the manager by some person selected by the village board. The power with respect to such audits shall not be construed to limit the responsibility of the manager for the proper expenditure of village funds. 
(10)  In case of accident, disaster, or other circumstances creating a public emergency, to award contracts and make purchases for the purpose of meeting such emergency. Should such expenditures occur, the manager shall promptly file with the board of trustees a certificate showing such emergency and the necessity for such action, together with an itemized account of all expenditures. 
(11)  To appoint, subject to the confirmation of the president and board of trustees, a person to act as secretary to the development commission. Such person shall perform such duties of his position as are required by ordinance and by direction of the village manager. The appointment shall be for an indefinite time, but the person so appointed shall be subject to the provisions of this article regarding persons appointed by the village manager. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 3, 5-20-1971; Ord. No. O-72-12, §§ 1, 2, 5-4-1972; Ord. No. O-72-22, § 1, 8-3-1972; Code 1975, § 2-122; Ord. No. O-77-35, 7-7-1977; Ord. No. O-85-26, § 5, 5-16-1985; Ord. No. O-08-23, § 5, 4-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-180. - Same-Appointment, direction, removal of employees. 
    The village manager, or the manager's designee, shall be responsible for establishing and administering personnel policies and, as such, shall: 
(1)  Be responsible for the proper conduct of and conformance with established policies of all personnel programs, actions, and procedures. 
(2)  Appoint and assign all village employees. 
(3)  Be authorized to create classifications and positions, amend the classification plan in order to establish new classes and positions, or abolish existing classes and positions. Said changes shall be subject to adoption in ordinance form by the village board of trustees. 
(4)  Be authorized to investigate, examine, or inquire into the affairs and records of village employees. 
(5)  Be authorized to suspend, discharge, and/or demote employees in accordance with the village's personnel rules, and in compliance with local ordinances, applicable state statutes, and federal laws. 
(6)  Promulgate personnel rules and regulations, with the concurrence of the village board, in order to administer and implement this article and for the day-to-day operation of the personnel system. Prior to the effective date of any such rules, the village manager shall provide written notice to village departments and employees. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 5, 5-20-1971; Ord. No. O-72-12, § 3, 5-4-1972; Code 1975, § 2-123; Ord. No. O-85-26, § 6, 5-16-1985; Ord. No. O-99-04, § 1, 1-21-1999; Ord. No. O-08-23, § 5, 4-3-2008) 
Sec. 2-181. - Same-Officers and departments. 
    Every administration department of the village shall be under the supervision and control of the manager, and he shall have the power to remove from office any department head. All department heads shall be filled by appointment by the manager, except where otherwise provided by law, or by village ordinance. the village manager shall report to the president and board of trustees such appointments or any removal from office made by him as soon as possible after the appointment or removal. This shall not be construed to include the elected officers, the village clerk, corporation counsel, or members of the development commission or any other commissions, boards, or committees heretofore established or hereafter created by the board. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 6, 5-20-1971; Ord. No. O-72-12, § 4, 5-4-1972; Ord. No. O-72-22, § 2, 8-3-1972; Code 1975, § 2-124; Ord. No. O-99-04, § 1, 1-21-1999; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 13, 3-17-2005) 
Sec. 2-182. - Same-Contracts. 
    The village manager or his designee shall examine all proposed contracts to which the village may be a party; and may sign on behalf of the village any contract for an amount up to and including $20,000.00, or for an amount over $20,000.00 if authorized by the board of trustees, except where the board directs that some other officer shall do so, and except for change orders in public works contracts that either are (i) greater than $20,000.00 or (ii) exceed 50 percent or more of the original contract price or 50 percent or more of an original subcontractor price. It shall be the duty of the manager to see that all the terms of any contract to which the village is a party are fully performed by all parties thereto. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 7, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-125; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 14, 3-17-2005; Ord. No. O-12-13, § 1, 5-3-2012) 
Sec. 2-183. - Same-Purchases. 
    The village manager shall be the general purchasing agent of the village and shall make all purchases of supplies, materials, and equipment; provided however, except as provided in section 2-179(11), for any purchase which exceeds the sum of $20,000.00, the manager shall, before making such purchase, obtain prior approval and direction from the board of trustees. No purchase shall be made or obligation incurred, except for the purpose for which there has been a prior appropriation, or for which no additional appropriation is required. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 8, 5-20-1971; Ord. No. O-72-12, § 5, 5-4-1972; Code 1975, § 2-126; Ord. No. O-80-6, § 1, 1-17-1980; Ord. No. O-82-12, § 1, 2-18-1982; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 15, 3-17-2005; Ord. No. O-08-23, § 6, 4-3-2008; Ord. No. O-12-13, § 1, 5-3-2012) 
State Law reference- Purchasing and public works contracts, 65 ILCS 5/8-9-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-184. - Same-Sale of personal property. 
(a)  "Personal property" as used in this section means personal property of the village having a value of less than $10,000.00 as determined by the village manager and shall not include personal property which shall be turned in as part of the purchase price on a new purchase of any similar article. 
(b)  Whenever any personal property in the opinion of the village manager is no longer necessary or useful to or for the best interests of the village, he may authorize the sale of that property and shall report the proceeds from that sale to the president and village board within 30 days. 
(Code 1975, § 2-126.5; Ord. No. O-83-60, § 1, 10-20-1983; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 16, 3-17-2005) 
Sec. 2-185. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-186. - Same-Accounts. 
    It shall be the duty of the village manager to keep current accounts showing at all times the fiscal condition of the village, including the current and anticipated expenses, appropriations, cash on hand and anticipated revenue of all municipal funds and accounts; and he shall see to the collection of all money due the municipality. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 10, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-128) 
Sec. 2-187. - Same-Inventories, property. 
(a)  The village manager shall ensure that a current inventory showing all real and personal property of the village and its location is maintained, and shall be responsible for the care and custody of all such property, including equipment, buildings, and all other village property which is not assigned by law to some other officer or body for care and control. 
(b)  The manager shall recommend to the village board an insurance program of sufficient coverage to protect the village and its property and personnel. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 11, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-129; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 17, 3-17-2005) 
Sec. 2-188. - Same-Reports and publications. 
    It shall be the duty of the village manager to see to the publication of all notices, ordinances or other documents required by law to be published, and to prepare or cause to be prepared all reports which the village or any of the officials thereof are required by law to prepare. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 12, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-130) 
Sec. 2-189. - Same-Elections. 
    The village manager shall prepare for the village clerk all notices, ballots and election supplies necessary in connection with municipal elections. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 13, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-131) 
Sec. 2-190. - Same-Records, certificates. 
(a)  The village manager shall prepare and have custody of all municipal records required by law to be kept by the village and not by a specific officer. Where the law makes it the duty of a specific officer to keep or maintain records, the manager shall make available to such officer the necessary clerical assistance for the preparation of such records, and shall make available a place for custody of such records. In compliance therewith, the manager shall make available to the clerk the stenographic or clerical assistance necessary for the preparation of the journal of the village board proceedings, and the record of ordinances and all other documents which by law the clerk is required to keep. The manager shall perform similar services for the treasurer for maintenance of bond registers and all other records or documents which, by law, the treasurer is required to keep or prepare. 
(b)  Where the law requires or provides for certifications of any records or documents by any officer of the village, the manager shall cause such records or documents to be properly prepared and presented to such officer for his signature. 
(Ord. No. O-71-15, art. I, § 14, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-132) 
Secs. 2-191-2-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CLERK[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Duties of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 

Sec. 2-211. - Election, term. 
    The village clerk shall be elected and serve for a four-year term and until his successor is elected and qualified as required by law. The term of office of the clerk shall commence on the first Thursday in the month of May following the election at which such office was filled and terminate on the first Thursday in the month of May four years later. 
(Code 1963, § 3.001; Code 1975, § 2-144; Ord. No. O-81-11, § 5, 3-5-1981) 
State Law reference- Election, term of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-90. 
Sec. 2-212. - Bond. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his office, the village clerk shall execute a bond in such amount as is provided by statute, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties. 
(Code 1963, § 3.002; Code 1975, § 2-145) 
State Law reference- Bond of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30. 
Sec. 2-213. - Signatures, attesting documents. 
    The village clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the village and all licenses, permits, other than building permits, and such other documents as shall require this formality. 
(Code 1963, § 3.003; Ord. No. O-70-8, § 1, 5-7-1970; Code 1975, § 2-146) 
Sec. 2-214. - Disposition of receipts. 
    The clerk shall turn over all money received by him on behalf of the village to the village treasurer promptly upon receipt thereof, and with such money shall give a statement as to the source thereof. 
(Code 1963, § 3.004; Code 1975, § 2-147) 
Sec. 2-215. - Duty to keep accounts. 
    The clerk shall keep accounts showing all money received by him and the source and disposition thereof, and such other accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1963, § 3.005; Code 1975, § 2-148) 
Sec. 2-216. - Duty to keep records. 
    In addition to the record of ordinances and other records which the clerk is required by statute to keep, he shall keep a register of all licenses and permits issued, and the payments thereon; a record showing all of the officers and regular employees of the village; and such other records as may be required by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1963, § 3.006; Code 1975, § 2-149) 
Sec. 2-217. - Custody, use of seal. 
    The clerk shall be the custodian of the village seal and shall affix its impression on documents whenever required. 
(Code 1963, § 3.007; Code 1975, § 2-150) 
State Law reference- Duty to keep corporate seal, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
Sec. 2-218. - Custody of documents. 
    The clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the village which are not assigned to the custody of some other officer. 
(Code 1963, § 3.008; Code 1975, § 2-151) 
State Law reference- Custody of documents, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
Sec. 2-219. - Duty to keep index. 
    The clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records kept by him, so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had. 
(Code 1963, § 3.009; Code 1975, § 2-152) 
Sec. 2-220. - Additional duties. 
    In addition to the duties provided in this article, the clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1963, § 3.010; Code 1975, § 2-153) 
State Law reference- General duties of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
Sec. 2-221. - Vacancy, appointment. 
    In case the office of village clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the president and board of trustees shall appoint a successor as provided by statute. 
(Code 1963, § 3.011; Code 1975, § 2-154) 
State Law reference- Filling vacancy, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-50. 
Sec. 2-222. - Salary. 
    The annual salary of village clerk, if the clerk has been certified in the manner hereinafter stated, shall be $10,000.00 paid in monthly installments. If the clerk has not been so certified, the annual salary shall be $6,700.00 paid in monthly installments. A clerk shall be deemed certified for purposes of this section if the clerk received a certificate as a professional municipal clerk from the International Institute of Municipal Clerks. The salary shall be increased at the rate of three percent per each following year. 
(Ord. No. O-64-149, § 3, 3-12-1965; Ord. No. O-71-13, § 1, 5-20-1971; Code 1975, § 2-155; Ord. No. O-80-53, § 1(c), 12-4-1980; Ord. No. O-99-71, § 3, 12-16-1999; Ord. No. O-12-28, § 3, 9-6-2012; Ord. No. O-18-35, § 3, 10-4-2018) 
Sec. 2-223. - Deputy clerk. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of deputy clerk. The village clerk is authorized to appoint a deputy clerk, who shall have the power and duty to execute all documents required by any law or ordinance to be executed by the clerk and affix the seal of the village thereto whenever required. 
(b)  When signing any documents, the deputy clerk shall sign the name of the village clerk followed by the word "By" and the deputy clerk's own name and words "Deputy Clerk." 
(c)  The powers and duties described in this section shall be exercised by the deputy clerk only in the absence of the village clerk from his office, and only when either written direction has been given by the village clerk to exercise such power, or the president and board of trustees have determined by resolution that the village clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform such function. 
(d)  The deputy clerk shall have the authority and power described in this section and such further power and authority as may be provided by statute. 
(Code 1963, § 3.013; Ord. No. O-72-37, § 1, 12-7-1972; Code 1975, § 2-156) 
State Law reference- Authorization for and powers of deputy, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-95. 
Sec. 2-224. - Publication of annual treasurer's report. 
    The clerk shall, within six months after the end of each fiscal year, and after having received a copy of the annual treasurer's report, publish a notice in a newspaper advising of the availability of said annual report and that the same may be inspected or copied at the office of the clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 2-157; Ord. No. O-93-65, § 1, 10-21-1993) 
Secs. 2-225-2-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - STATE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES ETHICS ACT[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-04-31, § 1, adopted May 6, 2004, amended article VII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article VII, §§ 2-251-2-256, pertained to state gift ban act. For complete derivation, see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 

Sec. 2-251. - Adoption of Act. 
    The regulations of Sections 5-15 (5 ILCS 430/5-15) and Article 10 (5 ILCS 430/10-10 through 10-40) of the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act, 5 ILCS 430/1-1 et seq., (hereinafter referred to as the "Act" in this article) are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of the village to the extent required by 5 ILCS 430/70-5. 
(Ord. No. O-04-31, § 1, 5-6-2004) 
Sec. 2-252. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under the Act, by any officer or any employee of the village, is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an officer or employee of the village under the Act is hereby prohibited. 
(c)  The participation in political activities prohibited under the Act, by any officer or employee of the village, is hereby prohibited. 
(d)  For purposes of this section, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be defined as set forth in 5 ILCS 430/70-5(c). 
(Ord. No. O-04-31, § 1, 5-6-2004) 
Sec. 2-253. - Existing ordinances and personnel rules. 
    This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of village officers and employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this section, however, the provisions of this section shall prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 ILCS 430/70-5(a). 
(Ord. No. O-04-31, § 1, 5-6-2004) 
Sec. 2-254. - Future amendments to Act. 
    Any amendment to the Act that becomes effective after the effective date of this section shall be incorporated into this section by reference and shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering, and making of gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this section by reference without formal action by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Ord. No. O-04-31, § 1, 5-6-2004) 
Sec. 2-255. - Future declaration of unconstitutionality of Act. 
(a)  If the Illinois Supreme Court declares the Act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this section shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois Supreme Court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals or rehearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of the village if the Act is found unconstitutional by the Illinois Supreme Court. 
(b)  If the Illinois Supreme Court declares part of the Act unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the Act, or does not address the remainder of the Act, then the remainder of the Act as adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this section relating to the part of the Act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Ord. No. O-04-31, § 1, 5-6-2004) 
Sec. 2-256. - Penalty. 
(a)  A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-252(c) may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary for a period of not more than 364 days and may be fined in an amount not to exceed $2,500.00. 
(b)  A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-252 (a) or (b) is subject to a fine in an amount of not less than $1,001.00 and not more than $5,000.00. 
(c)  Any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of this article to the local enforcement authorities, the state's attorney, or any other law enforcement official may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary for a period of not more than 364 days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed $2,500.00. 
(d)  A violation of section 2-252(c) of this article shall be prosecuted as a criminal offense by an attorney for the village by filing in the circuit court any information, or sworn complaint, charging such offense. The prosecution shall be under and conform to the rules of criminal procedure. Conviction shall require the establishment of the guilt of the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt. 
    A violation of section 2-252(a) or (b) may be prosecuted as a quasi-criminal offense by an attorney for the village. 
(e)  In addition to any other penalty that may be applicable, whether criminal or civil, an officer or employee who intentionally violates any provision of this article is subject to discipline or discharge. 
(Ord. No. O-04-31, § 1, 5-6-2004) 
Secs. 2-257-2-280. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS[9]

State Law reference- Local improvements, 65 ILCS 5/9-1-1 et seq.; board of local improvements, 65 ILCS 5/9-2-7. 

Sec. 2-281. - Created; composition. 
    There is hereby established the board of local improvements for the village, which shall consist of the president and all the members of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1963, § 6.101; Code 1975, § 2-188) 
Sec. 2-282. - Secretary. 
    The village clerk shall be the secretary of the board of local improvements. 
(Code 1963, § 6.102; Code 1975, § 2-189) 
Sec. 2-283. - Powers, duties.

ARTICLE IX. - HUMAN RESOURCES DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 2-311. - Creation and composition. 
    There is hereby established a human resources department consisting of a human resources director and such other personnel as may be employed and assigned thereto. 
(Ord. No. O-99-04, § 2(2-202), 1-21-1999) 
Sec. 2-312. - Director; duties. 
(a)  The human resources director shall be the chief administrative officer of the human resources department and shall be appointed by the village manager. 
(b)  The human resources department shall be responsible for administration of professional human resource practices for all village employees in a manner consistent with the ordinances of the village, applicable laws of the state and the United States, including the responsibility to: 
(1)  Encourage and exercise leadership in the development of effective human resource administration within the departments of the village. 
(2)  Advise the village manager on utilization of employees. 
(3)  Foster and develop programs for the improvement of employee effectiveness including, but not limited to, position classification, salary administration, recruitment, selection, promotion, performance ratings, probationary periods, employee benefits, and training activities. Said activities shall ensure equal employment opportunity for all applicants and employees, including the establishment and maintenance of an affirmative action plan. 
(4)  Evaluate from time to time the operation and effect of this article and the rules made hereunder and report the findings and recommendations to the village manager. 
(5)  Establish and maintain records of all current and former village employees. 
(6)  Recommend to the village manager the creation of new positions and classifications, reclassifications, and the deletion and/or revision of existing positions and classifications. 
(7)  Verify that persons named on the payroll have been appointed and employed in accordance with the provisions of this article and the rules adopted pursuant to this article. 
(8)  Administer personnel recruitment, promotion, selection, and placement in conformance with article V of the village's Personnel Rules and Regulations. 
(9)  Advise department heads, supervisors and employees on personnel matters. 
(10)  Apply and carry out this article and the rules adopted thereunder and perform any other lawful act which may be necessary or desirable to carry out the purposes and provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-99-04, § 2(2-203), 1-21-1999; Ord. No. O-11-02, § 2, 2-3-2011) 
Secs. 2-313-2-340. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - FINANCES[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Taxation, ch. 94. 
State Law reference- Finance, 65 ILCS 5/8-1-1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-341, 2-342. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-343. - Restrictions on indebtedness. 
    No indebtedness shall be incurred except such indebtedness as may be payable solely from the proceeds of a duly authorized bond issue or from a designated specified source, unless there is a prior appropriation out of which such indebtedness could be paid, as provided by statute. 
(Code 1963, § 7.203; Code 1975, § 2-217; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 2, 3-17-2005) 
Sec. 2-344. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-345. - Bills; payroll. 
    All bills payable by the village shall be submitted to the village board for approval before payment with the following exceptions: 
(1)  Employee salaries, payroll deductions, and benefits. 
(2)  Bond principal and interest payments. 
(3)  Other payments as authorized by the village manager. 
A listing of the payments made shall be provided to the village board for approval. 
(Code 1963, § 7.205; Code 1975, § 2-219; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 3, 3-17-2005) 
Sec. 2-346. - Annual audit. 
    As soon as practicable at the close of each fiscal year, and no later than six months thereafter, there shall be an audit of all accounts of the village made by a competent person authorized to act as an auditor under the laws of the state, to be designated by the village board. Copies of such audit report shall be filed with the village clerk and in such other places as may be required by law. 
(Code 1963, § 7.207; Code 1975, § 2-220; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 4, 3-17-2005) 
State Law reference- Audit of accounts, 65 ILCS 5/8-8-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-347. - Designated depositories. 
(a)  Pursuant to Section 3.1-35-50 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-50), as amended, the following financial institutions are hereby designated as depositories for village funds: 
(1)  Charter National Bank, 
(2)  Charter One Bank, 
(3)  Harris N.A., 
(4)  LaSalle Global Trust Services/Bank of America, 
(5)  First Eagle Bank, 
(6)  Fifth Third Bank, 
(7)  Or any other financial institution authorized by the village's investment policy and state statute. 
(b)  Each bank or saving and loan association designated as a depository shall comply with the requirements of Section 6 of the Public Funds Investment Act (30 ILCS 235/6), as amended. 
(c)  The authorized signatories for village accounts at designated depositories shall be two: (i) one of the village president or the village clerk, and one of the village manager or the finance director. 
(Ord. No. O-71-24, § 1, 6-17-1971; Code 1975, § 2-221; Ord. No. O-95-72, § 1, 10-19-1995; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 5, 3-17-2005; Ord. No. O-09-01, § 1, 1-15-2009; Ord. No. O-14-30, §§ 1, 2, 8-7-2014; Ord. No. O-15-07, § 2, 4-2-2015; Ord. No. O-15-18, § 2, 8-20-2015) 
Sec. 2-348. - Penalty for payment of any village fee or charge by a check which is not honored by the payor bank. 
(a)  Whenever any person has issued to the village a check in payment of any license fee, permit fee, charges for municipal utility service, charges for the use of village property, or special services rendered by the village, sums due the village on any contracts, sales tax, and all other sums due the village, by use of a check which is not honored by the payor bank, such person shall be required to redeem such check by a cash payment, and to pay an additional sum of $35.00. The cash payment for such check and the $35.00 penalty charge shall be paid to the village within seven days after written notice is sent to such person that the check which had been delivered to the village was not honored by the payor bank. 
(b)  In the event a cash payment required for the provisions hereof is not made within such seven-day period, the issuer of said check shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00, and each separate check so issued by a person which is not honored by the payor bank and shall be considered a separate offense hereunder. 
(Code 1975, § 2-222; Ord. No. O-77-57, § 1, 12-15-1977; Ord. No. O-84-35, § 1, 6-21-1984; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 6, 3-17-2005; Ord. No. 16-O-02, § 1, 1-7-2016) 
State Law reference- Civil liability for deceptive practices, 720 ILCS 5/17-1a. 
Secs. 2-349-2-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE 

Sec. 2-371. - Established; composition. 
    There is hereby created the department of finance for the village. This department shall consist of the director of finance, who shall be appointed by the manager, and such other officers and employees as may be authorized. The village manager shall serve as ex-officio director of finance until a separate appointment is made to fill such office. The director of finance shall have control and supervision over all employees assigned to this department. 
(Ord. No. O-72-26, § 1, 9-21-1972; Code 1975, § 2-230; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 7, 3-17-2005) 
Sec. 2-372. - Duties of director-Generally. 
(a)  The director of finance shall be charged with preparing and keeping all financial records of the village. Subject to the supervision of the manager, he shall make all purchases of materials, supplies, or equipment for the village, in the manner provided by law, ordinance, and rules and regulations of the village. 
(b)  He shall keep a current account of the amount appropriated each year and the sum spent out of each appropriation, showing the unexpended balance for each item. He shall prepare each year the tax levy ordinances in time for their enactment and filing as required by law. 
(c)  The director of finance shall serve as the village treasurer and is responsible for keeping accounts, showing at all times the fiscal condition of the village, including the current and anticipated revenues and expenses of all municipal funds and accounts. 
(d)  The director of finance shall also prepare and keep all bond registers and other records required by law to be kept by the treasurer, and shall prepare, sign, and publish the annual treasurer's report and any other report required by law. 
(Ord. No. O-72-26, § 1, 9-21-1972; Code 1975, § 2-231; Ord. No. O-78-65, § 1, 12-21-1978; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 8, 3-17-2005) 
Sec. 2-373. - Same-Payment of bills. 
(a)  The director of finance shall prepare a warrant for the payment of all sums due from the village listing each item and the account out of which it is payable, which warrant, when properly signed by the president and clerk, shall authorize the issuance of a voucher or check to be signed by the treasurer and countersigned by the village clerk or village president for the payment of each item. 
(b)  Each warrant shall contain the statement of the director of finance and of the village manager to the effect that all items contained therein are proper expenses due from the village for services performed or materials furnished to the village. Approval of such list of items to be paid by the village board on a roll call vote shall constitute the approval by the village of the payment of all expenses listed thereon; provided, however, the village board may, in the motion to approve payment, exclude specific items from such approval, in which case, such items shall not be paid. 
(Ord. No. O-72-26, § 1, 9-21-1972; Code 1975, § 2-232; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 9, 3-17-2005) 
Sec. 2-374. - Same-Revenues. 
    The director of finance shall receive and collect all license fees, permit fees, charges for municipal utility service, charges for the use of village property or special services rendered by the village, sums due the village on any contracts, taxes, and all other sums due the village. 
(Ord. No. O-72-26, § 1, 9-21-1972; Code 1975, § 2-233; Ord. No. O-05-17, § 10, 3-17-2005) 
Sec. 2-375. - Same-Additional duties. 
    The director of finance shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by statute or ordinance. He shall receive all money paid into the village whether directly from the person paying the money or from the hands of such other office or employee as may receive it, and he shall pay out money only on vouchers or orders properly signed by the president and the clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 2-234; Ord. No. O-79-12, § 2, 4-19-1979) 
Sec. 2-376. - Same-Deposit of funds. 
    The director of finance shall deposit village funds in such depositories as may be selected from time to time as provided by law, and he shall keep the deposit of village money separate and distinct from his own money and shall not make private or personal use of any village money. 
(Code 1975, § 2-235; Ord. No. O-79-12, § 2, 4-19-1979) 
Sec. 2-377. - Same-Records required. 
    The director of finance shall keep records showing all money received by him, the source from which it is received and the purpose for which it is paid; and he shall keep records at all times showing the financial status of the village. 
(Code 1975, § 2-236; Ord. No. O-79-12, § 2, 4-19-1979) 
Sec. 2-378. - Same-Books and accounts. 
    The director of finance shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance, and he shall keep them in the manner required by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1975, § 2-237; Ord. No. O-79-12, § 2, 4-19-1979) 
Sec. 2-379. - Same-Special assessment funds. 
    All moneys received on any special assessment shall be held by the director of finance as a special fund to be applied only to the payment of the improvement on bonds and vouchers issued therefor, together with interest thereon, for which the assessment was made. Payments on bonds or vouchers shall be made in accordance with statute. 
(Code 1975, § 2-238; Ord. No. O-79-12, § 2, 4-19-1979) 
Sec. 2-380. - Same-Warrants; transfers of funds. 
    All warrants drawn on the director of finance must be signed by the president and countersigned by the clerk, stating the particular fund or appropriation to which the same is chargeable and the person to whom payable. 
(Code 1975, § 2-239; Ord. No. O-79-12, § 2, 4-19-1979) 
State Law reference- Warrants, 65 ILCS 5/8-1-8 et seq. 
Sec. 2-381. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-06-17, § 1, adopted May 4, 2006, repealed § 2-381, which pertained to duties of director-investment of public funds and derived from § 2-240 of the 1975 Code; Ord. No. O-83-61, § 1, 10-20-1983; Ord. No. O-87-77, § 1, 11-19-1987. 
Secs. 2-382-2-410. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-16-28, § 2, adopted Dec. 1, 2016, amended Art. XI in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. XI, §§ 2-411-2-414, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1975, §§ 2-245-2-247; Ord. No. O-80-24, § 1, adopted May 15, 1980; and Ord. No. O-14-01, § 1, adopted Jan. 9, 2014. 

Sec. 2-411. - Department created. 
    There is hereby created the department of public works for the village. This department shall consist of the director of public works, the village engineer, and such other divisions and employees as may be provided for by the village manager. 
(Ord. No. O-16-28, § 2, 12-1-2016) 
Sec. 2-412. - Director-Office created; appointment; authority. 
    There is hereby created the office of director of public works. The director shall be appointed by the village manager as provided by law. The manager shall serve as ex officio director of public works until this office is filled by appointment. The director shall have control and supervision over all officers, divisions, and employees assigned to the department, subject to the control of the manager. 
(Ord. No. O-16-28, § 2, 12-1-2016) 
Sec. 2-413. - Same-Functions. 
(a)  The director of public works shall have charge of and supervision over all public property of the village including all streets, parks, parkways, sidewalks and all of the property of the village not specifically assigned to some other officer. 
(b)  The director shall have charge of and be responsible for the care, maintenance and operation of the village water distribution system, the sanitary sewer system and the disposal plants, the street lighting system, storm sewer system, and all streets, sidewalks, and the drains thereof. 
(c)  All construction, repair or extension of any pavement, building, sewer, light system, water mains and any appurtenances thereto, and all other construction, repair or maintenance work conducted by the village shall be done by or under the supervision of the director of public works. 
(d)  The director shall be the chief supervisory official of the village on and for all public improvements, and no work shall be accepted and payment made therefore except upon approval and certification by him. 
(e)  The director of public works shall also have charge of and be responsible for the purchase and maintenance of all motor vehicles, trucks and other equipment of the village, except as otherwise provided in this article, and of all buildings or places in which the same are housed or kept, and other duties as may be assigned by the village manager. 
(Ord. No. O-16-28, § 2, 12-1-2016) 
Sec. 2-414. - Fees and/or restitution for use of public works employees and equipment. 
    When public works personnel are requested or required to stand by or work for a non-village sponsored event, the person and/or entity responsible shall be required to pay or make restitution to the village, pursuant to the following fees for the cost of such personnel and equipment: 
(1)  $60.00 per hour per employee. 
(2)  A minimum of two hours shall be charged. Subsequent hours or portions thereof will be billed in 15-minute increments. 
(3)  Equipment-Department of Homeland Security, FEMA's Schedule of Equipment Rates per Hour or fraction thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-16-28, § 2, 12-1-2016) 
Secs. 2-415. - Village engineer. 
(a)  Village engineer qualifications. There shall be a village engineer within the department of public works. The village engineer shall be the assistant director of public works. The village engineer shall be a duly qualified engineer licensed by the state, and shall be appointed by the village manager as provided by law. 
(b)  Duties. The village engineer shall prepare or approve all plans and specifications of public improvements made or caused to be made by the village. The village engineer shall be responsible for the approval of all engineering plans and specifications, drainage, public improvements in subdivisions, performance and maintenance bonds, engineering related permits for water and sewer, plats and easement determinations, engineering reviews, plan approval and other duties as may be assigned by the director of public works or the village manager. 
(Ord. No. O-16-28, § 2, 12-1-2016) 
Secs. 2-416-2-430. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XIII. - CORPORATION COUNSEL AND VILLAGE ATTORNEY[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) ---

Sec. 2-451. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the office of corporation counsel and village attorney who shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the village board. 
(Ord. No. O-09-18, § 2, 6-18-2009) 
Sec. 2-452. - Duties and compensation. 
    The corporation counsel and village attorney shall receive such compensation and perform such duties as the village board may establish by contract with the attorney. The corporation counsel and village attorney shall be the chief legal officer of the village and shall attend all regular and special meetings of the village board. The village president and board of trustees may, in its discretion, employ additional counsel to handle such matters, or to assist the village's attorney on any matter. 
(Ord. No. O-09-18, § 2, 6-18-2009)
