Chapter 26 - CONDOMINIUM DEVELOPMENTS AND CONVERSIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; electricity, ch. 30; engineering standards and specifications, ch. 38; health and sanitation, ch. 54; planning, ch. 70; plumbing and sanitary code, ch. 74; rental residential housing code, ch. 82; streets, sidewalks and public places, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 110. 
State Law reference- Condominium Property Act, 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Purpose. 
    The president and board of trustees of the Village of Hanover Park, having found and determined that there is an increasing percentage of residential units in the village that are intended for condominium development and that a considerable portion of the village's rental housing is or may be converted to condominium status; that the prospective purchasers of these condominium units are often without knowledge of the unique concepts of ownership involved; that prospective purchasers of units in condominium conversions or in newly constructed condominiums often have little factual basis presented to them on which to make a decision that existing tenants of such projects may be displaced with insufficient time to find replacement housing in the area; and that in order to facilitate fair and equitable bargaining and to provide buyers of such condominium units with basic information by which to make an intelligent housing choice and promote the health, safety and welfare of the people, it is necessary and appropriate for the village to require that developers of condominium projects prepare and distribute information deemed relevant to the purchasers of this type of residential property. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-1; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-2. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply only to residential condominium projects containing three or more units, located within the Village of Hanover Park. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-2; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-3. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Act means the Condominium Property Act of the State of Illinois (765 ILCS 605/1 et seq.), and as it may from time to time be amended. 
    Agent means any person, firm, partnership, association, joint venture, corporation or any other entity or combination of entities who represents or acts for or on behalf of a developer in selling or offering to sell any condominium unit. 
    Blanket encumbrance means a trust deed, mortgage, judgment or other lien or encumbrance, including an option or contract to sell or a trust agreement affecting a condominium, including any lien or other encumbrance arising as a result of the imposition of any tax assessment by a public authority. 
    Board of managers or board means those owners elected to administer the property at the time and in the manner provided by the declaration for the property and vested with the rights, titles, powers, privileges, trusts, duties and obligations imposed by the Act, declaration and bylaws and, until such persons are or must be elected, shall mean the developer as herein defined. 
    Closing of sale means the operation of transferring ownership of a condominium unit to the purchaser from the developer through a deed of conveyance, or closing pursuant to articles of agreement or contract sale. 
    Common elements means all of the condominium, except the condominium units, including limited common elements unless otherwise specified. 
    Condominium means property subject to the condominium regime established pursuant to the Illinois Condominium Property Act. 
    Condominium project means the sale of or a plan by a developer to sell residential condominium units in existing buildings or buildings to be constructed or under construction under a common declaration. 
    Condominium unit or unit means a separate three-dimensional area within the condominium identified as such in the declaration and on the condominium plat and shall include all improvements contained within such area except those excluded in the declaration. 
    Conversion, convert, or like words means the offering for sale by a developer or his agent of a condominium unit occupied or rented for any purpose by any person before commencement of a condominium project which includes such unit. 
    Conversion condominium means a property improved with any building of three or more dwelling units which contain structures, excepting those newly constructed and intended for condominium ownership, which are, or have previously been, wholly or partially occupied before recording of condominium instruments by persons other than those who have contracted for the purchase of condominium units. 
    Declaration means the declaration required by the Illinois Condominium Property Act. 
    Department means the department of buildings of the Village of Hanover Park. 
    Developer means any person, firm, partnership, association, joint venture or corporation or any other entity or combination of entities or any successors thereto, who undertake to develop a condominium project, either by conversion of an existing structure(s), or construction of new buildings. 
    Limited common elements means a portion of the common elements so designated in the declaration as being reserved for the use of a certain unit or units to the exclusion of other units. 
    Offer means any inducement, solicitation, advertisement, publication or announcement by a developer to any person or the general public to encourage a person to purchase a condominium unit in a condominium project. 
    Person means any individual natural person, trustee, court-appointed representative, syndicate, association, partnership, firm, club, company, corporation, business trust, institution, agency, government corporation, municipal corporation, city, county, municipality, district, or other political subdivision, department, bureau, agency or instrumentality of federal, state or local government, contractor, supplier, vendor, installer, operator, user or owner, or any officers, agents, employees, factors, or any kind of representatives of any thereof, in any capacity, acting either for himself, or for any person, under either personal appointment or pursuant to law, or other entity recognized by law as the subject of rights and duties. The masculine, feminine, singular or plural is included in any circumstances. 
    Plat of condominium subdivision means the plat of a surveyor duly licensed by the State of Illinois establishing and describing condominium units and common elements. 
    Preliminary declaration means a declaration in the form referred to in the Illinois Condominium Property Act, provided, the legal description of units if not then ascertainable may be omitted and the allocation of percentage of ownership interest in common elements may be stated as tentative if accompanied by a preliminary plan and a statement in type size and style equal to at least ten-point boldface type as follows: 
THE DESCRIPTION OF UNITS AND PERCENTAGE OF OWNERSHIP INTEREST IN COMMON ELEMENTS HEREIN IS PRELIMINARY AND MAY BE CHANGED IN MATERIAL RESPECTS UPON THE RECORDING OF THE DECLARATION AND PLAT WHICH MUST OCCUR NO LESS THAN 30 DAYS PRIOR TO THE TIME OF THE FIRST CLOSING. 
    Property report means the property report required in accordance with article II of this chapter. 
    Prospective purchaser means a person who visits the condominium project site for the purpose of inspection for possible purchase or who requests a copy of the property report. 
    Site means the lot or lots, tract or tracts of land, described in the declaration referred to in the Illinois Condominium Property Act. 
    Unit owner means the person or persons whose estates or interests, individually or collectively, aggregate fee simple absolute ownership in a unit. 
    Village means the Village of Hanover Park. 
    Village manager means the duly appointed village manager of the Village of Hanover Park. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-3; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 26-4-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROPERTY REPORT 

Sec. 26-31. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any developer to offer for sale any condominium unit in a condominium project with three or more units prior to making available to the village and to prospective purchasers a property report which shall contain the information specified herein, provided that in the event information required herein is outside the control of the developer and will not be available to a developer until a later date, the property report may be distributed without said information, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The information will be distributed with the property report as soon as it becomes available in the form of a supplement to the property report, and copies are given to any person who previously executed a contract for the purchase of a unit along with a notice of the purchaser's right of rescission pursuant to the provisions of section 26-90. 
(2)  The property report identifies what information is required but is unavailable at the time, and states that the information will be provided as soon as it is available. 
(3)  All the information required in the property report shall be made available to prospective purchasers and given to persons who have signed contracts for the purchase of units at least 30 days before the closing of the first sale in the project. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-4; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-32. - Contents of property report. 
    The property report shall contain the following: 
(1)  Identification information including: 
(a)  Name of project, building addresses and number of units. 
(b)  The name, address and phone number of the developer, name and address of the legal and beneficial owner of the parcel, including all general partners of a partnership and officers and directors of a corporation. 
(c)  The names and addresses of all persons with a direct material financial interest in the property, including interim and permanent mortgage lenders secured by a blanket encumbrance. 
(d)  The names and addresses of the principal attorneys, accountants, architects, engineer and contractor for the property. 
(2)  A description of the property and improvements, including the following: 
(a)  Map or plat showing size and dimensions of the condominium project, together with all improvements, including recreational facilities, proposed construction and present and planned location of streets and roads, including driveways, access roads and parking areas. The share of ownership of each unit in the common elements shall be indicated. 
(b)  Description of the condominium units offered and the nature and extent of individual ownership in such condominium units, including the percentage of former renters who have purchased or contracted to purchase a condominium unit when the property is a conversion. 
(c)  Description, nature and ownership of all property and facilities on the site which are not part of the condominium project. 
(d)  Description of all existing and proposed facilities including, but not limited to recreational facilities within the condominium project. 
(e)  Location, nature and ownership of streets and roads, including driveways, access roads and parking areas, on and contiguous to the site. 
(f)  Drawings, architectural plans or other suitable documents setting forth the necessary information for location, maintenance and repair of all condominium facilities and equipment to the extent these documents exist. Such items may be incorporated in the property report by reference, shall be located at the sales office site or construction office site and shall be turned over to the board of managers upon transfer of control by the developer. 
(g)  Projected initiation and completion dates for proposed construction, renovation or conversion. 
(h)  Use permitted for individual condominium units by the declaration, bylaws of the condominium association or organization and applicable zoning provisions. 
(i)  Statement of title, listing all restrictions of record and the condition of title. 
(3)  If the purchase of all or any of the condominium units is to be financed by the developer or if financing has been arranged by the developer, a statement indicating: 
(a)  The name, address and telephone number of the person providing such financing. 
(b)  The interest rate to be charged. 
(c)  The down payment which will be required. 
(d)  The length of the mortgages being offered. 
(e)  The service charge (points) which will be charged. 
(f)  Any other fees which will be charged for considering an application for a mortgage or providing financing including, but not limited to, application fees and appraisal charges. 
(4)  Copies of the annual estimated operating budgets for the condominium project, projected for each year from the date of recording the declaration until control of the condominium project passes to the board of managers, to include monthly payments to be prorated to each condominium unit for maintenance and/or management of condominium property and charges for use of recreational and other facilities. In particular, the operating budget shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(a)  Operation costs: 
Supplies; 
Utilities; 
Heating fuels; 
Janitorial services; 
Trash and garbage disposal; 
Ground and building maintenance; 
Security; 
Maintenance and operation of recreational and other facilities; 
Elevator maintenance; 
Sidewalk, street and parking lot maintenance, including snow removal; 
Insurance; 
Other operating costs. 
(b)  Management costs: 
Legal and accounting services; 
Bookkeeping services; 
Management fees. 
(c)  Reserve costs: 
Reserve for improvements; 
Reserve for contingencies; 
Reserve for replacement and upkeep of common elements and facilities, including basis upon which reserves are calculated. 
If no reserve is provided for any one or more of the costs listed in this item, the following statement must be inserted in the property report in a type size and style equal to at least ten-point bold type: 
THE DEVELOPER HAS NOT PROVIDED A RESERVE FOR CERTAIN POSSIBLE FUTURE COSTS ON THE CONDOMINIUM IN HIS BUDGET. ACCORDINGLY, IT MAY BE NECESSARY TO PROVIDE FOR A SPECIAL ASSESSMENT TO ALL CONDOMINIUM UNIT OWNERS TO PAY FOR SUCH COSTS SHOULD THEY OCCUR. 
(5)  Maintenance and amenity costs which are not covered by the monthly assessment for which optional charges are or may be levied. 
(6)  Alternative provisions, if any, if an insufficient number of units are sold to cover the proposed operations and maintenance budget. 
(7)  Method and timing of transfer of control over the condominium elements to the board of managers and the nature, extent and duration of any interest, right or obligation retained by the developer. 
(8)  Rights and obligation of unit purchasers after closing and prior to election of the initial board of managers. 
(9)  In the case of a new construction or conversion of other legal status to condominiums, at the expense of developer, a report from a qualified State of Illinois licensed engineer or registered architect, not associated with the developer, stating his opinion concerning the condition and the rated life and expected useful life of the roof, foundation, external and supporting walls, mechanical, electrical, plumbing and structural elements and all other common facilities, together with an estimate of repair and replacement costs, at current market prices to put said items in compliance with the Hanover Park building code, and which shall indicate what the cost per category of unit would be if the unit owners were assessed for the estimated cost. This report shall include the approximate dates of installation of the facilities listed above and the dates of major repairs to such facilities. There shall also be attached a list of violations of the Hanover Park building code and rental residential housing code, or, if no notice of such violations has been received, the report shall so state. The engineer's or architect's State of Illinois license or registration number shall be indicated on the report. 
(10)  A statement of management and expected operation costs of the condominium, including: 
(a)  Name and address of management agent, if any, and the services the agent will perform. 
(b)  Length of term of any management or other contract affecting the use, maintenance or access to the condominium project, and charges and circumstances, if any, under which the charges may be increased. A copy of each contract shall be attached to the property report. 
(c)  The conditions, if any, under which the contracts may be cancelled or terminated. 
(d)  A statement disclosing any relationship between the developer and the management and other contracting firms and their respective corporate officers and/or controlling interest. 
(11)  Copies of the following documents numbered and indexed in such a manner as the developer may select, so as to permit ready reference thereto: 
(a)  The plat and declaration, or, if the declaration is not completed, a preliminary declaration as defined in section 26-3. 
(b)  The articles of incorporation or charter of the condominium association. 
(c)  The bylaws and regulations of the condominium association. 
(d)  Any leases of real or personal property applicable to the condominium of more than one year duration. 
(12)  A statement describing coverage and amounts of condominium insurance policies. 
(13)  A description of physical provisions made by the developer for pets, if any, and the restrictions on keeping same in the units, if any. 
(14)  If there are any restrictions upon the free sale, transfer, conveyance, encumbrance or leasing of a unit (including restrictions on the purchase of a unit by investors for rental purposes or by businesses for use by persons if authorized), then a statement in boldface type or capital letters in substantially the following form shall be included: 
THE SALE, LEASE OR TRANSFER OF A UNIT IS RESTRICTED OR CONTROLLED. 
Immediately following this statement, there shall appear a reference to the document, articles, paragraphs or pages in the disclosure materials where the units, restrictions or controls are set forth or described in detail. 
(15)  A statement describing the warranties required by section 26-62 of this chapter. 
(16)  Copies of the sales documents and literature, including but not limited to: 
(a)  Proposed contract for sale of unit. 
(b)  Deed or deeds of conveyance. 
(c)  Bill of sale. 
(d)  Trust deed, mortgage and promissory note, if financing is through the developer. 
(17)  Statement disclosing the existence of penalty if the construction, renovation or conversion or completion date is not met and the additional costs to be imposed if such date is not met. 
(18)  Statement disclosing the existence of the escrow account in which developer is required to deposit any deposit or advance payment in the purchase price pursuant to section 26-61 of this chapter, and the terms and conditions governing the escrowed funds and their release under the section. 
(19)  Statement of any pending litigation which might affect the condominium or the developer's ability to convey clear title. 
(20)  State of the current taxes and estimated possible changes in the tax situation of the condominium project which buyers may encounter during the first three years after the date of recording of the declaration and the formula used in making such estimates. 
(21)  Summary of past operating history of the condominium project, if any. 
(22)  A statement designating a person or firm responsible for the receipt of notices on behalf of the developer and responsible for answering inquiries by prospective purchasers or purchasers relating to the condominium. 
(23)  A statement of whether, and under what circumstances, the unit owners are required to be a member of, support, or participate financially in recreational facilities, such as, but not limited to, health clubs, exercise rooms, swimming pools, party rooms and golf putting greens. If any such facility is not part of the common elements, the following warning shall be included in capital letters in a type size and style equal to at least ten-point type: 
THE (HERE NAME FACILITIES) ARE NOT INCLUDED IN THE COMMON ELEMENTS. THESE FACILITIES ARE AVAILABLE TO UNIT OWNER FOR (HERE DESCRIBE MONTHLY CHARGE AND INITIATION FEE). UNIT OWNERS ARE NOT REQUIRED TO PARTICIPATE FINANCIALLY. 
(24)  A description of the location, ownership and availability to unit owners and the general public of accessory off-street parking associated with the condominium. 
(25)  A statement as to the existence of the Hanover Park Municipal Code chapter regulating condominiums and that a copy of same is attached to the property report. 
(26)  Each property report shall contain on the front page the following warning in capital letters, in a type size and style equal to at least ten-point bold type: 
VILLAGE OF HANOVER PARK LAW SPECIFICALLY PROHIBITS ANY REPRESENTATION TO THE EFFECT THAT THE VILLAGE HAS PASSED UPON THE MERITS OF OR GIVEN APPROVAL TO MAKE OR CAUSE TO BE MADE TO ANY PROSPECTIVE PURCHASER ANY REPRESENTATIONS WHICH DIFFER FROM THE STATEMENTS IN THIS PROPERTY REPORT. ORAL REPRESENTATIONS CANNOT BE RELIED UPON AS CORRECTLY STATING THE REPRESENTATIONS OF THE DEVELOPER AND ARE NOT BINDING ON THE DEVELOPER. REFER TO THE PROPERTY REPORT FOR CORRECT REPRESENTATIONS. 
(27)  The person or persons having a majority beneficial or legal interest in the ownership of the condominium project as of the date of the property report shall sign the property report and affirm that it and any supplements, modifications and amendments are true, full, complete and correct. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-5; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-33. - Amendments to property report. 
    The developer shall amend the property report from time to time when any material changes occur in any matter contained in such report. Amendments shall be made within 30 days after such change occurs or the developer has reason to know of such change. Amendments shall be attached to reports subsequently distributed to prospective purchasers and shall be immediately distributed to all purchasers of condominium units. Amendments shall be sent to the department prior to distribution. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-6; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-34. - Information in addition to property report. 
    In addition to the property report, a prospective purchaser shall be provided, prior to executing a contract for the purchase of a unit, the following information relating to said unit: 
(1)  A statement of the sales price, terms and conditions, including estimated closing and settlement costs. 
(2)  Estimated monthly assessment upon the unit and taxes on the unit based on previous year's tax bill. If the unit has not been assessed separately, estimated taxes on the unit may be stated and the formula used to estimate the taxes. 
(3)  Description of personal property which may be included in the sale, stating whether new or existing, including without limitation: Air conditioner, refrigerator, range, garbage disposal, dishwasher, clothes washer, clothes dryer, decorating and floor covering, and the change in sales price resulting from inclusion or exclusion of the items in the purchase, and in a statement of what, if any, warranties cover said personal property which will be transferred or given to purchaser at closing. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-7; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Secs. 26-35-26-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ESCROW AND WARRANTIES 

Sec. 26-61. - Escrow account required. 
    The developer shall establish an escrow with a bank or trust company having trust powers, an attorney who is a member of the Illinois Bar or title company authorized to do business in Illinois, with whom shall be deposited any deposit, payment or advance in the payment of the purchase price for a unit, received by the developer or his agent, other than a payment made for extra work ordered in writing by the purchaser of a unit. The escrowed funds shall be deposited in a separate account designated for this purpose, and conditions and release of escrowed funds shall conform to the following: 
(1)  If a purchaser legally terminates the contract of purchase the escrowed money shall be paid to him free of the cost of escrow. 
(2)  Prior to the closing of sale, no money shall be paid to the developer from escrowed funds, except upon a default by the purchaser. 
(3)  The account shall bear interest at least five percent per year, with all such interest to be credited to purchaser on the purchase price of the unit. 
(4)  Escrowed funds shall not be subject to attachment by the creditors of any party to the escrow or by the holder of a lien against any portion of the property. 
(5)  The cost of such escrow shall be borne by the developer. 
(6)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any payment received on account for the purchase of a completed condominium unit under articles of agreement for deed, installment agreement for deed, or lease with option to purchase, if the agreement provides for conveyance of title more than one year after the date of execution of the agreement. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-8; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-62. - Warranties. 
(a)  All sales contracts for the first-time sale of any condominium unit covered under this chapter shall contain the following express warranties by the developer: 
(1)  Common elements and systems. For the purposes of this section, "common elements and systems" shall refer to the roof, foundation, external and supporting walls and other structural elements, the electrical, plumbing, heating, central air conditioning and other mechanical systems, and all other common facilities, including but not limited to private sidewalks, recreational areas and common open space (but excluding decorating and carpeting). The developer shall warrant the materials, workmanship, construction, and condition of all such items or elements are as stated in the engineer's or architect's report required by section 26-32(9) herein, and that for a period of two years from the date control is turned over to the board of managers such items and systems shall properly perform the function for which each was designed to perform, except as provided in section 26-62(a)(3). The developer shall provide his own warranty, whether or not any manufacturer's warranty currently exists. 
(2)  Individual unit mechanical equipment. "Individual unit mechanical equipment" shall refer to all mechanical equipment including heating, electrical and plumbing systems physically located within the individually owned units. The developer shall warrant the materials, workmanship, operation, construction and condition of said items and systems, for a period of one year from the date of title transfer of that individual unit, to properly perform the function for which each was designed to perform, except as provided in section 26-62(a)(3). 
(3)  Warranty exclusions. The following are exempted from all of the above warranties provided the work was done in accordance with existing applicable codes: 
a.  Damage caused by acts of unauthorized third parties, including vandalism, negligence, failure to properly maintain and service in accordance or installer's specifications, or if none, then those of the developer, if any; or improper operation by anyone other than the developer or his employees, agents or subcontractors. 
b.  Acts of God and accidents, including but not limited to fire, explosion, smoke, water escape, windstorm, hail, lightning, flood and earthquake. 
c.  Normal wear and tear and normal deterioration. 
d.  Ordinary maintenance and repairs. 
(b)  The developer shall have the option to repair or replace warranted systems or elements, or to pay the cash value of such repair or replacement, except that where he fails upon notice and reasonable time as set forth below, to repair, replace, or pay for said item or system, or to state in writing why they do not fall within the warranty, the unit owners' association, or the unit owners, may decide whether to repair or replace the items. The developer shall not be required to honor his own warranty unless or until the unit owner or association, as the case may be, shall have first sought to enforce existing manufacturers' warranties. 
(c)  Following timely notification by a unit owner or the unit owners' association, the developer shall, during the period of the warranty, make any required repairs or replacements. If the developer fails to comply with the warranty provisions, the unit owners' association may notify the developer in writing of its intention to correct the condition at his expense. If the developer fails to comply within 14 days after being notified by the unit owners' association or as promptly as conditions require in case of emergency, the unit owners' association may have the work done and shall have recourse to the escrow or other security provided pursuant to section 26-62(e). 
(d)  In order to cause said warranty to be honored, the unit owners' association or the unit owner, as the case may be, shall give timely notice of any defect or failure of operation to the developer or his successor, all such notices to be during the period of warranty. 
(e)  To assure compliance with the warranties set forth in this section, the developer shall set up escrows or other appropriate security acceptable to the village manager, which shall provide for said escrows or other security to revert to sole control of the developer at the expiration of the different warranty periods unless outstanding claims exist against them. Escrows or other appropriate security shall be in an amount constituting the total of one percent of the sales price of each unit sold. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-9; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Secs. 26-63-26-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 

Sec. 26-81. - Lease of common elements/contracts. 
(a)  Any contract, lease or other agreement made prior to the election of a majority of the board of managers not controlled by the developer, by or on behalf of unit owners, individually or collectively, the unit owners' association or the board of managers, which extends for a period of more than two years from the recording of the declaration, shall be subject to cancellation by more than one-half of the votes of the unit owners other than the developer cast at a special meeting of members called for that purpose during a period of 90 days following expiration of the two-year period. During the 90-day period the other party to the contract, lease or other agreement shall also have the right of cancellation. 
(b)  The developer may not require, nor, except as established by the board of managers following assumption of control by unit purchasers, may the condominium bylaws require that a unit owner be a member of or participate in recreational or similar facilities which are not owned in fee simple by the unit owners or by an association in which they are members, individually or through the board of managers. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-10; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-82. - Parking facilities. 
(a)  No developer shall record a declaration or plat for a newly constructed or conversion condominium project unless parking facilities are located on or within the condominium property and are: 
(1)  Included in the common elements, or 
(2)  Divided as individual parking spaces among and designated as being a part of designated condominium units. 
(b)  The required parking lot or spaces shall be kept in good repair and be constructed in accordance with the Village of Hanover Park's engineering standards. The parking lot shall have markings for parking spaces. 
(c)  Each newly constructed condominium project shall have a minimum of two parking spaces per condominium unit, plus one extra parking space for every two condominium units. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-11; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-83. - False advertising. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise, sell or offer for sale any condominium unit by making any intentional, false misrepresentation or misstatement of a known fact set forth or required to be set forth in the property report required by this chapter. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-12; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-84. - Discrimination prohibited. 
    No person shall be denied the right to purchase or lease a unit because of race, religion, sex, marital status or national origin, nor shall any person advertise that same will be a reason for denial of the right to purchase or lease a unit. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-13; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
State Law reference- Civil rights violations re real estate transactions, 775 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq. 
Sec. 26-85. - Inspection of records. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to allow unit owners to inspect, during normal business hours, the financial books and records of the condominium project from the date of filing and recording of the condominium declaration relating to the management and maintenance of the common elements and expenses to which a unit owner's dues and assessments are applied. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-14; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-86. - Payment for common expenses exceeding estimate. 
    The developer will be held financially responsible for any intentional misrepresentation in his budget analysis as required by section 26-32(4). For the purposes of this chapter, intentional misrepresentation shall mean the underestimate of such total operating budget by the developer by over 20 percent. The developer shall pay all operating expenses for a given year which exceed his estimates for the year by 20 percent; i.e., the developer shall pay all operating expenses over the 20 percent; provided, however, the developer shall not be required to pay the excess amounts attributed to increased common expenses due to increases in the cost of fuel or usage of fuel which exceed the amount upon which said estimate was based, inflation and unforeseen circumstances including, but not limited to, unusually cold or hot weather, heavy snows, vandalism, acts of God or items requested by owners which are not customarily budgeted. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-15; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-87. - Retention of documents. 
    The board of managers shall keep a copy of the latest property report for seven years following the date of the property report's initial distribution. Upon reasonable notice, the property report shall be made available for inspection by any prospective purchaser of a unit. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-16; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-88. - Health and safety provisions. 
(a)  In newly constructed condominiums a four-hour firewall shall separate each individual condominium unit. 
(b)  Each newly constructed condominium building over three stories above grade shall be equipped with an elevator system approved by the department. 
(c)  In all condominium projects, separate water service and means of metering same shall be provided for each building. Each building shall have an individual outdoor water meter and master water shutoff valve. 
    In condominium projects where there are not separate meters for each unit the condominium instruments shall provide for payment of the water bills for all units to be paid by the condominium association as a common expense, and shall reflect that upon nonpayment of the water bill for a building the water service for the entire building may be shut off by the village. 
(d)  All condominium units shall be equipped with at least one battery operated smoke or heat detector and all hallways which are part of the common elements shall be equipped with electric smoke or heat detectors located at each end of the hallways. A smoke detector shall be located in all basement areas and in any laundry area or any space that can be used for storage. Location of same shall be approved by the department. 
(e)  Approved minimum ten-pound ABC fire extinguishers shall be located in metal cabinets with glass windows on each floor of a condominium building at least every 75 feet, and in any storage area and laundry room, in positions approved by the department. 
(f)  No unit in a condominium building may be sold as a condominium unit where more than 25 percent of the unit is located below ground level. 
(g)  Each condominium unit in a newly constructed condominium building shall have its own heating, hot water system and equipment. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-17; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-89. - Restrictions on advertising and sale. 
(a)  A developer shall not offer for sale or enter into an agreement or contract for the sale of any condominium unit within a condominium project unless: 
(1)  A property report, and any amendments or supplements thereto, as appropriate, are available for distribution to prospective purchasers, and copies of same have been filed with the department. 
(2)  Copies of all documents that were filed or required to be filed in connection with the condominium project with the registrar of titles or recorder of deeds of the county(ies) in which the property is located are available to prospective purchasers, and copies are on file with the department. 
(3)  A copy of the property report, any amendments, modifications and supplements thereto, and a copy of this chapter, are given to the prospective purchaser, upon his visit to the site or upon his request for information. 
(b)  A developer shall not execute a contract for the sale of any condominium unit within a condominium project unless: 
(1)  The prospective purchaser has been given an opportunity to read the property report, supplements and amendments thereto, as appropriate. 
(2)  A receipt signed by the prospective purchaser has been received by the developer or agent acknowledging that the prospective purchaser has received and has had an opportunity to review the report, supplements and amendments thereto, as appropriate. Such receipts are to be kept on file in the possession of the developer for a period of three years from the date of signature of the prospective purchaser and such receipts are subject to inspection by the department at any reasonable time. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-18; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-90. - Right of rescission. 
(a)  Unless a purchaser is given copies of the property report, all supplements and amendments thereto, and this chapter, before a contract for the purchase of a unit is executed, the purchaser may cancel the contract within five days of receiving the last of the foregoing. To be effective the notice of cancellation must be in writing and received by the developer prior to closing on the sale of the unit. 
(b)  No penalty shall be charged a purchaser for a cancellation made pursuant to subsection (a) herein. All payments made by purchaser and required to be placed in an escrow under section 26-61 of this chapter, plus whatever interest earned thereon, shall be refunded to a purchaser within ten days of the developer's receipt of notice of cancellation. 
(c)  The rights of purchasers under this section may not be waived in any purchase agreement and any attempted waiver is void. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-19; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-91. - Transfer of control. 
    Every declaration recorded pursuant to the Illinois Condominium Property Act after the effective date of this chapter shall provide that the election of the initial board of managers shall be held not later than 60 days after the conveyance by the developer of 75 percent of the units or three years after the recording of the declaration, whichever is earlier. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-20; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-92. - Notice of intent to convert. 
(a)  No less than 120 days prior to the recording the declaration pursuant to the Illinois Condominium Property Act, the developer of a conversion condominium shall give written notice to each tenant of the building of the intent to submit the property to the Act, and a copy of this chapter. 
    Any developer of a conversion condominium must, upon issuing the notice of intent, publish and deliver along with such notice of intent a schedule of selling prices for all units subject to the condominium instruments and offer to sell such unit to the current tenants, except for units to be vacated for rehabilitation subsequent to such notice of intent. Such offer shall not expire earlier than 30 days after receipt of the offer by the current tenant, unless the tenant notifies the developer in writing of his election not to purchase the condominium unit. 
    In addition, for a period of 120 days following his receipt of the notice of intent, any tenant who was a tenant on the date the notice of intent was given shall be given the right to purchase his unit on substantially the same terms and conditions as set forth in a duly executed contract to purchase the unit, which contract shall conspicuously disclose the existence of, and shall be subject to the right of first refusal. The tenant may exercise the right of first refusal by giving notice thereof to the developer prior to the expiration of 30 days from the giving of notice by the developer to the tenant of the execution of the contract to purchase the unit. 
(b)  A copy of the notice of intent to convert and an affidavit containing a list of tenants, including apartment numbers to whom notice was given and date of service, shall be delivered to the department before any unit is offered for sale. In addition to the foregoing notice, as soon as practicable after preparing the property report, the developer shall notify each tenant of the availability thereof and of the rights of a prospective purchaser to receive a copy thereof. 
(c)  Any tenant who was a tenant as of the date of the notice of intent and whose tenancy expires (other than for cause) prior to the expiration of 120 days from the date on which a copy of the notice of intent was given to the tenant shall have the right to extend his tenancy on the same terms and conditions and for the same rental until the expiration of such 120-day period by the giving of written notice thereof to the developer within 30 days of the date upon which a copy of the notice of intent was given to the tenant by the developer. 
    Each tenant in a conversion condominium shall be informed by the developer at the time the notice of intent is given whether his tenancy will be renewed or terminated upon its expiration. If the tenancy is to be renewed, the tenant shall be informed of all charges, rental or otherwise, in connection with the new tenancy and the length of the term of occupancy proposed in conjunction therewith. 
(d)  Notwithstanding lease provisions to the contrary, the tenant's premises will not be shown to prospective purchasers without the tenant's permission until the expiration of the tenant's option to purchase or 90 days prior to the end of the term of the tenant's lease, whichever is later. 
(e)  No lease or other agreement for the rental of property shall contain any provision which authorizes the lessor to terminate the lease less than 120 days from notice of intent to convert because of conversion of the property covered by the lease to a condominium or a unit of a condominium, or which authorizes the termination of a lease less than 120 days from notice of intent to convert as a part of any operation or transaction incident to such a conversion. No such provision of any lease or other agreement entered into after the effective day of this chapter shall be given any force or effect, and any such provisions are declared to be void. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-21; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-93. - Additional requirements of developer. 
    The developer shall be required to pay the maintenance, service, assessment and/or management fees for all unsold units through the date of closing of the sale of the unit. The fees for each such unsold unit shall be the same as would be attributed to a like sold unit. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-22; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Secs. 26-94-26-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BUILDING DEPARTMENT, INSPECTION, FEES 

Sec. 26-121. - Village inspections and reports. 
(a)  Any developer desiring to sell a unit as regulated by this chapter shall apply to the department for a certificate of occupancy with respect to such unit and with respect to the common elements of the property containing the unit. The applicant shall submit with the application the declaration and plat pertaining to the property and "as built" architectural drawings of the building and site development certified by a registered architect, provided that for conversion condominiums the developer need only submit what architectural drawings it has under its control. 
(b)  The village manager or his designee shall thereupon cause a visual inspection to be made of the unit and of the common elements to ascertain compliance with current codes. Based on said visual inspection, if any such unit is determined not to be in compliance with current codes, the developer may submit a request in writing for a waiver of the application of current codes to the village manager who will notify the president and board of trustees of said request. The village manager or his designee shall issue an opinion to the president and board of trustees as to whether the items requested to be waived pertain to life/safety factors of the applicable codes and whether he recommends for or against such a waiver, and the president and board of trustees shall, within 21 days of a request for waiver, grant or deny same, in whole or in part and upon such conditions as the president and board of trustees deem necessary to protect the public health, welfare and safety. 
    If a waiver is granted, the developer shall give to all prospective purchasers after the date of waiver, in addition to the other documents required by this chapter, and to all persons who have executed contracts for the purchase of a unit, within seven days of the date the waiver is given, a copy of the ordinance granting same, with a notice in substantially the following form attached thereto: 
NOTICE TO CONDOMINIUM BUYERS: 
The Village of Hanover Park in recognition of its responsibility to protect its current and future residents from inadequate disclosure and other unfair sales practices in the area of condominium sales has adopted an ordinance regulating condominiums within the Village of Hanover Park. In those situations where the strict enforcement of the provisions of that ordinance would produce an extreme financial hardship or result in a practical confiscation of property based upon evidence submitted by the developer or others on his behalf, the board of trustees has deemed it appropriate to grant a waiver from those provisions of that ordinance, thereby excusing the developer from certain responsibilities in connection with the condominium conversion. The granting of a waiver should not be construed to infer that the developer is or is not in compliance with all other village requirements. 
Section 26-121(b) of the Village Code requires a developer to give prospective purchasers a copy of the ordinance waiving any requirements of the village. Attached is a copy of said waiver ordinance. 
(c)  After the inspection, as provided for above, has been completed and compliance with current codes has been ascertained or waived pursuant to section 26-121(b) hereof, the department shall issue a certificate of occupancy with respect to each unit inspected. All of the certificates issued shall include therein a specification of each separate condition of noncompliance which has been waived pursuant to section 26-121(b) hereof. The department shall also issue to such applicant clear and legible copies of said certificates suitable for posting. 
(d)  Except as otherwise contained herein, no certificate of occupancy shall be issued if such unit, or the common elements pertaining thereto, are not in compliance with current codes. No closing on the sale of any condominium unit shall take place prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the unit and common elements. 
(e)  Upon issuance of the certificate of occupancy for a unit, it shall become the obligation of the applicant to keep copies of the certificates of occupancy for the common elements and all units in the sales office at the project and to make said certificates available for inspection by prospective purchasers and the village. The developer shall maintain documentation pertaining to each unit to establish that the purchaser of such unit has received from him or his agent a copy of the certificate of occupancy pertaining thereto at or before closing. These records shall be maintained and available for examination by appropriate authorities of the village. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-23; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-122. - Filing of plans. 
    True copies of the drawings and plans required herein to be filed with the department under this chapter, bearing the approval stamp of the department, shall remain on file in that office for a period of six months after the closing of the unit of such building, after which, upon demand, such drawings and plans shall be returned by the department to the person by whom they have been deposited. Additionally, one copy of the drawings and plans shall be given to the board of managers of the condominium association when control of the common elements are turned over to it. It shall be obligatory upon the board of managers to retain such drawings and plans in its custody. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-24; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-123. - Fees. 
    The applicant shall secure any necessary building permits at current fees and shall pay a $50.00 per condominium unit filing fee to the village prior to offering any unit for sale. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-25; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Secs. 26-124-26-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VIOLATIONS, ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 26-141. - Complaints. 
    The village manager is hereby authorized and directed to receive complaints and conduct such investigations as it deems necessary pursuant to the authority vested in that office. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-26; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-142. - Violation; settlement. 
    Whenever it is determined by the village manager that there has been a violation of this chapter or any duly adopted rule or regulation of the village that office is authorized, at its discretion to commence with one or more of the following procedures: 
(1)  Attempt to conciliate the matter by conference or otherwise and secure a written conciliation agreement; or 
(2)  Seek a written assurance of discontinuance which shall be signed by the developer and the director of department of buildings; or 
(3)  Request the village attorney to institute injunctive or other appropriate action or proceeding in any court of competent jurisdiction to obtain a restraining order, permanent or temporary injunction or any other appropriate form of relief, including the penalty provisions hereof. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-27; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-143. - Penalties. 
    Any person who willfully violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter, and, upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $300.00 for the first offense, and not less than $300.00 nor more than $500.00 for the second and each subsequent offense within 180 days of a prior offense. A separate and distinct offense shall be regarded as committed each day on which a violation exists. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-28; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-144. - Other relief. 
    Nothing herein shall prevent any person from exercising any right or seeking any remedy to which such person might otherwise be entitled, or from filing an appropriate complaint with a court of law or equity. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-29; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980) 
Sec. 26-145. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and an independent provision and such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions thereof. It is hereby declared to be the legislative intent of the village board of Hanover Park that this chapter would have been adopted had such unconstitutional or invalid section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this chapter not been included. 
(Code 1975, § 71/2-30; Ord. No. O-80-55, § 1, 12-18-1980)

State Law reference- Municipal regulation of electrical wiring, 65 ILCS 5/11-8-2; inspection of electrical equipment, 65 ILCS 5/11-37-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - ELECTRICAL CODE 

Sec. 30-1. - Adopted. 
    The regulations of the 2011 edition of the National Electrical Code, 2011 NEC, as recommended and published by the National Fire Protection Association, published in pamphlet form, are adopted as the regulations governing the installation, alteration, and use of electrical conductors, equipment, raceways, and systems in the village with such amendments as are hereafter set forth in section 30-2 below. 
(Code 1975, § 9-1; Ord. No. O-82-14, § 2, 2-18-1982; Ord. No. O-85-30, § 1, 6-6-1985; Ord. No. O-87-62, § 1, 9-17-1987; Ord. No. O-94-25, § 24, 6-2-1994; Ord. No. O-96-01, § 1, 1-5-1996; Ord. No. O-05-66, § 1, 12-1-2005; Ord. No. O-15-02, § 4, 2-5-2015) 
State Law reference- Municipal Adoption of Codes and Records Act, 50 ILCS 220/0.01 et seq. 
Sec. 30-2. - Electrical code amendments. 
(a)  Section 90.4 is amended by adding: 
Upon notice from the code official that electrical work is being done contrary to the provisions of this code or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, such work shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work. The notice shall state the condition under which work is authorized to resume. Where an emergency exists, the code official shall not be required to give a written notice prior to stopping work. Any person who shall continue any electrical work after having been served a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable for a fine of not less than one hundred ($100.00) dollars or more than one thousand ($1,000.00) dollars. 
(b)  Section 210.11 (A) is amended by adding: 
Electrical service in the form of at least one duplex outlet and one overhead light must be provided to each garage at the time of construction. There shall be two circuits provided to each garage, one for lighting and one for power. 
(c)  Section 220.14 is amended by adding the following: 
(M)  Dedicated circuits: All dedicated circuits shall be wired to a single receptacle outlet, i.e., microwave, sump, or ejector pump. 
(d)  Section 230.11 is added to read as follows: 
Service entrance conductor and cable: No EMT for any service entrance is allowed. No service entrance cable is allowed. 
(e)  Section 230.12 is added to read as follows: 
The minimum size conduit for 100 amp services is one and one-fourth inch. 
(f)  Section 230.13 is added to read as follows: 
Service entrance connectors: The use of no-thread connectors on the line side of the service or main breaker is not allowed. 
(g)  Section 230.67 is added to read as follows: 
Grounding bushing: Grounding bushings are required on all concentric and eccentric knockouts used in the meter socket and breaker panel, with a bonding jumper sized appropriately. 
(h)  Section 310.2(B) is amended to read as follows: 
Conductors in this article shall be copper and not aluminum or copper-clad aluminum except when supplied by the utility company and when located on the utility side of the meter. 
(i)  Section 314.20 is amended by adding the following: 
All ceiling boxes to be fan rated except hallways and closets. 
(j)  Articles 330 (Type MC), 332 (Type MI), and 334 (Type NM, NMC, NMS) are deleted. 
All wiring systems shall be installed in a metal raceway or conduit. 
(k)  Section 352.12 is amended by adding the following: 
(F)  The use of plastic pipe and electric boxes is not allowed above grade. Plastic pipe which is listed for below grade can be used. It shall have a ground conductor installed, and it shall transition to a metal pipe before the elbow, which turns up. 
(l)  Section 680.40 is amended by adding the following: 
Spa and tubs general: The equipment shall connect to the electric system with a single receptacle outlet with a GFCI-protected circuit breaker. The connection shall be accessible. 
(Code 1975, § 9-2; Ord. No. O-82-14, § 2, 2-18-1982; Ord. No. O-85-30, § 2, 6-6-1985; Ord. No. O-87-62, § 1, 9-17-1987; Ord. No. O-88-28, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. O-89-45, §§ 16, 17, 7-20-1989; Ord. No. O-94-25, §§ 25, 26, 6-2-1994; Ord. No. O-96-01, §§ 2, 3, 1-5-1996; Ord. No. O-96-25, § 1, 5-16-1996; Ord. No. O-05-66, § 2, 12-1-2005; Ord. No. O-15-02, § 4, 2-5-2015) 
Sec. 30-3. - Electrical fee schedule. 
    To provide for costs of administration and inspection, fees required by this chapter shall be as set forth in this section and shall be paid prior to the issuance of the permit. This fee shall be paid only when electrical work is not a part of new construction and when plan review is not required. When electrical work is part of new construction and/or when plan review is required, the fee for the building permit shall be computed according to sections 18-152 and 18-151. The fees required by this chapter shall be paid according to the following schedule and shall be computed on a cumulative basis: 
(a)  The term "circuit" as used in this section shall mean any set of branch lighting conductors which have been extended from a distribution center and which may be utilized for the transmission of electric energy. 
(b)  Service installation fees: 
100 amperes ..... $35.00 
200 amperes ..... 40.00 
Each additional 100 amperes ..... 7.50 
(c)  Branch circuits fees: 
15 and 20 amperes (two-wire): 
0 to 50 circuits, each ..... 8.00 
Additional circuits, each ..... 4.00 
Branch circuits exceeding 20 amperes (two-wire): 
All circuits, each ..... 16.00 
(d)  For each three-phase circuit of 15 and 20 amperes nominal capacities, the fee shall be three times the fee charged for two-wire circuits. For each three-phase circuit exceeding 20 amperes nominal capacity, the fee shall be $25.00 for each circuit. 
(e)  Motor or current consuming device: 
First motor or device ..... $15.00 
Each additional ..... 5.00 
(f)  Fixtures, sockets and receptacles (not including circuit wiring): 
1 to 15 ..... 5.00 
Each additional 5 or fraction thereof ..... 1.00 
(g)  For all miscellaneous inspections, the fee shall be ..... 35.00 
(h)  The minimum permit fee shall be ..... 35.00 
    When permits are voided, new permits shall be obtained and regular fees paid before work can be started or continued. 
(Code 1975, § 9-3; Ord. No. O-82-14, § 2, 2-18-1982; Ord. No. O-85-30, §§ 4-6, 6-6-1985; Ord. No. O-88-18, § 7, 4-7-1988; Ord. No. O-94-25, § 27, 6-2-1994) 
Secs. 30-4-30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ELECTRICAL COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 30-31. - Created; composition. 
    There is hereby created an electrical commission consisting of five members appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The village president shall select one of its members as chairman. 
(Code 1975, § 9-7; Ord. No. O-82-14, § 2, 2-18-1982) 
Sec. 30-32. - Terms, qualifications of members. 
(a)  Each member shall be appointed for a three-year term or until his successor shall have been appointed. The terms of the initial appointees shall be staggered so that the term of one member shall be for one year, two members for two years and two members for three years. 
(b)  One member shall be a registered professional engineer, one an electrical contractor, one a journeyman electrician, one a representative of an inspection bureau maintained by the American Insurance Association, or the chief of the fire department, and one a representative of an electrical supply house. The electrical inspector shall be an ex officio member. 
(Code 1975, § 9-8; Ord. No. O-82-14, § 2, 2-18-1982) 
Chapter 34 - EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER PROGRAM[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46; police, ch. 78. 
State Law reference- Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act, 20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq. 

Sec. 34-1. - Emergency service and disaster agency established. 
    There is hereby created the Hanover Park Emergency Service and Disaster Agency (HP-ESDA) to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or damage resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or from natural or manmade disaster, in accordance with The Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act (20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.), as amended. The HP-ESDA shall consist of the coordinator and such additional members as may be selected by the coordinator. 
(Ord. No. O-96-38, § 1(8-1), 7-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-2. - Coordinator of agency. 
(a)  The coordinator of the HP-ESDA shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees and shall serve until removed by same. 
(b)  The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training, and operation of the HP-ESDA, subject to the direction and control of the village president as provided by statute. In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability to serve as the coordinator, the village president shall be and act as coordinator until a new appointment is made as provided by the Emergency Interim Executive Succession Act (5 ILCS 275/7), as amended. The emergency interim successors of the village president shall be those in the following order of preference: the deputy village president, the village trustees by seniority, the village clerk, and the village manager. 
(Ord. No. O-96-38, § 1(8-2), 7-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-3. - Functions of agency. 
    The HP-ESDA shall perform such ESDA functions within the village as shall be prescribed in and by the state ESDA plan and program prepared by the governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor, and in addition shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with other political subdivisions and private organizations as provided in the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act (20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.), as amended. 
(Ord. No. O-96-38, § 1(8-3), 7-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-4. - Service of members of emergency management organization as mobile support team. 
(a)  All or any members of the HP-ESDA organization may be designated as members of a mobile support team created by the director of the state ESDA as provided by law. The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the coordinator of the HP-ESDA organization. 
(b)  Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee or officer while serving on call to duty by the governor, or the state director, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights, and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of the village, while so serving, shall receive from the state reasonable compensation as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. O-96-38, § 1(8-4), 7-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-5. - Agreements with other political subdivisions. 
    The coordinator of HP-ESDA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other subdivisions of the state and private organizations, but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the village president and board of trustees and by the state director of ESDA. 
(Ord. No. O-96-38, § 1(8-5), 7-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-6. - Emergency action. 
    If the governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from manmade or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the HP-ESDA to cooperate fully with the state ESDA and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. O-96-38, § 1(8-6), 7-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-7. - Reimbursement by state. 
    The coordinator shall request from the state treasurer reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training members of the HP-ESDA as prescribed by the state director of ESDA, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the village in response to a call by the governor or state director of ESDA, as provided by law, and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to ESDA activities as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. O-96-38, § 1(8-7), 7-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-8. - Purchases and expenditures. 
(a)  The village manager may, on recommendation of the HP-ESDA coordinator, authorize any purchase of contracts necessary to place the village in a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any nuclear or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and safety, protect property, and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of such disaster, or from manmade or natural disaster. 
(b)  In the event of enemy-caused or other disaster, the HP-ESDA coordinator is authorized, on behalf of the village, to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency, without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to contracts or obligations, as authorized by the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act (20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.), as amended, and this Code. 
(Ord. No. O-96-38, § 1(8-8), 7-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-9. - Oath of members of emergency management organization. 
    Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the village ESDA organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the following oath, which shall be filed with the coordinator: 
I, ___________, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions, and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; and I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Hanover Park ESDA organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence. 
(Ord. No. O-96-38, § 1(8-9), 7-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-10. - Office space. 
    The village manager is authorized to designate space in a village building, or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the village president, for HP-ESDA as its office. 
(Ord. No. O-96-38, § 1(8-10), 7-18-1996) 
Sec. 34-11. - Emergency government location. 
    Whenever, due to a local disaster, it becomes imprudent, inexpedient or impossible to conduct the affairs of the village at the regular or usual place, the president and board of trustees may meet as provided in the Emergency Government Relocation Act (50 ILCS 5/0.01 et seq.), as amended, by the written notice of the village president or any three trustees filed with the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. O-96-38, § 1(8-11), 7-18-1996) 
Chapter 38 - ENGINEERING STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; condominium developments and conversions, ch. 26; planning, ch. 70. 
State Law reference- Local improvements, 65 ILCS 5/9-1-1 et seq.; municipal streets and public ways, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-1 et seq.; municipal utilities, 65 ILCS 5/11-117-1 et seq.; municipal water supply and sewage systems, 65 ILCS 5/11-124-1 et seq.; construction and purchase of waterworks, 65 ILCS 5/11-130-1 et seq.; utilities, 220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be designated as the "Engineering Standards and Specifications for the Village of Hanover Park, Illinois." 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-1; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(1.00), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-2. - Intent and purpose. 
    While it is obvious that regulations are needed to assure orderly extension of village improvements, the other purposes of these regulations are: 
(a)  To insure sound, harmonious development and community growth, and to safeguard the interest of the owner, the developer, the investor and the village. 
(b)  To provide permanent assets to the locality and to the village. 
(c)  To minimize scattered development beyond existing public utilities and prevent excessive development costs. 
(d)  To assure the development of land for optimum use with necessary protection against deterioration and obsolescence. 
(e)  To limit and control the pollution of the environment that can be caused by inadequate or incomplete urban development. 
(f)  To provide common grounds of understanding and a sound working relationship between the village and the developer. 
(g)  To lessen congestion in the streets and highways. 
(h)  To attempt to provide for adequate light and air. 
(i)  To facilitate adequate provision for transportation, water, sewerage, schools and other public necessities. 
(j)  To ensure proper legal description and proper monumenting of subdivided land. 
    The regulations are established with reasonable consideration of the character of the village with a view toward conserving the value of buildings upon the land and providing the best possible environment for human habitation. It is intended that these regulations shall supplement and facilitate the enforcement of the provisions and development standards contained in the building code, official map regulations, zoning ordinance, and the official village comprehensive plan, and the subdivision regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-2; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(2.00), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-3. - Jurisdiction. 
    The engineering standards and specifications of the Village of Hanover Park, Illinois shall apply to all improvements as defined herein, located within the Village of Hanover Park and entirely or in part within the unincorporated area within 11/2 miles of the corporate limits of the village, in accordance with chapter 65 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes (65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq.), as amended. The proposed improvements to be installed, and all procedures relating thereto, shall in all respects be in full compliance with the regulations herein. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-3; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(3.00), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-4. - Improvements generally. 
(a)  Public improvements. The public improvement requirements, standards and specifications contained herein are adopted as the minimum required standards and specifications for public improvements of the village. When public improvements are required by application for subdivision, no such improvements may be made until the plats for the subdivision and also the plans for improvements thereto have been formally recommended by the Hanover Park Plan Commission and approved by the board of trustees. The village engineer is designated as the enforcing officer of the public improvement requirements, standards and specifications contained herein. When public improvements are made other than as part of the subdivision no such improvements may be made until the plans are approved by the village engineer. If any improvements are being constructed in violation of regulations contained herein, it shall be the responsibility of the village engineer, or his designee, to stop such construction until there is full compliance with said regulations. 
(b)  No improvements shall be approved for any use in any area which is determined after investigation by the village engineer to be located within areas of special flood hazard until the subdivider has complied with article III of this chapter. 
(c)  No improvements shall be approved for any use in any area which is determined after investigation by the village engineer, to be unsuitable for such a use by reason of flooding or bad drainage, adverse earth and rock formation or topography, or any other features likely to be harmful to the health, safety or welfare of the public. 
    Unsuitable land and any improvements located within areas of special flood hazard and identified in article III of this chapter shall be subject to the provisions of that article. 
    Unsuitable land and any improvements located outside of special flood hazard may be developed only if the developer agrees to make improvements which will, in the opinion of the village engineer, make the area safe for occupancy and provide adequate lot and street drainage and stormwater detention facilities. 
(d)  Where the developer of land outside areas of special flood hazard can show in writing and with appropriate documentation that the strict adherence to the standards and specifications set forth causes an unnecessary hardship, the village board may approve a variance. Such variance may be granted after recommendation by the village engineer and where topography and conditions peculiar to the site or surrounding area substantiates a variance without destroying the intent of the provisions of this chapter. 
    Variances for land within areas of special flood hazard shall be subject to the provisions of article III of this chapter. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-4; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(4.00), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-5. - Interpretation. 
(a)  Minimum standards established. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(b)  Higher standards govern. Where the conditions imposed by any other provisions of this chapter or any other applicable law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation of any kind, the regulations which are more restrictive and impose higher standards or requirements shall govern. 
(c)  Easements or covenants not abrogated. This chapter is not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant or any other private agreement, provided that where the regulations of this chapter are more restrictive or impose higher standards or regulations than such easement, covenant or other private agreement, the requirements of this chapter shall govern. 
(d)  Existing improvements. No improvements which were not lawfully existing at the time of the adoption of this chapter, shall be made lawful solely by reason of the adoption of this chapter; and to the extent that said improvements are in conflict in any manner with the requirements of this chapter, said improvements remain unlawful hereunder. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-5; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(4.01), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-6. - Adoption of references. 
    The latest editions with any revisions thereof of the following documents are hereby identified as parts of this chapter and are incorporated herein: 
(a)  United States Geological Survey Maps, Washington, D.C. 
(1)  Floods in Streamwood Quadrangle, Atlas HA-203. 
(2)  Floods in West Chicago Quadrangle, Atlas HA-202.

ARTICLE II. - RULES AND DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 38-31. - Generally. 
    In the interpretation of this chapter, the rules and definitions contained in this article shall be observed and applied, except when the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-21; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(5.00), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-32. - Language construction. 
    The language set forth in the text of this chapter shall be interpreted in accordance with the following rules of construction: 
(a)  Words used in the present tense shall include the future, the words used in the singular number shall include the plural number, and the plural the singular. 
(b)  The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary. 
(c)  The word "may" is permissive. 
(d)  The word "lot" shall include the words "plot," and "piece," and "parcel." 
(e)  The phrase "used for" shall include the phrases "arranged for," "designed for," "intended for," "maintained for," and "occupied for." 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-22; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(5.01), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-33. - Words, terms, phrases defined. 
    ADT: Average daily traffic. 
    Alley: The right-of-way which affords secondary means of access to properties abutting upon a street. 
    Applicant: The owner or contract purchaser of land proposed to be subdivided or his legal representative. 
    Apron: An extension of a driveway lying between the public sidewalk (or the right-of-way line if there is no sidewalk) and the curb and gutters of a street. The maintenance responsibility for this facility normally being with the owner of the driveway so extended. 
    Block: A tract of land bounded by streets, or by a combination of one or more streets and public parks, cemeteries, railroad rights-of-way, shore lines or waterways, or corporate limit lines. 
    Bond: Any form of security approved as to form by the village attorney including a cash deposit, surety bond, letter of credit, collateral or instrument of credit in an amount or form accepted by the board of trustees. 
    Borings, soil: Examination and analysis of the subsoil conditions of a specific parcel of land by drilling. 
    Building: A structure, with a permanent roof, separated on all sides from adjacent open space by exterior or party walls, built for the support, shelter or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels or property of any kind, and which is permanently affixed to the ground. 
    Building permit: A permit issued by the Village of Hanover Park for the construction, erection or alteration of a structure or building. 
    Building setback line: A line parallel to the dedicated right-of-way line or parallel to the private street edge of pavement, at a distance from it as regulated by the Hanover Park zoning ordinance.
