(b)  Portland cement concrete shall be proportioned according to the applicable sections of the state standard specifications and shall be designed for a minimum 28-day compressive strength of 3,500 psi. Air entrainment shall be four to seven percent and slump between two inches and four inches. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-59; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(7.08), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-110. - Subgrade preparation. 
    The subgrade of all roads shall be graded and rolled in accordance with section 212 of the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, current edition, by the department of transportation, hereinafter referred to as "state standard specifications." Particular attention is directed to the requirements for the replacement of soft and unstable material as contained in article 202.03. Embankment shall be placed and compacted in accordance with section 207 of said specifications. 
    At least one standard density test (performed in accordance with AASHTO T99) shall be taken in each fill section, with the maximum distance between tests of 300 feet. One standard proctor test shall be taken from each different source of borrowed material, if required by the village engineer. The proctor and density tests must be submitted for review and approval by the village engineer. Upon approval of these tests, an inspection of the subgrade will be made by the village, and the subgrade must be approved prior to placing any type of curb and gutter or base material. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-60; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(7.09), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-111. - Grades. 
    The longitudinal gradient shall not be in excess of four percent on primary, major or secondary streets, nor in excess of six percent on other streets, unless approved by the village engineer, nor will it have a minimum of less than 35/100 of one percent. 
    Where the gradient of the street warrants installation of vertical-type curb and other special design of improvements due to right-of-way conditions, such as double inlets, the village engineer is authorized to require said design. 
    The minimum length of vertical curves shall be 100 feet for 1.5 percent difference of grade. For each additional one percent difference in grade over 1.5 percent, a 50-foot increment shall be added to the length of vertical curve. If the grade differential is less than 1.5 percent, a vertical curve is not required. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-61; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(7.10), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-112. - Sight distances. 
    The village engineer shall show at the points of intersection of proposed roads with existing roads that the minimum stopping sight distance indicated below for the legal speed limit is provided on existing roads. 
Legal Speed Limit Minimum Stopping Sight Distance 
(feet) 25-30 200 31-40 275 41-50 350 51-60 475 61-70 600  
(Code 1975, § 91/2-62; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(7.11), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-113. - Curbs and gutters. 
    Combination curb and gutters shall be concrete with a two-inch minimum compacted granular subbase and shall conform to the Village of Hanover Park standard details. 
    On major collector, local collector or industrial/business service streets, all curb and gutter at the parkway side of the road shall be B-6.12 barrier type of curb and gutter except at driveways, ramps and except where the village engineer approves a modification to conform with an existing curb and gutter. On arterial streets all curbs and gutters shall be B-6.18. 
    The concrete used for the curb and gutter shall be of class X concrete and conform with the Illinois Department of Transportation publication, Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, section 500, entitled "Concrete for Structures and Incidental Construction" and section 700, "Materials." 
    On minor multifamily residential, minor single-family residential and cul-de-sac streets, all curb and gutters at the parkway side of the road shall be roll-type of curb and gutter except at driveways, ramps and except where the village engineer approves a modification to conform with an existing curb and gutter. At crosswalks, sidewalk ramps will be constructed in accordance with the Village of Hanover Park standard details, "Sidewalk Ramps for the Handicapped." 
    At concrete medians, the curb and gutter shall be reversed slope B-6.12. 
    All minor private streets shall have a six-inch by 18-inch concrete barrier curb, type B, constructed on both sides. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-63; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(7.12), 5-21-1981; Ord. No. O-84-32, § 2, 6-7-1984) 
Sec. 38-114. - Sidewalks. 
    All public walks designed for pedestrian travel shall be improved with not less than five inches of class X Portland cement concrete pavement, six inches at driveways and extending three feet each side of the driveway. The width shall be at least four feet in areas zoned residential and five feet in other areas. Sidewalks shall be poured on a two-inch compacted granular subbase. Expansion joints are to be placed 50 feet on center. 
    Construction joints are to be troweled-in four feet on center for four-foot sidewalks and five feet on center for five-foot sidewalks. The sidewalk shall have a cross-slope of one-quarter inch per foot down toward the street and be elevated one inch above the finished grade of the parkway. The parkway shall be pitched down from the sidewalk toward the street with a minimum pitch of one-quarter inch per foot to a maximum of three-quarters inch per foot. Sidewalks shall meet the requirements of the following applicable sections of Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction of the Illinois Department of Transportation: section 600, Incidental Construction and Diagram D; section 700, Materials. 
    Whenever a side of a street in a block of a development is more than 75 percent completed by the building of structures on such block, sidewalks must be installed by the developer on all vacant premises to provide a continuity of sidewalks. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-64; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(7.13), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-115. - Maintenance and responsibility. 
(a)  The maintenance and responsibility for all CPD or private roadways shall be accountable to the developer/owner or homeowners' association. 
(b)  All streets, curbs, gutters and sidewalks shall be under warranty for all defects and failures in base course, as well as surface course for a period of two years. A guarantee for those improvements which will be dedicated to the village shall be for a period of two years after the date of acceptance. Those improvements in private areas shall be guaranteed for one year from the date of release of the subdivision improvement security. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-65; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(7.14), 5-21-1981) 
Secs. 38-116-38-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STREET NAME SIGNS AND STREET LIGHTING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, ch. 86. 

Sec. 38-141. - Street name signs. 
    Street name signs should be erected at all street intersections regardless of other route marking that may be present. Lettering on street name signs should be at least four inches high. Supplementary lettering to indicate the type of street (e.g., Street, Avenue, Road, etc.) or section of city (e.g., N.W.) may be in smaller lettering, at least two inches high. Conventional abbreviations are acceptable except for the street name itself. 
    The street name sign should be reflectorized or illuminated. The legend and background shall be of contrasting colors and should have a white message and border on a green background. 
    In business districts and on principal arterials, street name signs should be placed at least on diagonally opposite corners so that they will be on the far righthand side of the intersection for traffic on the major street. Signs naming both streets should be erected at each location. They should be mounted with their faces parallel to the streets they name and they shall be installed at a height of seven feet and not less than two feet nor more than six feet from the edge of the pavement. Where possible they shall be installed adjacent to street lighting. Street name signs shall be permanently anchored in concrete. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-71; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(8.01), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-142. - Traffic control devices; pavement markings. 
    All traffic control devices and signals, except traffic control light signals, shall be installed on all streets in accordance with the standards in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, Illinois Department of Transportation, Springfield, Illinois, and approved by the village engineer. 
    All streets shall be striped with lane markings in accordance with the standards in the Manual on Traffic Control Devices, Illinois Department of Transportation, Springfield, Illinois, and approved by the village engineer. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-71.5; Ord. No. O-83-54, § 2, 9-1-1983) 
Sec. 38-143. - Street lighting. 
(a)  Description. Streetlights and appurtenances shall be installed according to: 
(1)  The American Standard Practice for Roadway Lighting, current edition. 
(2)  The National Electric Code, current edition. 
The streetlight system consists of the poles, mast arms, luminaries, wire and all other materials and work necessary to complete the street lighting installation. 
The street lighting system is to be constructed within the right-of-way or easements for improvements to be accepted by the village and in locations shown on the approved plan for comprehensive planned developments. 
(3)  All streetlights and appurtenances and installation and operation shall conform to the current requirements of Commonwealth Edison Company. All streetlight engineering and plans must be approved by Commonwealth Edison Company prior to final approval by the village engineer. Any requirements of Commonwealth Edison Company shall override any requirements of this section where appropriate. 
(b)  Streetlight spacing. Streetlights are to be located at all intersections, as well as along street blocks as indicated in the following table: 
_____
TABLE 3 
Street Type Mounting Height Pole Height Spacing Measured Along Centerline Luminaries Type and Wattage Initial Lumens Arterial 35'0? 33' 175' 250-HPS* 30,000 Collector: Major 30'10? 28' 175' 150-HPS 16,000 Local 30'10? 28' 200' 150-HPS 16,000 Multifamily 25'10? 23' 250' 150-HPS 16,000 Single-family 25'10? 23' 250' 150-HPS 16,000 Private 25'10? 23' 250' 150-HPS 16,000 Commercial 30'10? 28' 200' 150-HPS 16,000  
    *HPS-High Pressure Sodium 
_____
(c)  Location. Street lights shall be located on one side of the street, unless in the judgment of the village engineer, it is impractical to do so. All street light poles shall be set three feet back from curb line. At intersections with only one standard, the bracket of each shall be perpendicular to a street as determined by the village engineer. 
(d)  Design requirement and approval. The complete lighting system shall be designed by a registered professional engineer of the State of Illinois and shall be submitted to the village engineer for approval. In special cases, the village engineer may designate larger lamps, higher poles, two-masted poles, or vary the spacing as he deems necessary to meet special conditions. In no event shall streetlights in residential districts be spaced less than 150 feet apart. 
(e)  Materials and workmanship. All materials comprising the lighting systems shall be the product of a firm or firms regularly engaged in the manufacture of such materials and shall be covered by the manufacturer's or installing contractor's warranty or guarantee. The materials shall be new, of current manufacture and of standard design free from all defects. Workmanship shall be of the highest grade in accordance with standard practice. All work shall be done in accordance with those standards requiring the highest grade. 
(f)  Material and equipment specification. 
(1)  Conduit. All driveways, street and sidewalk crossings shall have a two-inch galvanized rigid steel conduit or PVC conduit used as a raceway for underground cable with two-inch insulating fiber bushings. 
(2)  Wire/cable. All wire installed under this section shall be "USE" copper with six hundred-volt insulation. Cable shall be of a type approved by the Village Engineer for direct burial such as types "USE." Uniduct cable shall be required for commercial and manufacturing areas. One conductor shall be white to determine neutral. Wire installed in trench shall be six hundred-volt No. 6 copper "USE". All wire will be subject to an insulation test to ground after installation. Any section of wiring failing to pass the minimum insulation test or showing an obvious short circuit shall be replaced. All wire is to be buried at least 24 inches below finished grade. 
(3)  Fuses. Each pole shall be fused with a 10-amp fusetron and "USE" bussman, HEB-type fuse holder with rubber boots. All hot conductors must be fused. 
(4)  Lamps. All lamps shall be rated 120/240 volts. All lamps shall be high pressure sodium. All lamps shall be a minimum of 150 watts, except at intersections with state or county highways or at intersections in business parks or industrial parks where they shall be 250 watts. 
(5)  Luminaries. The luminaries for lighting improvements to be accepted by the village for maintenance shall be a standard line of luminaries equipped with photoelectrical control units and one piece reflector housing of anodized aluminum. The luminary shall be equipped also with a hinged refractor holder that shall be securely held in place by a suitable latch. The luminary head shall embody a two-inch slip filter and shall be equipped with adjustable latch lugs to permit the proper orientation of the light pattern on the street; and EEL-NEMA standard, three terminal polarized lock-in type, photoelectric-control receptacle. In addition, sodium units shall be equipped with built-in ballasts. The luminaries shall provide lighting distribution equivalent to IES type II except at intersections where IES type V or IES type II with four-way distribution shall be provided. The luminaries for lighting improvements to be installed in planned unit or other developments shall be approved by the village engineer for construction. 
(6)  Ballasts. Ballasts shall be of high quality grain-oriented strip steel, high power factor, constant wattage and shall have a primary voltage rating of 120/240 volts. They shall be suitable for outdoor service and capable of starting the lamp at minus 20 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(7)  Controls. Individual photoelectric control units shall be provided with each luminaire. Said control units shall fit all EEL-NEMA standard receptacles and shall be rated 240 volts, 1,200 watts and constructed so as to prevent false turnoff by passing automobile headlights or lightning flashes. 
(8)  Mast arm brackets. Mast arm brackets for lighting improvements to be accepted by the village for maintenance shall have a minimum spread of approximately eight feet and shall be the upsweep type with wire inlet and necessary bracing. The brackets shall be manufactured from aluminum alloy and shall be capable of accommodating the slip filter arrangement of the luminaire. 
The mast arm clamps and fittings shall be heat-treated aluminum castings, and shall be free of all imperfections to insure an even grip on the standard and to provide easy mounting of the mast arms. 
Where drawn seamless tubing is used for the mast arm, it shall conform to ASTM specifications 10-58T and GS10A-T6. 
Aluminum for the mast arm clamps and fittings shall conform to ASTM specifications S5A-F and B26-50T. 
Mast arm brackets for lighting improvements to be installed in planned unit and other private developments shall be of the type and length approved by the village engineer. 
(9)  Light standards. 
a.  Concrete light standards. Light standards to be accepted by the village for maintenance may be manufactured of concrete, centrifugally cast, prestressed, and steel reinforced and of breakaway design. The standards shall have smooth ground and polished surfaces. The cross section of the standard shall contain a raceway extending throughout the length of the standard. The raceway shall have a minimum opening of one and one-half inches and shall not exceed two inches at the top of the standard. A hand hold shall be provided, and shall be covered with a heat-treated cast aluminum door, fastened to nonferrous inserts in the standard with stainless steel bolts. 
All standards shall be provided with an aluminum mast cap held to the top of the standard by stainless steel screws and nonferrous inserts. 
Aluminum for the hand-hole doors and mast caps shall conform to A.S.T.M. specifications S5A-f or SG70A-T6 and B26-50T. 
Roadway lighting standards shall be not less than eight inches in diameter with a butt base below final grade level. It shall be equipped with mast arm brackets securely attached to the standard. 
(10)  Splices. All underground cable shall be continuous. Necessary splices shall be made above ground and shall have location recorded on plans. Splices shall be made by using 3M Scotch Cast Kits or approved equal. Connection to Commonwealth Edison feeder lines must include a fuse box for shutoff to Commonwealth Edison power supply. Said fuse box shall be of the type approved by the village engineer. 
(11)  Size of trench and backfilling procedures. This work shall consist of constructing a trench for the accommodation of cables or conduit and backfilling it at the location shown on the plans, or as directed by the village engineer. The trench shall be excavated at least 24 inches below finished grade. 
Backfilling material shall be deposited in the trench in layers, not to exceed six inches in depth and shall be thoroughly compacted by suitable tamping before the next layer is deposited in the trench. The trench shall be located two feet back of the curb or as directed by the village engineer. 
(12)  Tests. After the installation is complete and at a time convenient to the village, all equipment shall be demonstrated to operate in accordance with the drawings and specifications. 
(13)  Warranty. The contractor and his surety shall guarantee and warrant that the equipment, material and workmanship, regardless of the manufacturer, will, for a period of two years from the date of final acceptance by the village or private owner, satisfactorily serve the purpose for which they were installed. Any defective material or workmanship shall be repaired or replaced by said contractor to the satisfaction of the village without cost to the village. 
(14)  Existing utilities. The location of existing underground utilities, such as, water mains, sewers, gas lines, etc., can be determined from plans available at the project. However, the village does not assume responsibility in the event that the actual location may be different from the location as shown on the available plans. 
(15)  As-built drawings. Upon completion of the installation and testing by the village, the contractor must present a marked set of as-built, reproducible drawings to the village. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-72; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(8.02), 5-21-1981; Ord. No. O-87-08, § 2, 2-19-1987; Ord. No. O-93-13, § 11, 4-1-1993; Ord. No. O-04-08, §§ 1-3, 2-19-2004) 
Secs. 38-144-38-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Water and sewers, ch. 106. 

Sec. 38-171. - General. 
    No residential, commercial or industrial subdivision or development within the corporate limits of the village shall be approved unless it is served by the village's water supply system. 
    All water supply systems which are installed in the public ways or in easements serving a central system shall be dedicated to the Village of Hanover Park. In all cases where a central water supply system is installed pursuant to the provisions of this article, said water supply system shall be dedicated to the Village of Hanover Park. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-81; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(9.01), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-172. - Design. 
    Water distribution mains shall be of adequate size and shall serve the entire development. Said mains shall be designed according to the Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois or according to the Recommended Standards for Water Works. The more stringent requirements of either shall apply. Said mains shall, in general, be installed in the street right-of-way. In no case shall mains be installed within seven feet of a building in a residential district and within ten feet of a building in any other zoning district. The minimum size shall be six inches internal diameter in residential areas. In other developments, the minimum size shall be eight inches. All water mains shall be installed with a minimum depth of cover of 5.5 feet, measured from the established grade shown on the plans to the top of the pipe. Mains shall be extended to the far property line of the development along public rights-of-way and at any other location indicated by the village engineer. 
(a)  Fire protection system. The design engineer shall show in a separate report that at several locations and at any other location that may be selected by the village engineer, the proposed water main system, together with that proposed in the master plan for the Village of Hanover Park will supply the fire flow required in excess of domestic consumption demands, using a "C" factor of 100 for cast iron or ductile iron and 120 for asbestos cement or thick walled PVC water mains ignoring fittings and with a minimum residual pressure of 20 psi. 
(1)  Residence: 
a.  Dwellings, detached and semidetached: 1,000 to 1,500 gpm. 
b.  Dwellings, attached (townhouses) each unit separated by an approved firewall: 1,000 to 2,000 gpm. 
c.  Dwellings attached other than above and dwellings, multiple-family: 3,000 to 4,000 gpm. 
(2)  Business: 
a.  Business and office uses: 2,500 to 3,000 gpm. 
b.  Commercial and mercantile buildings, including warehouses: 3,000 to 6,000 gpm. 
(3)  Manufacturing: 3,000 to 6,000 gpm. 
(4)  Institutional: 3,000 gpm. 
(b)  Gridiron or looping of mains. Each six-inch water main shall be looped (except culs-de-sac or stubbed streets unless deemed necessary by the village engineer) so that runs between connections to six-inch or larger size mains shall not be greater than one block not to exceed 1,800 feet. Each eight-inch water main shall be looped so that runs between connections to eight-inch or larger mains shall not be greater than 1,400 feet in a commercial area or 1,800 feet in a residential area. Each ten-inch water main shall be looped so that runs between connection to ten-inch or larger size mains shall not be greater than 2,200 feet. Each 12-inch and larger water main shall be looped so that runs between connections to 12-inch or larger mains shall not be greater than 3,000 feet. If the design engineer's report shows spacing greater than the above for the required residual pressure, then that spacing shall supersede the above requirements. 
(c)  Fire hydrants. Whenever a water main is to be installed for the purpose of providing fire hydrants, the local fire protection district having jurisdiction and the village engineer must approve the hydrant spacing plan prior to commencement of work. Fire hydrants shall not be located closer than 30 feet to any building. Fire hydrants shall be located at all corners and intersections of public and private streets and the minimum spacing allowed shall be such that 300-foot radius circles centered on each hydrant cover all construction on the site that will burn. If the location or configuration of the building requires it, private fire hydrants shall be installed. Private elevated or ground storage reservoirs may also be installed as required. Dead-end six-inch main extensions serving hydrants in culs-de-sac shall not be more than 400 feet long. Where water transmission lines or off-site water lines are installed in existing right-of-way (or in easements to existing right-of-way) hydrants must be installed at 300-foot intervals. In other locations, 600-foot intervals are required with tees for future hydrants being provided within 300 feet of the fire hydrants. Fire hydrants must be located such that access routes from all points of any building to adjacent fire hydrants does not exceed 300 feet. 
(d)  Valves. Valves shall be located on water mains so as to effectively isolate the sections from the system with minimum disruption. Valves shall be installed so that not over 800 feet of main will be shut off at any given time unless the village engineer permits spacing at greater intervals. If a tee is installed, two valves may be utilized. The design engineer shall, by diagrams and/or written report, set forth his basis for location of water main valves. No more than 30 single-family dwelling units shall be without water with the shutting off of any three valve locations. Valve vaults are required on all valves 2.5 inches or larger. Forty-eight-inch vaults are required on valves ten inches or smaller. Sixty-inch vaults or larger are required on all other size valves. A maximum of three valves shall be used to isolate any given section of water main. 
(e)  Services. The plans except for residential developments with individual service for each unit, shall show the calculated static water pressure at the lowest and highest ground elevations on the site. Calculations shall be presented showing that the proposed water services are of a large enough size to supply an adequate flow of water at the outlet of the meter, assuming the service is "fairly rough pipe" as specified in the Illinois State Plumbing Code, current edition. 
(f)  Thrust blocks. Thrust blocks are required at all valves, hydrants, tees and bends. Engineering drawings shall indicate the location of each concrete thrust block to be installed. Where undisturbed earth is not available or not likely to be available to back up pressure-type concrete thrust blocks, the engineer shall specify tie rods with or without anchor-type concrete thrust blocks and submit design data for such specifications. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-82; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(9.02), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-173. - Allowable materials. 
    All water main pipe, be it new installation, replacement and/or repair, shall be ductile cast iron cement-lined bituminous coated pipe, class 52. All fittings shall be cast iron. The village engineer may allow other materials, as listed in this section, only if soil conditions warrant alternate pipe materials. 
    Water main pipe and fittings must conform to the applicable paragraphs of section 40 of the Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois (SSWS), current edition. 
(a)  Water main. 
(1)  Ductile iron: 
a.  Ductile iron pipe shall conform to AWWA specification C151-65. Normal working pressure shall not exceed 150 psi. Pipe shall be furnished in nominal 18-foot laying lengths. 
b.  Ductile iron pipe shall be bituminous coated cement mortar lined as specified in section 51-8.2 of AWWA specification C151-65. The ductile iron pipe shall be coated on the outside as specified in section 15.8.1 with the exceptions that the thickness of the coating shall be an average of two to four mils and a minimum of two mils. 
Each pipe shall have the weight and class designation conspicuously painted on it. In addition, the manufacturer's mark and year in which the pipe was made shall be distinctly stamped or cast on the face of the bell. 
c.  All fittings shall be connected to sections of water main pipe by means of mechanical joints or approved push-type joints. 
(2)  Thick walled PVC [Asbestos cement pipe]: 
a.  Asbestos cement pipe shall conform to the requirements of AWWA specification C400 or ASTM C296. Normal working pressure shall exceed 150 psi. Pipe shall be furnished in nominal 13-foot laying lengths, except that six-inch diameter pipe may be furnished in nominal ten-foot lengths. 
b.  All fittings shall be connected to sections of water main pipe by means of mechanical joints or approved push-type joints designed for use on asbestos cement water pipe. 
(3)  Thick walled PVC: 
a.  PVC pressure pipe (pipe class 150-SDR 18), available in sizes up to 12 inches, shall conform to the requirements of AWWA C900-75 and shall be manufactured to cast iron dimensions. Normal working pressure shall not exceed 150 psi. The pipe shall not exceed 20 feet in laying length. Random lengths shall not be less than ten feet long. 
b.  All fittings shall be connected to water main pipe by means of mechanical joints or approved push-type joints. 
(b)  Pipe joints. 
(1)  Ductile iron water main: 
a.  Slip joints. Sections of water main pipe shall be connected by means of slip joints, consisting of bells cast integrally with pipe which have interior angular recesses conforming with the shape and dimensions of a rubber sealing gasket, the interior dimension of which is such that it will admit the insertion of the spigot end of the joining pipe in such manner as to compress the gasket tightly between the bell of the pipe and the inserted spigot, thus securing the gasket and sealing the joint. Such a slip joint shall be any one of the following make or type or its equivalent: 
1.  Super belltite-As supplied by James B. Clow and Son. 
2.  Fastite-As supplied by the American Cast Iron Pipe Company. 
3.  Tyton-As supplied by the U.S. Pipe and Foundry Company. 
The lubricant used in conjunction with the slip joints shall be that recommended by the supplier specified, or commercially processed animal fat or vegetable shortening. 
b.  Mechanical joint pipe shall meet the requirements of ASA specification A-U 11. Bolting materials shall meet the requirements of the manufacturer. 
(2)  Thick walled PVC joints. PVC pressure pipe joints (pipe class 150-SDR 18), available in sizes up to 12 inches shall conform to the requirements of AWWA specification C900-75 with an integral wall thickened bell and an elastomeric gasket such that the minimum wall thickness of the bell at any point shall conform to SDR 18. 
(c)  Concrete thrust blocks. All thrust blocks shall be precast or poured with class X concrete in accordance with the provisions of Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction (STSRB), section 5.04, except that the contractor shall bear the cost of the mix design. When poured, care shall be taken so that the cement does not interfere with access to joints or with hydrant drainage. 
(d)  Pipe sleeves for augering or tunneling. Pipe sleeves for augering or tunneling shall be fabricated of 0.312-inch-thick rolled sheet steel, of the diameter specified, with a continuous circular one-half-inch bead weld and shall meet the requirements of ASTM A-120. 
(e)  Castings. Castings for water valve vaults shall be Neenah R-1031 or approved equal with type B lid stamped "Village of Hanover Park-Water." 
(f)  Curb stop. Curb stops shall be the O-ring sealing type, Mueller Oriseal Mark II model H-15154 with copper service thread connections at both ends. The stop shall be quarter turn with a solid tee head which is an integral part of the plug. The stop shall be of nominal size equal to the size of the service line and be Minneapolis pattern type (11/2-inch threads for three-fourths-inch stop) with check and without drain. 
(g)  Curb box. Curb boxes shall be Minneapolis pattern base, telescoping extension type, equipped with stationary rod, Mueller model H-10300 for three-fourths-inch stops, model H-10302 for one-inch stops and model H-10304 for 11/2-inch or two-inch stops. 
(h)  House service. All house service water lines shall be a minimum of three-fourths-inch copper, type K complete with corporation cock, stop cock and cast iron buffalo box. Service lines shall conform to ASTM B-88-58 or equal and the Village of Hanover Park plumbing ordinance. 
(i)  Corporation stops. Corporation stops shall be Mueller H-15000, with nominal size being equivalent to the copper service line. 
(j)  System valves: 
(1)  Four-inch to 12-inch gate valves shall be resilient wedge type conforming to AWWA C-509-80, manufactured by Mueller. Valves larger than 12 inches in size shall be resilient seated butterfly valves conforming to C-504 and shall be equipped with manual operators designed for submersible service. 
(2)  Four-inch to ten-inch system valves shall be installed in a 48-inch precast concrete valve vault, and system valves greater than ten inches in size shall be installed in a 60-inch precast concrete valve vault. 
All valve vaults shall be in accordance with the requirements set forth elsewhere in chapter 38 of the Hanover Park Municipal Code entitled "Water, Sanitary, and Storm Appurtenances." Steps are not required for water vaults. 
(3)  Fire hydrant auxiliary valves shall be furnished with a two-piece, 51/4-inch buffalo style cast iron screw type adjustable valve box, Mueller H-10360 with the word "WATER" cast on the lid. 
(4)  All valves shall have mechanical joint or push type ends, inside screw, and shall be equipped with a two-inch operated nut. All valves shall open by turning counterclockwise. 
(k)  Fire hydrants. The fire hydrant shall have a valve opening of 51/4 inches and shall be equipped with two 21/2-inch hose connections and one 41/2-inch male pumper connection. The outside diameter of the male thread on the 21/2-inch hose connection shall be "National Standard" threads. Hose caps shall be fastened to barrel with steel chain of at least one-eighth-inch thickness. 
Each hydrant shall be provided with a drain that will leave no water standing in the barrel of the hydrant when the hydrant is closed. This drain shall close tightly before the hydrant begins to open. 
All fire hydrants shall be equipped with a six-inch Mueller resilient wedge gate valve flanged directly to the hydrant. 
Fire hydrants shall be the break flange type, open against pressure, and shall be one of the following: 
(1)  Mueller Centurion as manufactured by Mueller Company, Decatur, Illinois. 
(2)  Clow Medallion as manufactured by Clow Valve Co., Oskaloosa, Iowa. 
The bowl of each hydrant shall be well braced against unexcavated earth at the end of the trench with stone slabs or concrete backing, or it shall be tied to the pipe with suitable rods or clamps. 
All hydrants shall be thoroughly cleaned of dirt and foreign matter before setting. 
Fire hydrants shall be installed not further than seven feet nor less than three feet from the edge of a lane of traffic that is to be kept open to all weather and is adequate in width, clearance and strength for firefighting equipment. Parking lots shall be designed to provide not less than 15 feet of clearance on each side of the hydrant on which a steamer or hose connection is located. 
The height of the nut on a 41/2-inch steamer connection shall be no less than 24 inches or more than 36 inches above the finished grade at the hydrant. 
All fire hydrants shall conform to AWWA C-502. 
(l)  Air release valves. Air release valves shall be placed on the water main at high points as deemed necessary by the village engineer to serve as air vents preventing air locking of the water main. 
These air release valves shall be of the APCO 200 A type or an approved equal. All air release valves [sic]. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-83; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(9.03), 5-21-1981; Ord. No. O-84-3, §§ 4-8, 1-5-1984; Ord. No. O-87-08, § 1, 2-19-1987; Ord. No. O-93-13, §§ 11, 14-16, 4-1-1993) 
Sec. 38-174. - Construction requirements. 
(a)  Excavation. The trench shall be excavated so that the water main will be at a minimum depth of 5.5 feet. The trench for the pipe shall be excavated at least 12 inches wider than the external diameter of the pipe and not more than 18 inches wider than the diameter of the pipe at the top of the pipe. 
    Bell holes of sufficient depth shall be provided across the bottom of the trench to accommodate the bell of the pipe to provide sufficient room for joint making and to insure uniform bearing for the pipe. 
    Where a firm foundation is not found to exist for the bottom of the trench at the required depth, due to soft, spongy or other unsuitable soil, such unsuitable soil shall be removed for the full width of the trench or tunnel and replaced with well-compacted unwashed gravel or an equal substitute therefor, or crushed stone if such compacted material proved unsatisfactory. Where rock, in either ledge or bounder formation is encountered, it shall be removed below grade and replaced with a well-compacted cushion of unwashed gravel having a thickness under the pipe of not less than eight inches. 
(b)  Sheeting and bracing. Sheeting and bracing shall be placed in the ditch, as may be necessary, for the safety of the work and public, for the protection of the workmen, adjacent properties, or structures and for the proper installation of the work. 
    Sheeting and/or bracing shall be progressively removed as the backfill is placed in such a manner as to prevent the caving in of the sides of the trench or excavation and to prevent damage to the work. 
    Sheeting which is placed for the protection of the public, adjacent properties or structures, shall not be removed until the backfill has been placed and thoroughly compacted. While sheeting is being withdrawn, all vacancies shall be carefully filled with sand free from silt, rammed into place, puddled or otherwise firmly compacted. 
(c)  Laying water main. The contractor shall keep the trench free from water while the water main is being placed and until the pipe joint has been sealed to the satisfaction of the village engineer or his representative. 
    Adequate provision shall be made for safety, storing and protecting all water pipe prior to actual installation in the trench. Care shall be taken to prevent damage to the pipe castings, both inside and out. Provisions shall be made to keep the inside of the pipe clean throughout its storage period and to keep mud and/or other debris from being deposited therein. All pipe shall be thoroughly cleaned on the inside before laying of the pipe. Proper equipment shall be used for the safe handling, conveying and laying of the pipe. All pipe shall be carefully lowered into the trench, piece by piece, by means of a derrick, ropes, or other suitable tools or equipment, in such manner as to prevent damage to water main materials and protective coatings and linings. Under no circumstances, shall water main materials be dropped or dumped into the trench. 
    In making joints, all portions of the jointing materials and the socket and spigot ends of the joining pipe shall be wiped clean of all foreign materials. The actual assembly of the jointing shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions and/or directed in writing by the village engineer. During construction, until jointing operations are complete, the open ends of all pipes shall be at all times protected and sealed with temporary watertight plugs. 
(d)  Pipe cutting. The cutting of pipe for inserting valves, fittings or closure pieces shall be done in a neat and workmanlike manner without damage to cement lining and so as to leave a smooth end at right angles to the axis of the pipe. When machine cutting is not available for cutting pipe 20 inches in diameter or larger, the electric arc cutting method will be permitted, using a carbon or steel rod. Only qualified and experienced workmen shall be used on this work. 
    The flame cutting of pipe by means of an oxyacetylene torch shall not be allowed. 
(e)  Water service connections. 
(1)  House services. Water service connections shall be located as directed by the village or its representative and shall be laid at a depth of not less than 5.5 feet and conform to requirements of the Village of Hanover Park plumbing code ordinance in chapter 74, article III, division 2 of the Hanover Park Code of Ordinances. 
Each service connection shall be connected to the water main by a brass corporation cock, said pipe to extend horizontally at right angles with the water main to the front line of lot or parcel which it is to serve unless otherwise shown on the plans or specified herein; said service pipe shall be provided with a brass stop cock at location in the lines as directed by the village over which a cast iron service box or valve vault shall be set. Flared-type joints shall be used between service pipe and fittings. 
(2)  Commercial services. Water service connections shall be installed according to the requirements of the Village of Hanover Park plumbing code ordinance in chapter 74, article III, division 2 of this Code. 
(f)  Backfilling. The contractor shall not backfill above the top of the pipe, until grade, alignment and the pipe joints have been made available for checking by the village engineer or his representative. 
    Unless otherwise directed, all trenches and excavations shall be backfilled as soon as possible and the work shall be prosecuted expeditiously after it has been commenced. As soon as it is laid, all pipe shall have the space between the pipe and the bottom and sides of the trench packed full of sand, grade 9 gravel, or clean, dry materials by hand and thoroughly tamped with a shovel, hoe or light tamper, as fast as placed up to the level of the middle of the pipe. The filling shall be carried up evenly on both sides. Care shall be taken that no rock, frozen material, or other hard substances are placed in contact with the pipe. The pipe shall then be covered at least 18 inches with clean, dry material. 
    The remainder of the trench shall be backfilled by using the material originally excavated from the ditch (except for conditions hereinafter defined) to a height slightly above the original elevation of the ground. 
    Pipe constructed in open cut across any existing or proposed pavement, existing driveways and sidewalks, shall be backfilled to subgrade with grade 9 gravel thoroughly flushed and jetted or tamped in nine-inch lifts into place. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-84; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(9.04), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-175. - Water main pressure testing. 
(a)  Pressure test. Each section of water main and appurtenances shall be tested by the contractor and village jointly. Any defects or leaks shall be corrected by the contractor. 
    It is the responsibility of the contractor to re-excavate the pipe at his expense if the system fails to meet the requirements of the test. 
    A hydrostatic pressure of 150 pounds per square inch shall be applied for the testing of the water main, valves, fittings and fire hydrants. The duration of the test shall be for a period of not less than two hours. The section of water main shall pass if the pressure loss in the pipe is not greater than 7.5 pounds per square inch during the test. 
(b)  Procedure for test. Each section of pipe to be tested, as determined by the village engineer, shall be slowly filled with water and the specified test pressure shall be applied by means of a pump connected to the pipe in a satisfactory manner. The pump pipe connection and all necessary apparatus including gauges and meters shall be furnished by the contractor. Before applying the specified test pressure, all air shall be expelled from the pipe. To accomplish this, taps shall be made as necessary, at points of highest elevation and afterwards tightly plugged. Any cracked or defective pipes, fittings, valves or hydrants discovered in consequence of this pressure test shall be removed and replaced by the contractor with sound material and the test shall be repeated until satisfactory to the village engineer. Provisions of AWWA C-600 and C-603, where applicable, shall apply. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-85; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(9.05), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-176. - Water main leakage test. 
(a)  After completion of the pressure test, the village engineer may require a leakage test to be conducted to determine the quantity of water lost by leakage under the specified test pressure. Test pressure is defined as the maximum operating pressure of the section under test and is based on the elevation of the lowest point in the line or section under test corrected to the elevation of the test gauge. Applicable provisions of AWWA C-600 and C-603 shall apply. Duration of each leakage test shall be a minimum of one hour in addition to the pressure test period. 
(b)  Allowable leakage in gallons per hour for cast iron water main shall not be greater than that determined by the formula: 
L = ND vP 
3,700  
for mechanical joints and push-on joints, or: 
L = ND vP 
1,850  
for caulked bell-and-spigot-joints. 
Note: 
L = Allowable leakage in gallons per hour. N = Number of joints in length of pipeline tested. D = Nominal diameter of the pipe in inches. P = Average test pressure during leakage test in pounds per square inch gauge.  
    Tables of allowable leakage and basis of allowable leakage can be found in table 4 for cast iron water main. 
    Allowable leakage for asbestos-cement water pipe shall conform to provisions of AWWA C-603. Allowable leakage per 100 couplings based on 150 psi pressure represents a leakage of 30 gpd per mile of pipe per inch of diameter for pipe in 13-foot lengths. A table showing the allowable leakage is provided in table 4. 
(c)  Leakage is defined as the quantity of water to be supplied in the newly laid pipe or any valved section under test, which is necessary to maintain the specified leakage test pressure after the pipe has been filled with water and the air expelled. 
(d)  Flanged pipe shall be "bottle tight." 
(e)  In no case shall the leakage exceed the greater of either 3,000 gallons per day per mile of water main or three percent of total supplied water.

(Code 1975, § 91/2-86; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(9.06), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-177. - Preliminary flushing. 
    Prior to chlorination, the main shall be flushed as thoroughly as possible with the water pressure and outlets available. Flushing shall be done after the pressure test is made. It must be understood that such flushing removes only the lighter solids and cannot be relied upon to remove heavy material allowed to get into the main during laying. If no hydrant is installed at the end of the main, a tap should be provided large enough to affect a velocity in the main of at least 2.5 feet per second. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-87; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(9.07), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-178. - Sterilization. 
    The preferred point of application of the chlorinating agent shall be at the beginning of the pipeline extension or any valved section of it and through a corporation stop in the top of the newly laid pipe. The water injector for delivering the chlorine-bearing water into the pipe should be supplied from a tap on the pressure side of the gate valve controlling the flow into the pipeline extension. In a new system application of chlorine may be made at the pumping station, the elevated tank, the standpipe or the reservoir. When properly cleaned first, these units are thus chlorinated adequately. 
    Water from the existing distribution system or other source of supply shall be controlled so as to flow slowly into the newly laid pipeline during the application of chlorine. The rate of chlorine mixture flow shall be in such proportion to the rate of water entering the pipe that the chlorine does applied to the water entering the newly laid pipe shall be at least 40 to 50 ppm, or enough to meet the requirements during the retention period. A convenient method of determining the rate of flow of line full of water and measure the rate of discharge at a hydrant with a Pitot tube. Great flexibility is made possible by providing a series of orifices to give good gauge readings at high and low flows. 
    Valves shall be manipulated so that the strong chlorine solution in the line being treated will not flow back into the line supplying the water. 
    Treated water shall be retained in the pipe long enough to destroy all spore-forming bacteria. This retention period should be at least 24 hours. After the chlorine-treated water has been retained for the required time, the chlorine residual at the pipe extremities and at other representative points should be at least ten ppm. 
    In the process of chlorinating newly laid pipe, all valves or other appurtenances shall be operated while the pipeline is filled with the chlorinating agent. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-88; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(9.08), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-179. - Final flushing and testing. 
    Following chlorination, all treated water shall be thoroughly flushed from the newly laid pipeline at its extremities until the replacement water, throughout its length shall, upon test, be approved as safe water by the department of public works. This quality of water delivered by the new main should continue for a period of at least two full days as demonstrated by laboratory examination of samples taken from a tap located and installed in such a way as to prevent outside contamination. Samples should never be taken from an unsterilized hose or from a fire hydrant, because such samples seldom meet current bacteriological standards. 
(a)  Repetition of procedures. Should the initial treatment fail to result in the conditions specified, the chlorination procedure shall be repeated until such results are obtained. 
(b)  Sampling tap. Three-quarter-inch bronze corporation cocks shall be installed in all water mains at intervals not exceeding 1,000 feet. 
The contractor must notify the engineering department at least 24 hours in advance to arrange for appropriate pressure testing and water samplings. The contractor is to provide the engineering department with sampling bottles at the time of sampling. All samples will be sent to a State of Illinois approved testing lab for analysis. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-89; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(9.09), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-180. - Environmental protection agency. 
    Water main design and construction shall in all respects be in accord with the regulations of the Bureau of Public Water Supply, Environmental Protection Agency, State of Illinois. No construction shall commence until a copy of a permit from this agency is filed with the village or that the village received verification from this agency that a permit has been issued. 
    All water mains must be constructed according to the rules and regulations of the Illinois Department of Public Health regarding the protection of water mains, water service lines and appurtenances from contamination. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-90; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(9.10), 5-21-1981) 
Secs. 38-181-38-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 54; water and sewers, ch. 106. 

Sec. 38-201. - General. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, no residential, commercial or industrial subdivision or development within the corporate limits of the village shall be approved unless it is served by sanitary sewers connected to the village's sewer system. 
    All sanitary sewers which are installed in the public ways or in easements serving a central system, shall be dedicated to the Village of Hanover Park. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-101; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(10.01), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-202. - Design. 
(a)  Sewer mains shall be designed according to the Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois or according to Recommended Standards for Sewage Works. The more stringent requirements of either shall apply. Sewer mains shall be of adequate size to serve the entire development proposed, and except as otherwise approved by the village engineer, shall be installed in the street right-of-way, or in an easement adjacent thereto. In no case shall mains be installed within ten feet of a building. The minimum size of mains shall be eight-inch internal diameter. Manholes shall be installed not more than 400 feet apart for sewers 15 inches in diameter or less, and 500 feet for sewers 18 inches to 30 inches in diameter. 
    Before commencing the sewer layout, the developer shall confer with the village to determine the required size and grades for any trunk sewers traversing the subdivision to fit the village's available or proposed capacities required for existing or proposed developments both upstream and downstream. Construction required to accommodate the subdivision or development shall be submitted as part of the engineering plans. Sanitary sewers shall be extended to the edge of the development along public rights-of-way and at other points indicated by the village engineer. 
(b)  All sanitary sewers shall be constructed in accord with the provisions of division II and division III of the Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, 1967, as modified and/or more specifically defined in these paragraphs and sections. In case of conflict, the provisions of the following paragraphs shall apply. 
(c)  For pipe depths less than three feet, pipe shall be case iron, ductile iron or thick walled PVC, or vitrified clay of ACP in a concrete cradle or encased in concrete. 
(d)  Type 2 bedding, consisting of at least four inches of clean uniformly graded granular aggregate CA11 or CA13, shall be furnished and placed across the trench bottom under all sewer pipe, except ductile iron and shall completely cover the pipe to a point six inches over the top of the sewer pipe. Material shall be placed and formed as described in ASTM specification C12-64. 
(e)  Sanitary sewer service laterals of a minimum of four inches internal diameter shall be provided for each lot, parcel or tract prior to the construction of street pavements. Services shall extend to the property line. Service connection shall consist of one-eighth sewer pipe bend set in the bell of the eye or tee and the necessary lengths of pipe. 
(f)  If a lift station is part of the engineering design, it shall be shown in plan elevation. Specifications for said lift station shall be submitted with engineering plans. Lift station shall be of the dry well or wet well type, and shall conform in all respects to the standards established by the State of Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and MSD. However, every reasonable effort shall be made to avoid lift station in engineering design. 
    A separate source of power shall be furnished to each sewerage lift station. This shall be from another electrical source provided by a separately powered engine. Engine, enclosure and mounting shall be subject to approval by the village engineer. An alarm shall be installed to the village master panel in the event of failure at the lift station. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-102; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(10.02), 5-21-1981; Ord. No. O-93-13, § 17, 4-1-1993) 
Sec. 38-203. - Allowable materials. 
(a)  Sewer pipe. 
(1)  Extra strength vitrified clay pipe (ESVCP) conforming to the requirements of ASTM C-700. 
(2)  Extra strength concrete sewer pipe (ESCSP) conforming to the requirements of ASTM C-14 or C-76. 
(3)  Cast iron main conforming to the requirements of ASA A21.11 and A21.6, class 150. 
(4)  Ductile iron main shall conform to AWWA specification C151-65. 
(5)  Thick walled PVC pipe shall conform to the requirements of ASTM D-224.1 or D-3034, SDR 35 (SDR, or standard dimension ratio, is the ratio of the pipe OD to the minimum wall thickness (SDR = D/t). The structural stability and supporting strength of the pipe decrease with the increase of SDR). The pipe shall not exceed 20 feet in laying length. Installation and selection of bedding material shall conform to the requirements of ASTM specification D-2321. 
(6)  Truss pipe shall conform to the requirements of ASTM D2680-68T. 
(b)  Pipe joints. 
(1)  Rubber gasket joints. On tongue-and-groove type of pipe joints, rubber gaskets may be used. The gasket shall consist of a special rubber ring of a size to fit snugly over the tongue of each size pipe. The gasket shall be circular, elliptical or of the manufacturer's special design cross section fabricated out of a special composition or rubber specifically designed to resist the hardening action of the sulphur compounds in sewage and to prevent disintegration from sewage or water over long periods. 
A ring shall be fitted over the tongue of each pipe to be laid at its outer end. The tongue shall be inserted into the groove of the pipe previously laid and the pipe pulled home. 
Joints shall be made up in strict conformance with the manufacturer's recommendations and directions. Rubber gasket material shall conform to ASTM designation C425, type I or III (O-ring gasket). 
(2)  Sections of cast iron pipe shall be connected by means of slip joints consisting of bells cast integrally with the pipe, which have interior angular recesses conforming with the shape and dimension of a rubber scaling gasket, interior dimension of which is such that it will admit the insertion of the spigot end of the joining pipe in such manner as to compress the gasket tightly between the bell of the pipe and the inserted spigot, thus securing the gasket and sealing the joint. Such slip joints shall be any one of the following make or type or equal: 
a.  Super bellites supplied by James B. Clow and Son. 
b.  Fastite-As supplied by the American Cast Iron Pipe Company. 
c.  Tyton-As supplied by the U.S. Pipe and Foundry Company. 
The lubricant used in conjunction with the slip joints shall be that recommended by the suppliers, or commercially processed animal fat or vegetable shortening as approved by the engineer. 
(3)  Thick walled PVC joint. The pipe joint shall conform to the requirements of ASTM D-1869. The joint shall consist of a bell that is an integral part of the pipe, stiffened to securely lock a solid cross sectional rubber ring into position. A "home" mark shall be provided on the spigot end of the pipe. The joint shall be able to withstand an internal hydrostatic pressure of 25 psi for one hour and leakage during that time shall be considered a failure of test and joint. 
(4)  Truss pipe joint. The pipe joint shall conform to the requirements of ASTM D-2680. 
(c)  Pipe sleeves for augering or tunneling. 
(1)  Steel sleeves shall be three-eighths-inch thick of the diameter specified, with a continuous, circular one-half-inch bead weld and shall meet the requirements of ASTM A-120. 
(2)  Concrete sleeves (alternate), if selected in place of the steel sleeves specified above, shall be reinforced concrete pipe, tongue and groove type, conforming to the requirements of ASTM C-76-57, table IV, class designation 3,000D. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-103; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(10.03), 5-21-1981; Ord. No. O-93-13, §§ 18, 19, 4-1-1993) 
Sec. 38-204. - Construction requirements. 
(a)  Excavation and foundation. The trench shall be excavated so that the flow line of the finished sewer shall be at the depth and grade established by the village engineer. The trench for the pipe shall be excavated at least 12 inches wider than the external diameter of the pipe. The width of the trench shall not exceed the external diameter of the pipe by more than 18 inches at the top of the pipe. 
    The pipe foundation shall be bedding material consisting of road gravel or one-quarter-inch to three-quarter-inch crushed stone of the depth shown on the plans. Where pipes with bells or hubs are used, cross trenches shall be excavated to prevent nonuniform loading at the joints. The cross trenches shall not be more than two inches wider than the width of the bell or hub. 
    If the excavation has been made deeper than necessary, the foundation shall be brought to proper grade by the addition of well-compacted bedding material. Where a firm foundation is not encountered at the grade established, due to soft, spongy or other unsuitable soil (unless other special construction methods are called for on the plans or in the special provisions), all such unsuitable soil under the pipe and for the width of the trench shall be removed and replaced with well-compacted bedding material. 
    Where it is necessary to tunnel, the width shall be the same as for trenches. Where sheeting and shoring is necessary, this width shall be between the faces of said sheeting or shoring. The ends of a tunnel shall be at a distance equal to not less than the depth of the trench from the edge of pavements where tunneling is done under pavements. Ends of tunnels under trees, driveways, walks and other obstacles shall be of sufficient distance from them to give ample protection to them. The sides and roof shall be braced sufficiently to support roadways and other obstacles and to prevent caving, bulging and settlement. It is preferred that open trenching be used in all cases under pavements, walks and driveways except where they exist of concrete. Where trenches are dug through pavement, walks and driveways, the contractor shall provide substantial bridges over same so that traffic can be maintained and access to occupied properties is assured. 
    Access must be left to all fire hydrants, valves and to private drives at all times. 
(b)  Sheeting and bracing. Sheeting and bracing shall be placed in the ditch, as may be necessary for the safety of the work and public, for the protection of the workmen, adjacent properties, pavement or structures and for the proper installation of the work. In any event, the minimum protection shall conform to the recommendations in OSHA Safety and Health Standards for Construction. A sand box or trench shield may be used in place of sheeting as permitted by OSHA. When close sheeting is used, it shall be driven so as to prevent adjacent soil from entering the trench either below or through such sheeting. 
    Sheeting and/or bracing shall be progressively removed as the backfill is placed in such a manner as to prevent the caving-in of the sides of the trench or excavation and to prevent damage to the work. 
    Sheeting which is placed for the protection of the public, adjacent properties, pavement or structures, shall not be removed until the backfill has been placed and thoroughly compacted. While being drawn, all vacancies left by this sheeting shall be carefully filled with sand free silt, rammed into place, puddled or otherwise firmly compacted. 
(c)  Dewatering. Dewatering sufficient to maintain the water level at or below the surface of trench bottom or base of the bedding course, shall be accomplished prior to pipe laying and jointing if not prior to excavation and placing of the bedding as called for in other sections of the specifications or special provisions. The dewatering operation, however, accomplished, shall be carried out so that it does not destroy or weaken the strength of the soil under or along side the trench. The normal water table shall be restored to its natural level in such a manner as to not disturb the pipe and its foundation. 
(d)  Pipe laying. The laying of pipes in finished trenches shall be started at the outlet end with the spigot ends pointing in the direction of flow and shall proceed toward the inlet end with pipes abutting and shall be true to line and grade. The ends of the pipes shall be carefully cleaned before the pipes are lowered into the trenches and the pipes shall be lowered in such a manner that unnecessary handling in the trench will be avoided. At each length of pipe is laid, the mouth of the pipe shall be properly protected to prevent the entrance of earth or the bedding material. The pipe shall be fitted and matched so that when laid in the work, they will form a sewer with a smooth, uniform invert. 
    All jointing material shall be used in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer. Each pipe shall be pushed or pulled as tightly as possible to the section in place to insure tight joints. 
    Sewer pipe shall not be dropped from trucks or cars. All pipe must be lowered into the trench with suitable apparatus for this purpose; in no case shall it be dropped or thrown. 
(e)  Connections. Connections of new sewers to existing sewers when encountered in construction shall be made where ordered by the village engineer. Such connections shall be made within a manhole, except for house and drain connections. When connections are made with sewers carrying sewage or water, special care must be taken that no part of the work is built under water; a flume or dam must be installed and pumping maintained if necessary, to keep the new work dry until completed and concrete or mortar has been set up. 
    Junctions for future sewer connections shall be bricked off at the ends, or otherwise sealed off in a manner approved by the village engineer. 
(f)  Wyes. Wyes, for existing or future lateral connection, shall be inserted in the sewer at the appropriate location as required by the village engineer. Wyes shall be constructed so as to be an integral part of the main sewer pipe. Where risers are to be provided, the wye bell shall be placed at the top of the pipe perpendicular to the main sewer flow line. When risers are not required, the wye bell shall be placed midway between the top of the pipe and the horizontal centerline of the pipe at an angle of approximately 45 degrees to 60 degrees, with the upstream face of the pipe. 
    Wyes not put in service at the time of construction (of the sewer) shall be plugged in such a manner as to be watertight and to facilitate future removal without injury to the wye. 
(g)  Backfilling. The contractor shall not backfill sewers above the top of the pipe until the sewer elevations, gradient, alignment and the pipe joints have been made available for checking by the village engineer or his representative. 
    All trenches and excavations shall be backfilled as soon as joints have acquired a suitable degree of hardness. Concrete joints shall be protected to prevent drying and cracking of the joints. 
    All sewer pipe, as soon as laid, shall have the space between the pipe and the bottom and sides of the trench above the pipe foundation packed full with sand or grade 9 gravel by hand and thoroughly tamped with a shovel, hoe or light tamper, as soon as placed, to six inches above the top pipe. The filling shall be carried up evenly on both sides. Care shall be taken that no rock, frozen material or other hard substances are placed in contact with the pipe. In areas where clean fine and dry sand is used for backfill tamping will not be required. 
    The trench shall be backfilled by using the material originally excavated from the ditch (except for conditions hereafter defined) to a height slightly above the original elevation of the ground. Backfilling shall not be left unfinished more than 300 feet behind the completed masonry or pipe work. 
    No heavy rock shall be dropped into the trench nor placed within three feet of the sewer pipe. In depositing rock into the trench, care must be taken that the rock does not injure the structure. 
    All voids existing between the outside of the pipe and the limits of a tunnel excavation or lining shall be filled with sand free of silt thoroughly rammed or flushed into place, or with concrete composed of one part Portland cement, three parts of fine aggregate and five parts of coarse aggregate thoroughly packed into place. 
    Sewers constructed in open cut across any existing or proposed pavements, driveways and sidewalks (where locations are known), and all trenches where the inner edge of the existing or proposed pavement, shall be backfilled with gravel (grade 9), thoroughly flushed and jetted or tamped in nine-inch lifts in place. 
(h)  Completion of work. When the work is completed, all surplus material, earth, rubbish, etc., shall be removed and that portion of the surface of each street disturbed by construction shall be left in as good condition as it was before the commencement of the work and it shall be promptly and regularly maintained in such condition during a period of two years after the final acceptance of the work. This work of maintenance shall apply to the items of materials and workmanship improperly installed in the first instance and maintenance measures made necessary by the ordinary wear and tear occasioned by traffic shall not be at the expense of the contractor. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-104; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(10.04), 5-21-1981) 
Sec. 38-205. - Inspection and tests. 
    It shall be the intention of this chapter to secure a sewer system with a minimum amount of infiltration. Maximum allowable infiltration shall be 100 gallons per inch of diameter of sewer per mile per 24-hour day at any time for any section of the system. The joints shall be tight and visible leakage in the joints, or leakage in excess of that specified above, shall be repaired at the contractor's expense by procedures acceptable to the village engineer. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-105; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(10.05), 5-21-1981; Ord. No. O-93-13, §§ 12, 20, 4-1-1993) 
Sec. 38-206. - Sewer services. 
(a)  General. All labor, materials, equipment, services and tools required for the furnishing and installation of sewer services required shall be furnished and installed in compliance with the diameter and length as required in the Village of Hanover Park plumbing ordinances in chapter 74, article III, division 2 of this Code. 
(b)  Material. Sewer services pipe shall consist of clay sewer pipe, thick walled PVC or cast iron pipe. 
(c)  Construction. Sewer services from main or lateral sewers toward the property line shall be constructed as follows: 
    Services shall be laid in as straight a line as possible at a uniform gradient, except a connection at main or lateral sewers. 
    The minimum gradient allowable for sewer services shall be one-quarter inch per foot of length. Where the elevation of the main or lateral sewer permits, within the minimum gradient allowance, the sewer service shall be laid on a gradient such that its terminus shall not be less than three feet below the established grade of the street. A one-eighth-bend pipe fitting shall be used for the first length adjacent to the main or lateral sewer when connections are made to "Y" branches installed in such main or lateral sewers. 
    Terminus of sewer service leads shall be shown on the contract drawings. The ends shall be sealed with a vitrified clay or concrete round disc or equal one inch in thickness and of a diameter equal to the diameter of the bell of the sewer service pipe to be sealed. The stoppers shall be set in the ball end of the sewer service pipe and sealed in place with material of the kind and quality used in pipe joints. Oakum shall be placed around the periphery of the stopper before sealing in place to facilitate removal of the stopper without breaking the bell of the pipe. 
(d)  Records. The contractor shall furnish and place a temporary stake opposite the terminus of each sewer service. During construction of the curb and gutter, the contractor shall mark the location of all sewer and water service lines with an "S" or "W" etched into the curb and gutter as a permanent record of service location. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-106; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(10.06), 5-21-1981; Ord. No. O-93-13, §§ 21, 22, 4-1-1993) 
Secs. 38-207-38-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - STORMWATER AND FLOODPLAIN REGULATIONS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Planning, ch. 70; plumbing and sanitary code, ch. 74; streets, sidewalks and public places, ch. 86; water and sewers, ch. 106. 

Sec. 38-231. - General; adoption by reference. 
(a)  Adoption by reference. The findings of Section 15-3 and purposes of Section 15-4 of Article I and all subsequent articles of DuPage County Ordinance OSM-001-12 adopted by the County Board on April 24, 2012, "DuPage County Countywide Stormwater and Floodplain Ordinance," is hereby adopted by reference as a part of this chapter to regulate stormwater management within the corporate limits of the village in both Cook and DuPage Counties, with such addition or amendments as hereinafter stated. 
(b)  Additions and penalties. 
Additions: 
(1)  The oversight committee shall be the village president and board of trustees. The administrator shall be the village engineer. 
(2)  Applicants for permits for special management areas on property in the Cook County portion of the village shall obtain floodplain review and approval from the administrator and wetland review and approval from the United States Army Corps of Engineers. 
(3)  Whenever there is a conflict between the regulations contained in the DuPage County Stormwater and Floodplain Ordinance herein adopted by reference and any other regulation of this Municipal Code, that regulation which is the most restrictive shall apply. 
Penalties: Any person violating any provision of paragraph (a) above as amended by this paragraph (b) shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00. Each day during which such violation is committed, continued, or permitted shall constitute a separate violation and shall be fined as such. 
(c)  No subdivision, planned unit development or other development within the corporate limits of the village shall be approved unless it is served by a minor drainage system and a major drainage system. 
(d)  The minor system shall be sized to handle the ten-year storm event and shall consist of the storm sewer system and its appurtenances. 
(e)  The major system shall consist of all the pathways that runoff takes when the capacity of the minor system is exceeded and is composed of streets, larger natural or manmade swales, detention and retention basins, creeks, streams and rivers. 
(f)  The major system shall be sized to handle the 100-year storm event utilizing the Illinois State Water Survey Bulletin 70 Rainfall DATA. The lowest habitable floor of all structures (or the immediately adjacent ground if a basement) shall be elevated at least one foot above the calculated water surface profile for the 100-year storm event. 
(g)  All storm sewers which are installed in the public right-of-way or in easements serving a central system shall be dedicated to the village. Every subdivision or development shall have storm sewers separate and independent of the sanitary sewer system and with an adequate outlet or connection with the existing storm system. The outfall of said storm sewer systems shall be designed to prevent the transportation of eroded solid and floating matter to downstream points of discharge whether they be creeks, lakes or municipal or privately owned storm sewer system. 
(Code 1975, § 91/2-121; Ord. No. O-81-31, § 1(11.01), 5-21-1981; Ord. No. O-91-69, § 1, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. O-94-51, § 1, 9-1-1994; Ord. No. O-97-74, § 1, 12-18-1997; Ord. No. O-08-38, § 1, 5-1-2008; Ord. No. O-08-47, § 1, 8-7-2008; Ord. No. O-09-23, § 1, 8-6-2009; Ord. No. O-12-18, § 1, 7-19-2012) 
Sec. 38-232. - Design. 
(a)  All storm sewers must be designed by the rational method on the basis of a ten-year storm frequency utilizing Illinois State Water Survey 70 Rainfall DATA and shall be sized to adequately carry all tributary areas. 
(b)  Copies of the design computations for the following facilities together with a drawing defining each drainage area shall be submitted with the engineering plans under these headings: 
(1)  Facilities carrying drainage from watershed upstream of the development if developed in accord with present zoning, yielding runoff in cubic feet per second taking into account applicable stormwater requirements. 
(2)  On-site ditches and storm sewers. 
(3)  Street drainage, inlets and catchbasins. 
(4)  Parking lot drainage. 
(5)  Sediment control basins. 
(6)  Detention basins. 
(7)  Overland flow routes. 
(c)  Minimum grade for earth ditches shall be 1.5 percent. For lesser ditch grade, the engineer shall submit design for paved invert. 
(d)  Street drainage design. Inlets shall be provided so that surface water is not carried across or around any intersection of streets or parking lot drives nor for more than a distance of 400 feet. Said inlets shall discharge into storm sewers which shall not discharge into side lot or rear lot drainage ditches. 
(e)  Inlets shall be provided at all low points and at all points not to exceed 400-foot intervals. 
(f)  Rear yard inlets having a minimum depth of two feet shall be provided such that rear yard overland flow shall not travel more than 300 feet or across four lots, whichever is less. 
(g)  Minimum cover for storm sewers shall be 11/2 feet. Storm sewers shall be designed to flow full with a minimum velocity of two feet per second and a maximum velocity of ten feet per second. 
(h)  Storm sewers shall be constructed in accordance with the Illinois Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction. The minimum inside diameter of storm sewer permitted to be used shall be 12 inches, except that a single inlet can be connected into a catchbasin, manhole, or another inlet with a ten-inch diameter storm sewer. 
(i)  Building drainage design. 
(1)  A point of discharge of sump pumps shall be shown for each building intended to have a basement or crawl space. Positive drainage from that point shall be provided to the storm sewer system. Such drainage shall not be across any street, sidewalk or parking lot and shall be to the rear of the property. 
If feasible, 15 minutes' retention time shall be provided upstream of the storm sewer system for said discharge. 
(2)  Runoff shall be drained away from the building to lot line swales or ditches, which shall merge as quickly as possible and then discharge into storm sewers. The route of flow of stormwater away from each building into swales, ditches and storm sewers, to where it leaves the site, shall be shown. Inlets and catchbasins shall be provided. 
(j)  Vacant lot drainage design. Positive drainage design shall be established for each lot whether or not it is the intention to construct a building on that lot at this time. 
(k)  Parking lot drainage design. Flow within and from parking lots shall be shown by arrows on design drawings. Inlets and catchbasins shall be provided so that flow from said lots is not carried across any sidewalk line or across or around any intersection. The maximum depth for stormwater detention provided in parking lots shall be one foot. 
    The minimum longitudinal slopes shall be 0.5 percent and the maximum shall be five percent in the area of the parking lot that is provided. The inlets where up to one foot of water is ponded, shall be located in driving aisles wherever possible. 
(l)  Retention-detention facilities. 
(1)  Retention-detention facilities are required for all developments except those in which: 
a.  The parcels being redeveloped or developed total less than three acres for single-family or two-family residential land uses; or 
b.  The parcels being redeveloped or developed total less than one acre for multiple-family or nonresidential land uses; or 
c.  The parcels being redeveloped or developed total greater than the thresholds in paragraphs a. or b. above, but the new development totals less than 10,000 square feet. 
(2)  The volume of detention storage required shall be calculated, using methods outlined in the Federal Technical Publication TR-55 as developed by the soil conservation service using the following criteria:
