ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Enforcement. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of this chapter, to permit or maintain such violation, to refuse to obey any provision thereof, or to fail or refuse to comply with any such provision or regulation except as variation may be allowed by action of the president and board of trustees of the village in writing. Proof of such unlawful act or failure to act shall be deemed prima facie evidence that such act is that of the owner. Prosecution or lack thereof of either the owner or the occupant shall not be deemed to relieve the other. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  This chapter shall be deemed an exercise of the police powers of the village for the preservation and protection of the public health, peace, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. O-73-34, § 3, 11-1-1973; Code 1975, § 10-1; Ord. No. O-94-25, § 28, 6-2-1994) 
Secs. 46-2-46-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 46-31. - Adopted. 
    The regulations of the 2012 Edition of the International Fire Code, as recommended and published by the International Code Council, Inc., published in pamphlet form, are adopted as the Fire Code of the Village regulating and governing the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling, and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises with such amendments as are hereafter set forth in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 10-16; Ord. No. O-86-01, § 2, 2-6-1986; Ord. No. O-87-66, § 1, 10-1-1987; Ord. No. O-94-25, § 29, 6-2-1994; Ord. No. O-97-75, § 13, 12-18-1997; Ord. No. O-08-34, § 1, 5-1-2008; Ord. No. O-15-02, § 5, 2-5-2015) 
State Law reference- Municipal Adoption of Codes and Records Act, 50 ILCS 220/0.01 et seq.; incorporation by reference of certain construction regulations, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 46-32. - Amendments. 
(a)  Section 101.1 is amended to read as follows: 
Title. These regulations shall be known as the Fire Code of the Village of Hanover Park, hereafter referred to as "this code." 
(b)  Section 105.4.2.1 is amended by adding the following: 
Fire Protection System Shop Drawings. Shop drawings for the fire protection system(s) shall be submitted to indicate compliance with this code and the construction documents, and shall be approved prior to the start of installation. Shop drawings shall contain all information as required by the referenced installation standards in chapter 9. For each hydraulically calculated automatic fire sprinkler system area identified on submitted shop drawings provide a copy of the hydraulic nameplate. 
(c)  Section 109.4 is amended to read as follows: 
Violation penalties; Persons who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, install, alter, repair, or do work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the fire code official, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100 nor more than $1000. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall deem a separate violation. 
(d)  Section 111.4 is amended to read as follows: 
Failure to comply; Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine of not less than $100 or more than $1,000. 
(e)  Section 202, the first sentence of definition of Fire Area, is amended as follows: 
Fire Area. The aggregate floor area bounded by the exterior walls of a building, regardless of fire walls, fire barriers, or fire resistance-rated horizontal assemblies. 
(f)  Section 507.5.1 is amended to read as follows: 
Where required. Where a portion of the facility or building hereafter constructed or moved into or within the Village is more than 300 feet from a hydrant on a fire apparatus access road, as measured by an approved route around the exterior of the facility or building, on site fire hydrants and mains shall be provided where required by the fire code official. 
Exceptions: 
1.  For Group R-3 and Group U occupancies, the distance shall be 600 feet. 
2.  For buildings equipped throughout with an approved automatic fire sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2, the distance shall be 600 feet. 
(g)  Section 507.5.1.1 is amended to read as follows: 
Hydrant for sprinkler or standpipe systems; Buildings equipped with a sprinkler or standpipe system installed in accordance with Section 905 shall have a fire hydrant within 100 feet of the fire department connection. 
(h)  Section 901.4.1.1 is added as follows: 
Fire sprinklers and fire detectors-ceilings; In buildings protected by automatic fire sprinklers or automatic fire detectors, suspended or removable ceiling tiles shall be maintained in place to prevent the delay in fire sprinkler or fire detector activation. 
Exception: When additional fire sprinklers or fire detectors are installed in the space above the suspended ceiling. 
(i)  Section 903.2.1 is amended to read as follows: 
All buildings of all use groups, other than one-and-two-family dwellings, greater than 2,500 square feet shall be protected with an approved automatic fire sprinkler system installed and maintained in accordance with NFPA 13. All spec warehouse buildings (Use Groups S and F) with a ceiling height 25 feet or greater shall be protected with an ESFR fire sprinkler system or hydraulically-calculated system for Class IV commodities with rack storage calculated to the greatest storage height. All automatic fire sprinkler systems shall be electronically supervised by an approved fire alarm system. 
For one and two-family dwellings refer to the Residential Code. 
(j)  Section 903.2.1 through 903.2.10 is deleted. 
(k)  Section 903.3.5 is amended by adding the following: 
Water supplies. Water supplies for automatic sprinkler systems shall comply with this section and the standards referenced in Section 903.3.1. The potable water supply shall be protected against backflow in accordance with the requirements of this section and The International Plumbing Code. Hydrant flow data used for the design of any automatic fire sprinkler system shall be no more than one year old. 
(l)  Section 903.3.8 is added to read as follows: 
A minimum safety factor of 10% or 5 psi shall be provided in any automatic fire sprinkler system hydraulic calculation. The system demand shall be a minimum of 5 psi below the seasonal low water flow test supply. 
(m)  Section 903.4 is amended to read as follows: 
Sprinkler system supervision and alarms; All valves controlling the water supply for automatic sprinkler systems, pumps, tanks, water levels and temperatures, critical air pressures, and water-flow switches on all sprinkler systems shall be electrically supervised by a fire alarm system. 
Exceptions: 
1.  Automatic sprinkler systems protecting one-and-two-family dwellings; 
2.  Limited area systems serving fewer than 20 sprinklers; 
3.  Automatic sprinkler systems installed in accordance with NFPA 13R where common supply main is used to supply both domestic water and the automatic sprinkler system, and a separate shutoff valve for the automatic sprinkler system is not provided; 
4.  Jockey pump control valves that are sealed or locked in the open position; 
5.  Control valves to commercial kitchen hoods, paint spray booths or dip tanks that are sealed or locked in the open position; 
6.  Valves controlling the fuel supply to fire pump engines that are sealed or locked in the open position; 
7.  Trim valves to pressure switches in dry, pre-action and deluge sprinkler systems that are sealed or locked in the open position. 
(n)  Section 90.3.4.1 is amended to read as follows: 
Alarm, supervisory, and trouble signals shall be distinctly different and automatically transmitted to the Fire Department's communication center. All new required alarm systems shall, transmit trouble, supervisory, and fire signals directly to the Fire Department's communication center via a wireless transmitter in accordance with NFPA 72. Only equipment certified and approved by the remote receiving station, and/or its designated proprietor may be installed. The designated proprietary agent shall be the only authorized installer of the approved radio transmitter. Existing systems shall be changed to wireless upon alarm owner's request, when the existing equipment is updated or where a disconnection of the telephone lines has occurred for a period of more than thirty days. 
Exception: Supervisory service is not required for: 
1.  Single-and-multiple-station smoke alarms required by Section 907.2.10; 
2.  Smoke detectors in Group I-3 occupancies; 
3.  Automatic sprinkler systems in one-and-two-family dwellings. 
(o)  Section 903.4.2 is amended to read as follows: 
Approved audible and visual appliances shall be connected to each automatic fire sprinkler system in accordance with Sections 903.4.2.1 and 903.4.2.2. Sprinkler system water-flow alarm devices shall be activated by water flow equivalent to the flow of a single sprinkler of the smallest orifice size installed in the system. 
(p)  Section 903.4.2.1 is added to read as follows: 
Exterior appliances; A clear 75 cd, weather-proof strobe light shall be provided above the fire department connection. The strobe light shall be supervised by the fire alarm system and shall only operate upon the water flow activation. 
(q)  Section 903.4.2.1. is added to read as follows: 
Audible appliances; A 10-inch 120v DC alarm bell shall be provided above the fire department connection. 
(r)  Section 903.4.2.2 is added to read as follows: 
Interior appliances; Interior audible and visible alarms supervised by a fire alarm system shall be provided in accordance with Section 907.5.1 through 907.5.2.3.4. Audible and visible alarm indicating devices shall be seen and heard in all areas of the building. 
(s)  Section 903.4.2.3 is added to read as follows: 
Automatic fire sprinkler system inspector test valves shall be accessible at all times and located no more than six feet above the finished floor. On multiple riser systems the test valves shall be marked to indicate which riser and area it tests. 
(t)  Section 903.4.3 is amended to read as follows: 
Floor control valves; Approved supervised indicating control valves shall be provided at the point of connection to the riser on each floor in high-rise buildings. Indicating control valves and water flow switches shall be provided at the point of connection to the riser on each floor in multiple story occupancies. 
(u)  Section 903.4.4 is added to read as follows: 
Zoned areas. When single zone of an automatic fire sprinkler system protects more than a single room or area, the fire code official may require additional smoke detectors in order to more rapidly identify the location of the smoke or fire. 
(v)  Section 903.7 is added to read as follows: 
Hydraulic design; A copy of the hydraulic nameplate shall be provided on each drawing for all hydraulically-calculated areas. 
(w)  Section 903.8 is added to read as follows: 
Fire Pump Room. All automatic fire sprinkler system pump rooms shall be provided a one-hour separation. An outside access door shall be provided for all automatic fire sprinkler system pump rooms. The door shall be labeled "Fire Sprinkler Pump Room" in minimum 4 inch contrasting letters. 
(x)  Section 905.3.9 is added to read as follows: 
In all warehouse storage areas exceeding 30,000 square feet, and where storage exceeds 12 feet high, provide inside 2 1/2 inch fire hose valves with 1 1/2 inch reducer to a 1 1/2 inch connection. Locate the valves at each door entrance to the warehouse and/or storage area. Provide additional 2 1/2 inch fire hose valves so that no portion of the warehouse and/or storage area is more than 120 feet maximum travel distance to a fire hose valve. Show the location of all obstructions and/or racks on the drawing. 
The fire hose valves system piping shall be: 
a.  A separate riser piping system. 
b.  The 2 1/2 inch valves shall be supplied by a minimum of 4 inch piping with 2 1/2 inch drops to each valve. 
c.  Where system pressures exceed 100 psi provide Potter reducing pressure field adjustable type valves. 
(y)  Section 907.1.4 is added to read as follows: 
All fire alarms shall be of the addressable type and shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 72. Sections 907.1.4 and 907.1.5, as amended, in Section 18-1-9 of Chapter 18 of the Municipal Code of the Village of Hanover Park, as amended, shall also be adhered to and made part of this Fire Code. 
(z)  Section 907.2.24 is added to read as follows: 
Where required - new buildings and structures. A fire alarm system utilizing automatic fire detectors and manual fire alarm devices shall be provided throughout all buildings not provided with an automatic sprinkler system complying with NFPA 13 or NFPA 13R. 
The exceptions in the following sections are deleted: 907.2.1, 907.2.2, 907.2.3(3), 907.2.4, 907.2.7(1), 907.2.8.1(2), 907.2.9.1(2), 907.2.10.1(2). 
(aa)  Section 907.4.2.5 is amended to read as follows: 
Protective Covers. Listed manual fire alarm box protective covers shall be provided for all installed manual fire alarm boxes to prevent malicious false alarms or to provide the manual fire alarm box with protection from physical damage. 
(bb)  Section 907.5 is amended to read as follows: 
Occupant notification systems. A fire alarm system shall annunciate at the fire alarm control unit and shall initiate occupant notification upon activation, in accordance with sections 907.5.1 through 907.5.2.3.4. The activation of any of the following devices shall result in occupant notification: 
1.  Automatic fire detectors. 
2.  Automatic fire sprinkler system water-flow devices. 
3.  Manual fire alarm boxes. 
4.  Automatic fire extinguishing systems when installed in buildings or structures that are provided with occupant notification.

Multi-tenant Group M. Single story, multi-tenant Group M buildings shall be "ring by tenant" when activated by the automatic fire detection system and shall include a weatherproof, clear outside strobe over the entrance to each tenant space as directed by the fire code official. All outside strobes shall be 75 cd. 
(dd)  Section 912.1.1 is added to read as follows: 
All fire department connections shall be a 4 inch Storz connection with a 30 degree down turn.

Fire sprinkler system - Fire Pump test header

b.  Provide an outside test header on fire pump installations. 
(ff)  Section 1006.3 is amended to read as follows: 
Emergency power for illumination; the power supply for means of egress illumination shall normally be provided by the premises' electrical supply. In the event of power supply failure, an emergency electrical system shall automatically illuminate the following areas: 
1.  Aisles and unenclosed egress stairways in rooms and spaces that require two or more means of egress. 
2.  Corridors, interior exit stairways and ramps and exit passageways in buildings required to have two or more exits. 
3.  Exterior egress components at other than their levels of exit discharge until exit discharge is accomplished for buildings required to have two or more exits. 
4.  Interior exit discharge elements, as permitted in section 1027.1, in buildings required to have two or more exits. 
5.  Exterior landings, as required by Section 1008.1.6, for exit discharge doorways in buildings required to have two or more exits. 
6.  All rooms containing the building fire sprinkler riser(s), fire pump(s) and fire alarm control panel(s). 
The emergency power system shall provide power for a duration of not less than 90 minutes and shall consist of storage batteries, unit equipment or an on-site generator. The installation of the emergency power system shall be in accordance with Section 604. 
(gg)  Section 5504.3.1.1.3 is amended to read as follows: 
Location. Containers of cryogenic fluids shall not be located within diked areas containing other hazardous materials. Storage of flammable cryogenic fluids in stationary containers outside of buildings is prohibited within all zoning classifications except by permit. 
(hh)  Section 5704.2.9.6.1 is amended to read as follows: 
Locations where above-ground tanks are prohibited; Storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above-ground tanks outside of buildings is prohibited within all zoning classifications except by permit. 
(ii)  Section 6104.2 is amended to read as follows: 
Maximum capacity within established limits. Within the limits established by law restricting the storage of liquefied petroleum gas for the protection of heavily populated or congested areas, the aggregate capacity of any one installation shall not exceed a water capacity of 2,000 gallons (7,570 L.). Such storage is prohibited within all zoning classifications except by operational permit. 
Exception: In particular installations, this capacity limit shall be determined by the Fire Code Official, after consideration of special features such as topographical conditions, nature of occupancy, and proximity to buildings, capacity of proposed containers, degree of fire protection to be provided and capabilities of the fire department. 
(Code 1975, § 10-17; Ord. No. O-86-01, § 2, 2-6-1986; Ord. No. O-94-25, § 30, 6-2-1994; Ord. No. O-08-34, § 2, 5-1-2008; Ord. No. O-15-02, § 5, 2-5-2015) 
Sec. 46-33. - Access passageways; restrictions. 
    It shall be unlawful to enclose any exit from a building with any turnstile, fence, gate, rails or similar devices or combination of devices and openings. 
    All existing turnstiles, fences, gates, rails or other similar devices shall be removed prior to December 1, 1985. 
(Code 1975, § 10-19; Ord. No. O-85-13, § 1, 4-4-1985) 
Sec. 46-34. - Smoke detector act adopted; amendments; violation; penalty. 
(a)  Adopted. The regulations of the Smoke Detector Act (425 ILCS 60/1 et seq.) and all rules, regulations and amendments thereto are hereby adopted by reference with such amendments as are hereafter set forth. 
(b)  Amendments. 
(1)  Section 803(c) is amended by adding: "If each unit opens directly into a common enclosed stairway, a detector shall also be installed on the ceiling of each floor landing." 
(2)  Section 803(e) is amended by adding: "All smoke detectors required to be wired into the structure's AC power line shall also be provided with battery-powered backup." 
(c)  Violation; penalty. A violation of any provision of the Smoke Detector Act (425 ILCS 60/1 et seq.), as amended, shall be considered a violation of section 46-34(a) and the penalty as provided in section 1-9 [shall apply]. 
(Code 1975, § 10-20; Ord. No. O-90-66, § 1, 9-6-1990) 
Sec. 46-35. - Hazardous material removal and abatement costs. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the terms used herein are defined as follows: 
(1)  Hazardous material: 
a.  Hazardous substance or hazardous waste as defined in the Environmental Protection Act (415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.), amended; or 
b.  Any substance listed in the list of toxic pollutants found in 40 CFR 401.15, as amended; or 
c.  Any of the following: explosives, pyrotechnics, flammable gas, flammable compressed gas, nonflammable compressed gas, flammable liquid, oxidizing material, any flammable material, poisonous gas, poisonous liquid, irritating material, material that causes diseases in humans, gas under such pressure that an explosion hazard exists, radioactive material, corrosive material, or liquefied petroleum gas, including any substance, material, waste or mixture designated as a hazardous material, waste or substance according to 49 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), including: 
1.  Compressed gas: Any substance regulated as a compressed gas by the United States Department of Transportation by regulations found in 49 CFR 173.300. 
2.  Explosive: Any substance regulated as a class A or class B explosive by the United States Department of Transportation by regulations found in 49 CFR 173.53 and 173.88. 
3.  Flammable liquid: Any substance regulated as a flammable liquid by the United States Department of Transportation by regulations found in 49 CFR 173.115. 
4.  Flammable solid: Any substance regulated as a flammable solid by the United States Department of Transportation by regulations found in 49 CFR 173.150. 
5.  Oxidizer: Any substance regulated as an oxidizer by the United States Department of Transportation by regulations found in 49 CFR 173.151. 
6.  Poison Any liquid or gas that is life-threatening when mixed with air in small amounts and shall also include all those substances regulated as poison "A" by the United States Department of Transportation by regulations found in 49 CFR 173.326. 
7.  Radioactive material: Any substance required by the United States Department of Transportation to have type A packaging or other special protection or closed-transport vehicles under regulations found in 49 CFR 173.425. 
d.  Any material which is classified by the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) as either a flammable liquid, a class II combustible liquid or a class IIIA combustible liquid; or 
e.  Any material which has been determined to be the party storing it or having control of it through testing or other objective means to be likely to create a significant potential or actual hazard to public health, safety or welfare or to the environment. This definition shall not establish a requirement to test for the purposes of this section. 
(2)  Hazardous material incident: Any emergency or nonemergency circumstance involving the sudden release or threatened or potential release of hazardous material which, in the judgment of the village or a federal or state agency or other local agency, threatens immediate and irreparable harm to the environment or the health, safety or welfare of any individual other than individuals exposed to the risks associated with hazardous material in the normal course of their employment. "Hazardous material incident" includes those incidents of releasing or abandoning of a hazardous material, whether or not such releasing or abandoning is found to threaten immediate and irreparable harm, or the improper storage or possession of a hazardous material; but such term does not include any release of a hazardous material authorized pursuant to any federal, state or local law or regulation. 
(3)  Release: Any actual or threatened spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, escaping, leaching, dumping or disposing into the environment but excludes: 
a.  Any release which results in exposure to persons solely within a workplace with respect to a claim which such persons may assert against the employer of such persons; 
b.  Unlawful emissions from the engine exhaust of a motor vehicle, rolling stock, aircraft, vessel or pipeline pumping station engine; 
c.  Release of a source, byproduct or special nuclear material from a nuclear incident, as those terms are defined in Atomic Energy Act of 1954, if such release is subject to requirements with respect to financial protection established by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission under section 1870 of such act; and 
d.  The normal application of fertilizer. 
(4)  Remove or removal: The cleanup or removal of released hazardous material or improperly stored hazardous material from the environment; such actions as may be necessary to be taken in the event of the threat of release of hazardous material into the environment; such actions as may be necessary to monitor, assess and evaluate the release or threat of release of hazardous material, the disposal of removed material or the taking of such other actions as may be necessary to prevent, minimize or mitigate damage to the public health or welfare or the environment which may otherwise result from a release or threat of release. The term includes, in addition, without being limited to security fencing or other measure to limit access, provision or alternative water suppliers, temporary evacuation and housing of threatened individuals and any emergency assistance which may be provided under the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act (20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq.), as amended. 
(b)  Removal; abatement. The village is authorized to remove or abate the effect of any hazardous material involving the actual or threatened release, discharge or deposit upon or onto property or facilities within the village. The following described persons shall be jointly and severally liable to the village for the payment of all costs incurred by the village as a result of such removal or abatement activity: 
(1)  Any person or persons whose negligent or willful act or omission proximately caused such release, discharge or deposit; 
(2)  The person or persons who owned or had custody or control of the hazardous material at the time of such threatened or actual release, discharge or deposit without regard to fault or proximate cause; 
(3)  The person or persons who owned or had custody or control of the container or vehicle which held such hazardous material or substance at the time of or immediately prior to such actual or threatened release, discharge or deposit without regard to fault or proximate cause; and 
(4)  Any person owning or in control of any real property from which a hazardous material is or may be released. 
(c)  Supervision/verification by fire chief. In the event that any person undertakes, either voluntarily or upon the order of the fire chief or other village official to remove or abate the effects of any actual or threatened release, discharge, or deposit of hazardous material upon or onto any property or facility within the village, the fire chief may take such action as is necessary to supervise or verify the adequacy of the removal or abatement. The persons described in subsection (b) shall be liable to the village for all costs incurred as a result of such supervision or verification. 
(d)  Incurred costs. Costs incurred by the village shall include but shall not necessarily be limited to the following: actual labor costs of village personnel, including benefits and administrative overhead; cost of equipment operation; cost of materials obtained directly by the village and costs of consultants whose expertise is required to remove or abate the incident or to assess the nature and extent of damage done; cost of equipment operation; replacement cost of vehicles or equipment which, in the determination of the fire chief, is contaminated beyond refuse or repair; laboratory costs; cost of materials or equipment obtained directly by the village; cost of any contract or mutual-aid labor and materials; and attorney's fees incurred in collecting monies owed to the village by liable parties. 
(e)  Nonexclusive remedy. The remedies provided by this section shall be in addition to any other remedies or penalties provided by law. 
(f)  Burden of liability. This section shall be liberally construed to give effect to its purpose which is to shift the burden of liability for the aforesaid removal or abatement cost from the citizens of the village to those responsible for the incident. 
(g)  Exceptions. 
(1)  There shall be no liability under this section for a person otherwise liable who can establish by a preponderance of the evidence that the release or substantial threat of release of a hazardous substance and the damages resulting therefrom were caused solely by: 
a.  An act of God; 
b.  An act of war; 
c.  An act of omission of a third party other than an employee or agent of the defendant or other than one whose act or omission occurs in connection with a contractual relationship, existing directly or indirectly, with the defendant (except where the sole contractual arrangement arises from a published tariff and acceptance for carriage by a common carrier by rail) if the defendant establishes by a preponderance of the evidence that: 
1.  He exercised due care with respect to the hazardous substance concerned taking into consideration the characteristics of such hazardous substance in light of all relevant facts and circumstances; and 
2.  He took precautions against foreseeable acts or omissions of any such third party and the consequences that could foreseeably result from such acts or omissions; or 
d.  Any combination of the foregoing paragraphs. 
(2)  There shall be no liability under this section for any release permitted by state or federal law. 
(3)  There shall be no liability under this section for damages as a result of actions taken or omitted in the course of rendering care, assistance or advice in accordance with this section or the National Contingency Plan pursuant to the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act of 1980 (Public Law 96-510 as amended) or at the direction of any on-scene coordinator appointed under such plan with respect to an incident creating a danger to public health or welfare or the environment as a result of any release of a hazardous substance or a substantial threat thereof. This subsection shall not preclude liability for damages as the result of gross negligence or intentional misconduct on the part of such person. For the purposes of the preceding sentence, reckless, willful or wanton misconduct shall constitute gross negligence. 
(4)  No person may recover under the authority of this section for any response costs or damages resulting from the application of a pesticide product registered under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act. 
(5)  Nothing in this subsection (g) shall affect or modify in any way the obligations or liability of any person under any other provision of this section or state or federal law, including common law, for damages, injury or loss resulting from a release or substantial threat of a release of any hazardous substance or for removal or remedial action or the costs of removal or remedial action of such hazardous substance. 
(h)  Violation; penalty. If any person who is liable for a release or substantial threat of release of a hazardous substance fails without sufficient cause to provide removal or remedial action upon or in accordance with a notice and request by the village or upon or in accordance with any order of the Illinois Pollution Control Board or any court, such person may be liable to the village for punitive damages in an amount at least equal to and not more than three times the amount of any costs incurred by the village as a result of such failure to take such removal or remedial action. The punitive damages imposed shall be in addition to any costs recovered from such person pursuant to this section and in addition to any other penalty or relief provided by the act or any other law. 
(Code 1975, § 10-21; Ord. No. O-90-67, § 1, 9-20-1990; Ord. No. O-04-03, § 2, 1-15-2004; Ord. No. O-04-33, § 1, 5-6-2004) 
State Law reference- Uniform Hazardous Substances Act, 430 ILCS 35/1 et seq. 
Secs. 46-36-46-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to create a fire department, 65 ILCS 5/11-6-1. 

Sec. 46-61. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby created and established a fire department which shall be under the jurisdiction and control of the village manager which shall consist of a fire chief and such other members of said fire department as may be from time to [time] provided by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1975, § 10-29; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994) 
Sec. 46-62. - Appointment of members. 
(a)  The head of the fire department shall be the fire chief, who shall have the control and supervision over all employees of the department subject to the order and direction of the village manager. The village manager shall appoint the fire chief and all employees of the department. 
(b)  Procedures for the recruitment, selection, appointment, and promotion of fire department personnel shall be governed by article V of the Village of Hanover Park Personnel Rules and Regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 10-30; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994; Ord. No. O-99-04, § 1, 1-21-1999) 
Sec. 46-63. - Oath of members. 
    The fire chief and all members of the fire department, before entering upon the duties of their office, shall take the oath of office prescribed by the village. 
(Code 1975, § 10-31; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994) 
Sec. 46-64. - Fire chief duties. 
(a)  The chief of the fire department shall have control and be responsible for the fire department and the performance of the duties of the members of the department. The fire chief shall have control of all fire, emergency medical service, hazardous material, and all other fire apparatus and shall maintain such apparatus in good operating condition. He shall keep such records and make such reports regarding the activities of the fire department as may be required by the village manager, and he shall make an annual report to the president and board of trustees. 
(b)  The fire chief shall be responsible for the training and conduct of members of the department and may make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the conduct and guidance of the members of the department as he shall deem advisable. Such rules, when approved by the village manager, shall be binding on such members. 
(Code 1975, § 10-32; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994; Ord. No. O-04-33, § 2, 5-6-2004) 
Sec. 46-65. - Obedience to orders. 
    The chief and, in his absence, such officer of higher rank as may be designated by him, shall have charge of the activities of the department. All members of the department shall obey the orders and directions of the fire chief and other superiors in the department. 
(Code 1975, § 10-33; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994) 
Sec. 46-66. - Duties of department. 
    It shall be the function of the fire department and the duty of the members thereof to prevent and extinguish accidental or destructive fires, provide emergency medical services, and respond to hazardous material incidents occurring in the village; to enforce all ordinances relating to fire hazards, and to perform such other duties as directed by the village manager. 
(Code 1975, § 10-34; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994; Ord. No. O-04-33, § 3, 5-6-2004) 
Sec. 46-67. - Spectators at fires. 
    It shall be the duty of all spectators at fires to obey all orders of members of the fire department on duty there with respect to keeping away from the scene of the fire or the handling of or interference with the apparatus of the department. 
(Code 1975, § 10-35; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994) 
Sec. 46-68. - Removal of property. 
    The fire chief shall have the power to cause the removal of any property, whenever it becomes necessary for the preservation of such property from fire or to prevent the spreading of fire or to protect adjoining property. 
(Code 1975, § 10-36; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994) 
Sec. 46-69. - Destruction of structures. 
    The fire chief, or other officer in command, may direct a firefighter to cut down and remove any building, structure or fence for the purpose of extinguishing or checking the progress of any fire. 
(Code 1975, § 10-37; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994) 
Sec. 46-70. - Investigation and report of causes of fire. 
    The fire chief shall investigate the cause of all fires occurring in the village as soon after their occurrence as practical, and shall keep a record of such investigation and the evidence of any criminal act or violation of village ordinance in connection therewith. 
(Code 1975, § 10-38; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994) 
Sec. 46-71. - Power to arrest. 
    The fire chief or any member designated by the fire chief of the department shall have the power during a fire and for a period of 36 hours after its extinction to arrest any person at or near the scene of an accidental or destructive fire for interference with the fire department in the performance of its duties, or for the commission of any crime or ordinance violation in connection therewith. 
(Code 1975, § 10-39; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994) 
Sec. 46-72. - Emergency ambulance service. 
    The fire department shall provide emergency ambulance service in cases of actual and extreme emergency for the transportation of critically ill or injured persons whose lives are threatened unless medical treatment is immediately rendered. 
(Code 1975, § 10-40; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994) 
Sec. 46-73. - Foreign fire insurance company fees. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any corporation, company or association which is not incorporated under the laws of the State of Illinois to engage in effecting fire insurance in the village or to transact any business of fire insurance in the village without fully complying with this section. 
(b)  Any such corporation, company or association shall pay to the treasurer of the village for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department or for the firemen's pension fund a sum of money equal to two percent of the gross receipts received as premiums in any way for fire insurance policies on any property in the village. Such payments shall be made for the year ending July 1 of each year and made on or before July 15 following the termination of the year for which such payments are due. 
(c)  Every person acting as agent or representative on behalf of a designated corporation, company or association shall on or before July 15 of each year, render to the treasurer a full and true account, verified by oath, of all premiums which were received by him or by any other person for him on behalf of that corporation, company or association during the year ending on July 1 preceding the report on fire insurance policies. 
(Code 1975, § 10-41; Ord. No. O-94-55, § 1, 9-15-1994) 
Sec. 46-74. - Cost recovery program. 
(a)  Medical services. 
(1)  All patients receiving basic life support 1 [] services with no transport shall pay a fee of $525.00. 
(2)  All patients receiving basic life support services with non-emergent transport to an area hospital shall pay a fee of $900.00. 
(3)  All patients receiving basic life support services with emergent transport to an area hospital shall pay a fee of $900.00. 
(4)  All patients receiving advance life support 2 [] services with no transport shall pay a fee of $700.00. 
(5)  All patients receiving advanced life support 3 [] services non-emergent transport shall pay a fee of $1,100.00. 
(6)  All patients receiving advanced life support services and emergent transport shall pay a fee of $1,100.00. 
(7)  All patients receiving advanced life support II 4 [] and emergency transport to an area hospital shall pay a fee of $1,350.00. 
(8)  All patient receiving critical care transport 5 [] shall pay a fee of $2,000.00. 
(9)  In addition to the above stated fees, the following additional fees if applicable shall be charged: 
a.  A fee of $15.00 per mile for transport by ambulance. 
b.  Wait fees of $25.00 per 30-minute intervals while patient undergoes assessment/care and will be returned to the same or different destination from which the call originated. 
c.  All fees for disposable supplies when the receiving hospital does not replace those supplies to the village. 
(b)  Fire and rescue service. 
(1)  Definitions. 
a.  Careless. Not taking ordinary or reasonable care, including the disregard of the safety of others. 
b.  Contract. An oral or written agreement to have work performed by a contractor. 
c.  Contractor. Person or entity who has a contract to perform a task or service. 
d.  Emergency response. Any call requiring the fire department to respond. 
e.  Incendiary act. A fire purposely set by a person or persons. 
f.  Incident. Any request, by any person for the services of the Hanover Park Fire Department. 
g.  Malicious act. A wrongful act intentionally done without legal justification or excuse; an unlawful act done willfully and purposely. 
h.  Negligence. Failure to exercise the standard of care that a reasonably prudent person would use under similar circumstances, including the doing of something which a reasonable and prudent person would not do. 
(2)  Acts requiring cost reimbursement. The following acts are subject to the fees enumerated in subsection (b)(3) of this section: 
a.  Negligent/careless acts. Any contractor, whose negligence or careless actions or conduct causes an incident resulting in an emergency response, shall be required to make restitution, pursuant to section (b)(3) of this section to the Village of Hanover Park for the costs of that emergency response. 
b.  Malicious or incendiary acts. Any person, whose malicious or incendiary act causes an incident resulting in an emergency response, shall be required to make restitution, pursuant to section (b)(3) of this section to the Village of Hanover Park for the costs of that emergency response. 
c.  Driving under the influence. Every person found guilty, including an order of supervision or probation, of section 11-501 entitled, "Driving while under the influence of alcohol, other drugs or drugs, intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof" of the Illinois Vehicle Code, who proximately causes any incident resulting in an appropriate emergency response, shall make restitution pursuant to the fees in subsection (b)(3) of this section to the Village of Hanover Park for the village's costs of that emergency response. 
d.  Salvage operations. A fee of $300.00 shall be charged for fire department salvage operations including but not limited to tarping personal property and smoke or water removal. 
e.  Fire company standby. When a fire company (engine, truck, or ambulance) is requested or required to stand by for a nonvillage-sponsored event, the person responsible shall be required to make restitution, pursuant to subsection (b)(3) of this section to the Village of Hanover Park for the costs of such fire company standby. No person shall contract for fire company standby services within the village other than with the village fire department unless the village is unable to provide such services. 
(3)  Fees. 
a.  The following fees shall apply to all acts enumerated to subsection (b)(2) of this section: 
Per fire engine per hour ..... $350.00 
Per truck company per hour ..... 450.00 
Per command van per hour ..... 175.00 
Per ambulance per hour ..... 350.00 
Per administrative vehicle per hour ..... 100.00 
Per administrator per hour ..... 120.00 
Per fire inspector per hour ..... 100.00 
Per suppression member per hour ..... 100.00 
b.  The fee for use of any equipment not stated above shall be the higher of the current Federal Emergency Management Agency schedule of equipment rates or the schedule of average annual equipment ownership expense prepared by the Illinois Department of Transportation. 
c.  A minimum of one hour shall be charged. Subsequent hours will be billed at 15-minute increments. 
(4)  Additional fees. The following additional fees shall apply as indicated: 
a.  A fee of $500.00 for the extrication of persons from vehicles involved in traffic accidents. 
b.  A fee of $500.00 for the extinguishing of a motor vehicle fire. 
c.  A fee of $500.00 shall be charged for salvage operations including but not limited to tarping of personal property, ventilation of smoke or other hazardous products and or water removal. 
d.  When a fire company (engine, truck, or ambulance) is requested or required to stand by for a nonvillage-sponsored event, the person responsible shall be required to make restitution, pursuant to the fees in subsection (b)(3) of this section to the Village of Hanover Park for the costs of such fire company standby. No person shall contract for fire company standby services within the village other than with the village fire department unless the village is unable to provide such services. 
e.  A fee of $35.00 charged to all non-court ordered non-Village of Hanover Park residents whom request a child car seat installation, and a fee of $100.00 for all court ordered installations of a child's car seat regardless of residency. 
(c)  Waiver of fees. The fire chief or his/her designee may waive or reduce fees, upon his discretion, based on mitigating circumstances. 
(Ord. No. O-00-23, § 1, 7-1-2000; Ord. No. O-04-03, § 1, 1-15-2004; Ord. No. O-08-40, §§ 1, 2, 5-1-2008; Ord. No. O-10-20, § 1, 8-5-2010; Ord. No. O-12-47, § 1, 12-20-2012; Ord. No. O-13-06, § 7, 1-24-2013; Ord. No. O-16-03, § 1, 1-21-2016; Ord. No. O-17-31, § 1, 10-5-2017)

 The provision of medically necessary supplies and services as defined in the National EMS Practice Blueprint. A basic level of pre-hospital and inter-hospital emergency and non-emergency care, as authorized by IDOT and the department EMS medical director, that include:

 2. CPR. 
 3. Control of shock. 
 4. Control of bleeding. 
 5. Splinting of fractures.

 The provision of medically necessary supplies and services including the provision of an ALS Assessment or at least one ALS intervention, IV and cardiac monitor are the most common.

 The provision of medically necessary supplies and services including: 
 At least three administrations of one or more medications by intravenous, intranasal, intramuscular, or endotracheal tube bolus or continuous infusion; and/or at least one of the following procedures: 
 1. Manual defibrillation/Cardioversion. 
 2. Endotracheal Intubation. 
 3. Cardiac Pacing. 
 4. Chest Decompression. 
 5. Surgical Airway. 
 6. Intraosseous Line.

Supplies and services may include specialized intravenous medications, maintenance of central venous lines, ventilators, and other specialized skills as approved by the village's medical director and deemed necessary by the requesting facility.

(a)  The following fees shall be paid by participants in the following fire department programs and classes. 
(b)  Schedule of fees:

(2)  CPR and First Aid Class (Nonresident) ..... $50.00 
(3)  Healthcare Provider CPR Class ..... $65.00 
(c)  No fee shall be charged for village employees or public safety volunteers. 
(Ord. No. O-04-09, § 1, 2-19-2004; Ord. No. O-10-20, § 2, 8-5-2010)

ARTICLE IV. - FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Firefighters' pension fund, 40 ILCS 5/4-101 et seq. 

Sec. 46-101. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a firefighters' pension fund pursuant to the Illinois Pension Code (40 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.), as amended, to be administered by board of trustees of the firefighters' pension fund of the village, who shall have all powers and duties as provided by the Illinois Pension Code. 
(Ord. No. O-00-21, § 1(10-50), 7-1-2000) 
Sec. 46-102. - Membership of board of trustees. 
    Pursuant to the Illinois Pension Code (40 ILCS 5/4-121), as amended, the board of trustees shall consist of five members: Two members of the board shall be appointed by the village president, two members shall be active participants of the pension fund, and one member shall be a retired member of the pension fund. 
(Ord. No. O-00-21, § 1(10-51), 7-1-2000; Ord. No. O-06-07, § 1, 2-16-2006) 
Editor's note- This section shall be in effect on April 17, 2006. 
Sec. 46-103. - Term of office of trustees. 
    The term of office for members of the board of trustees shall be as provided in the Illinois Pension Code (40 ILCS 5/4-121) and until his or her successor has been duly qualified. 
(Ord. No. O-00-21, § 1(10-52), 7-1-2000; Ord. No. O-06-07, § 1, 2-16-2006) 
Editor's note- This section shall be in effect on April 17, 2006. 
Sec. 46-104. - Pickup of firefighter pension fund contributions. 
    The village will pick up the contributions that firefighters are required to make to the pension fund pursuant to Section 118.1 of the Illinois Pension Code (40 ILCS 5/4-118.1), as permitted by Section 118.2 of the Illinois Pension Code (40 ILCS 5/4-118.2). Such contributions, although designated as employee contributions, shall be made by the village in lieu of employee contributions, and the cash salary of each firefighter shall be reduced by the amount so contributed. Firefighters shall not be given the option of receiving the contributions directly rather than having them deposited in the pension fund. 
(Ord. No. O-06-15, § 1, 4-20-2006) 
Secs. 46-105-46-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HANOVER PARK FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. O-00-22, § 1, adopted July 1, 2000, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore, such ordinance has been added as article V, §§ 46-121-46-125 at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 46-121. - Hanover Park Foreign Fire Insurance Board-Established. 
    There is hereby established a board known as the Hanover Park Foreign Fire Insurance Board. This board shall be comprised of and shall exercise the powers as designated therein being consistent with state statutes. 
(Ord. No. O-00-22, § 1, 7-1-2000) 
Sec. 46-122. - Election of officers. 
(a)  The board shall consist of seven members. The members of the board shall be designated chairman, vice chairman, secretary, treasurer, and trustee. Each member of the board shall be either a full-time member or part-time member with more than one year of service, not including noncivilian members of the Hanover Park Fire Department. 
(b)  The members of the board shall be elected by full-time members or part-time members with more than one year of service, not including noncivilian members of the department. 
(c)  The members of the board shall serve two-year terms. In the event no successor member assumes office prior to the expiration of the two-year term, then the member shall serve until a successor member assumes office. The initial term of office of the members of the board shall begin 30 days after completion of the election. Each board member shall hold office during his term unless the member resigns from the department, retires from the department, or is discharged from the department. If any of the three events occur, the board member shall automatically be removed from the board and the position deemed vacant. 
(d)  Vacancies in the board shall be filled by election by the noncivilian members of the department and such election shall be for the balance of the unexpired term. Any person elected to fill a board vacancy shall assume office immediately upon completion of the election. 
(Ord. No. O-00-22, § 1, 7-1-2000; Ord. No. O-05-51, § 1, 9-15-2005) 
Sec. 46-123. - Election procedure. 
(a)  Temporary. 
(1)  There is hereby established a Temporary Hanover Park Fire Department Election Committee. The temporary election committee shall consist of three members. The Chief of the Hanover Park Fire Department shall serve as a member and as chairman of the committee. The chief shall appoint a member of the department to serve as a member of committee and the remaining member shall be from the Hanover Park Professional Firefighters Association. 
(2)  The temporary election committee shall be responsible for organizing, conducting, and supervising the initial election of department officers to serve on the board. Thereafter, the board shall establish election procedures consistent with this article. 
(b)  Permanent. 
(1)  The board shall develop a procedure for governing the nomination of members to run for the various offices to serve on the board. The nominating procedure shall be established a minimum of 30 days prior to the expiration of the board members' terms of office. 
(2)  The board shall develop a procedure for the final election of members to the various offices on the board. The final election procedure shall be established a minimum of 30 days prior to the expiration of the board members' terms of office. 
(3)  The board may adopt rules and regulations governing the election of officers of the board. All rules and regulations with respect to the election process shall be posted throughout the department a minimum of 30 days prior to the election. 
(Ord. No. O-00-22, § 1, 7-1-2000) 
Sec. 46-124. - Powers and duties and procedures. 
(a)  The board shall make all needful rules and regulations with respect to the Hanover Park Foreign Fire Insurance Board and/or the management of monies appropriated to the board. 
(b)  Prior to the appropriation of funds by the Village of Hanover Park's Board of Trustees, the board shall develop and maintain a listing of those items that the board feels are appropriate expenditures under the state statutes. 
(c)  All expenditures by the board shall be in accordance with all Village of Hanover Park ordinances, rules, procedures, and policies concerning the expenditure of monies. Good and sound accounting principals shall be followed regarding the holding and spending of any monies. 
(d)  The funds of the board shall be annually reviewed as part of the Village of Hanover Park's audit. The audit shall verify that purchases by the board are for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the Hanover Park Fire Department. 
(e)  The treasurer of the board shall give a sufficient bond to the Village of Hanover Park. The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance by the treasurer of his or her duties under the state statutes, ordinance, and the rules and regulations adopted by the board. 
(f)  The funds received by the Village of Hanover Park pursuant to the levy of the foreign fire insurance board tax shall be set apart and shall be appropriated annually in the budget ordinance by the Board of Trustees of the Village of Hanover Park to the Hanover Park Fire Department Foreign Fire Insurance Board. 
(g)  The treasurer of the board shall receive funds appropriated by the village and shall pay out money and/or otherwise make expenditures upon the order of the board. Any expenditures made by the treasurer, pursuant to the order of the Board shall be solely for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the Hanover Park Fire Department. 
(Ord. No. O-00-22, § 1, 7-1-2000) 
Sec. 46-125. - Quorum, special meetings. 
    The board shall, in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, establish a regular time and place for its meetings; and publish notice of same. The board shall be subject to the provisions of the Illinois Open Meetings Act. The chairman shall preside at board meetings, the secretary shall keep record of the proceedings and actions of the board and may certify the same. Four members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The chairman may call a special meeting at any time. A special meeting may also be called upon the written notice of three members of the board. Such notice shall be in writing, duly signed by the board members. Such notice shall describe in brief the nature or object of the special meeting. Any person shall be entitled to appear and be heard on any matter before the board. Minutes of board meetings shall be filed with the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. O-00-22, § 1, 7-1-2000) 
Chapter 50 - GARBAGE, REFUSE AND SCAVENGERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; electricity, ch. 30; health and sanitation, ch. 54; depositing refuse in public places, § 66-20; streets, sidewalks and public places, ch. 86; subdivision regulations, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- Disposal of refuse, garbage and ashes in municipalities, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq.; removal of garbage and debris, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-13; land pollution and refuse disposal, 415 ILCS 5/20 et seq.; Local Solid Waste Disposal Act, 415 ILCS 10/1 et seq.; Solid Waste Planning and Recycling Act, 415 ILCS 15/1 et seq.; Illinois Solid Waste Management Act, 415 ILCS 20/1 et seq.; Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq.; spilling loads on highways, 625 ILCS 5/15-109 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the terms used herein are defined as follows: 
    Bulk storage container: Any single container or three or more toter carts for garbage and/or refuse which has a storage capacity in excess of 105 gallons and complies with all other applicable provisions of this Code. 
    Construction debris: Any waste or refuse collected at a premises on which the construction, reconstruction, alteration or remodeling of a building(s) and/or structure(s) is in process and which waste and refuse originates and is derived from such construction processes and operations, including earth, sod, rock, cartons, boxes, barrels, carpeting, drywall, wood excelsior, concrete, brick, lumber, paneling, metal, siding and similar materials. 
    Customer: Any person, firm or corporation which owns or occupies any premises within the village. 
    Garbage: Includes but is not limited to food waste, animal, fruit, vegetable, fish or fowl matter; food containers of any nature and other material of any nature which is subject to rapid decay, putrefaction and generation of noxious gases or odors and which serve as breeding or feeding materials for insects, rodents or other animals. 
    Garbage container: 
(1)  A garbage container is: 
a.  A metal or synthetic material container which has a maximum storage capacity of 35 gallons, not weighing more than 70 pounds and is constructed of a suitable gauge and material and with a tight-fitting cover so as to be capable of securely containing garbage and is easy to handle and easy to clean; 
b.  A plastic bag constructed of not less than one mil material that has a maximum storage capacity of 35 gallons, not weighing more than 70 pounds which is capable of being tightly closed by rolling or tying the top thereof and which will securely contain all garbage and/or refuse placed therein; and 
c.  One or two toter carts. 
(2)  The garbage container for recyclable materials shall only be the recycling container as defined in section 50-111; and 
(3)  The garbage container for landscape waste shall be a brown Kraft paper bag of not more than a 35-gallon capacity, a metal or rigid plastic container of not more than 35-gallon capacity or a village-approved toter cart but shall not include plastic bags. 
    Landscape waste: All accumulations of grass or shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree limbs and other materials accumulated as the result of the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees. 
    Premises: Each dwelling unit, industrial or commercial establishment, motel, hotel, school, church, hospital, club building or meeting hall and every structure or building within the village which is occupied for any purpose. 
    Recycling containers, curbside recycling and recyclable materials: See section 50-111. 
    Refuse: Every type of waste material which is not garbage and includes but is not limited to paper, ashes, cinders, cartons, construction debris, household appliances, furniture, furnishings and fixtures and all other material which is not subject to rapid decay or decomposition and which does not serve as breeding or feeding material for insects, rodents or other animals. 
    Toter cart: A toter cart is a wheeled container approved by the village having a capacity from 35 to 96 gallons constructed of a suitable gauge and material and with a tight-fitting cover so as to be capable of securely containing garbage, refuse, landscape waste, or recyclable materials. 
(Code 1975, § 13-1; Ord. No. O-80-30, § 2, 7-3-1980; Ord. No. O-89-40, § 2, 7-20-1989; Ord. No. O-90-39, § 1, 6-7-1990; Ord. No. O-93-39, §§ 1-3, 6-17-1993; Ord. No. O-02-54, §§ 1, 2, 12-5-2002) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 50-2-50-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DISPOSAL REQUIREMENTS AND PROHIBITIONS 

Sec. 50-31. - Requirements. 
    All garbage, refuse, recyclable materials and landscape waste located within the village shall be stored, contained and disposed of by each customer of each premise within the village in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Required number of garbage containers. Each customer in the village shall provide and at all times properly maintain a sufficient number of garbage containers for that customer's garbage. All garbage and refuse generated from such premises shall be deposited in a garbage container in or on such premises as soon as practicable. No customer shall be limited to any number of garbage containers; however, whenever the village manager deems it necessary to protect the public health, welfare and safety, he may require the owner of such premises to only use a bulk storage container. 
(2)  Maintenance of garbage containers. All garbage containers shall be kept clean, leakproof and disinfected as often as necessary so that they shall remain in a sanitary condition. Evidence of neglect of these requirements or of containers which do not meet the requirements hereof shall be determined by the village health inspector, and these containers will either be repaired or replaced by the customer of such premises. 
(3)  Location, inspection of containers. For any premises for which garbage and refuse disposal is contained by the use of garbage containers, it shall be the duty of the customer to place such garbage containers in the parkway at the curbline unless other arrangements have been made between such customer and the scavenger. Garbage containers and refuse shall not be set out earlier than 5:00 p.m. on the night before collection. All containers, refuse, construction debris, landscape waste or other material not collected shall be removed from the specified location within 24 hours after the scavenger has been present for the purpose of collection and disposal; and the scavenger's refusal to collect such garbage and/or refuse based upon the failure of any customer to pay a scavenger bill does not limit the requirements provided for herein. 
(4)  Drainage, wrapping, depositing of garbage. It shall be the duty of every customer to cause all garbage produced or present on each premise to be thoroughly drained of all surplus liquid, then securely wrapped, bagged or packed in a garbage container. 
(5)  Bundling, weight and location of refuse. Refuse may be placed in open garbage containers weighing not more than 70 pounds. 
a.  Tree branches for collection of the village public works department under the annual brush pickup program in April, July and October, and not including other landscape waste, may be placed in the parkway and not in a garbage container if such materials are cut up and no more than ten feet in length and not greater than eight inches in diameter. 
b.  Tree branches and brush for collection by the residential scavenger may be placed in the parkway and not in a garbage container if such materials are cut to lengths not to exceed 48 inches long with individual branches not exceeding 31/2 inches in diameter and bundled with natural fiber twine. Individual bundles shall not exceed 18 inches in diameter and [shall] have a landscape waste sticker attached thereto. 
c.  Furniture, furnishings, fixtures and appliance refuse which is/are too large to be placed in containers shall be placed next to garbage containers in an orderly fashion. 
(6)  Disposal by franchised scavenger. It shall be unlawful for any person other than franchised scavengers to collect, remove or dispose of garbage or refuse in the village. 
(7)  Regulation of refuse storage areas containing bulk storage containers. 
a.  All bulk storage containers shall be placed in refuse storage areas approved by the community development department which shall provide sufficient capacity and meet the requirements of this chapter. Residential buildings containing three or fewer dwelling units shall not use bulk storage containers. 
b.  All bulk containers shall be emptied not less than once each week, and all garbage and refuse shall be kept in closed or sealed bulk-storage containers at all times. 
c.  Refuse storage areas shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and without weeds. 
d.  Refuse storage areas shall be screened on three sides and have a slab of impervious material on which the bulk storage containers shall be stored. The three screening sides shall be solid walls not less than six foot in height or may include as one wall the exterior building wall. The bulk storage containers in the refuse storage areas shall not be visible from adjoining residential property. If the exterior building wall is used as a side wall, then one other wall shall be parallel and furthest from the exterior building wall. The exterior walls, other than the building wall, shall be constructed of concrete block, brick, or stone. Existing refuse storage walls, other than the building wall, damaged or destroyed more than 50 percent of its replacement cost shall only be reconstructed in compliance with this section. 
e.  Exception. The 16 multifamily six-dwelling unit buildings located at 2001 through 2161 Narcissus Avenue shall not be required to screen their bulk storage container as required in subsection (7)d of this section but shall meet the following additional requirements: 
1.  Each building shall have only one wheeled two-yard bulk storage container for its regular scavenger service which shall be located adjacent to the rear wall of the building not visible from Narcissus Avenue. 
2.  Each building shall have not less than twice-a-week collection and disposal of its bulk storage container. 
3.  The bulk storage container shall be maintained in good repair and the exterior in good condition with protective treatment. 
4.  The area around the bulk storage container shall be kept free from any accumulation of rubbish or garbage. 
(8)  Location regulation of garbage containers. No garbage container, except as provided in section 50-31(3), shall be located or stored in the front yard including that area between the building and front yard, or located or stored in the corner-side or side yard of any property including that area between the building and that yard unless screened from view from the street. 
(9)  Location regulation of refuse. No garbage, refuse, landscape waste except stacked firewood, rubbish or building materials except those necessary for the construction of improvements pursuant to a currently issued building permit shall be located or stored in the front, corner-side or side yard of any residentially zoned property including that area between the building and that yard. Stacked firewood shall not be located or stored in the front yard including that area between the building and the front yard of any residentially zoned property. 
(10)  Toter carts. It shall be unlawful to store outside a building on a single zoning lot or lot of record: 
a.  One or two toter carts not in compliance with the disposal requirements and regulations of garbage containers; or 
b.  Three or more toter carts not in compliance with the disposal requirements and regulations of bulk storage containers including screening from view. 
(Code 1975, § 13-2; Ord. No. O-80-30, § 2, 7-3-1980; Ord. No. O-87-42, § 2, 7-16-1987; Ord. No. O-90-39, § 1, 6-7-1990; Ord. No. O-92-47, § 1, 7-16-1992; Ord. No. O-93-39, § 4, 6-17-1993; Ord. No. O-94-06, §§ 1, 2, 3-3-1994; Ord. No. O-01-28, § 1, 6-21-2001; Ord. No. O-03-35, § 1, 9-4-2003; Ord. No. O-02-54, § 3, 12-5-2002) 
Sec. 50-32. - Prohibitions concerning accumulation, storage and disposal of garbage, refuse, recyclable materials or landscape waste. 
    The following are prohibited in connection with the accumulation, storage or disposal of garbage, refuse, recyclable materials or landscape waste within the village: 
(1)  Failure to comply with village regulations. No customer shall accumulate, store or dispose of garbage, refuse, recyclable materials or landscape waste in violation of this chapter or any other applicable provision of this Code. 
(2)  Mandatory service. Garbage, refuse and landscape waste collection and disposal and recycling services shall be provided by the residential scavenger and shall be mandatory for all those customers defined in section 50-61; and the customer shall pay the fees for such service as established by the president and board of trustees. 
(3)  Burning and burying prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to burn garbage, refuse or landscape waste within the village. It shall be unlawful for any person to bury garbage, refuse or landscape waste anywhere within the village or to permit the same to be placed or accumulated in any place or manner other than in a garbage container or a bulk storage container. 
(4)  Accumulation prohibited. It shall be unlawful for the customer and/or owner of any premises in the village to accumulate thereon litter, debris, scrap metal, refuse, garbage, nonoperable motor vehicles or parts thereof. It shall be unlawful for any person to accumulate any garbage, refuse or landscape waste on any premises except in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(5)  Littering on public or private property prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit garbage, refuse, landscape waste or recyclable materials or allow said materials to be deposited in or upon any private property or upon any public property except as provided for in this chapter. 
(6)  Depositing garbage or refuse containers on another's premises. Except where a bulk storage container is provided for the multiple occupants of one building, it shall be unlawful for any person to deposit his garbage, refuse, landscape waste or his garbage containers upon the property of another for the purpose of having such garbage, refuse or landscape waste picked up by a scavenger. 
(7)  Construction debris. It shall be unlawful for any residential scavenger customer to place for collection more than one garbage container of construction debris per collection day. 
(8)  Special collection items. It shall be unlawful for any residential scavenger customer to place for regular collection more than one garbage container of construction debris or bathtubs, counter tops, garage doors, large auto parts, large logs, and tree stumps in excess of six inches or 70 pounds in weight or swimming pools. All such items shall be collected by the residential scavenger as a special pickup upon payment of the rate for special pickup per cubic yard by the customer to the residential scavenger except in small amounts as provided in subsection (7). 
(9)  Landscape waste. It shall be unlawful for any customer to mix landscape waste with garbage or refuse for collection or disposal in a landfill and to place landscape waste for collection except in compliance with section 50-1 ("garbage container"). 
(10)  Moving waste from one location to another. It shall be unlawful for any person to move any garbage, refuse, landscape waste or construction debris from one location to another to evade the provisions of this chapter. 
(11)  Backyard composting areas. Landscape waste defined as grass, shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree limbs and other materials accumulated as the result of the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees may be placed in a backyard composting area for the purpose of creating compost. Garbage, refuse, animal waste or other materials that may attract animals or vermin to the backyard composting area or produce an obnoxious odor shall not be deposited on the compost pile. Composting areas shall only be located in rear yards; or for corner lots, the compost area may be located in the corner lot's side yard within 20 feet of the rear yard. Composting areas may be located in utility easements only if the composting area causes no disruptions to natural drainage and not within five feet of the side lot line. Composting areas located on a utility easement shall be placed there with the customer's understanding that any utility repairs causing damage or removal to the composting area shall be at the sole responsibility and cost of the customer and/or property owner. Composting areas shall be maintained so that no obnoxious odors are produced and shall be the sole responsibility of the customer and/or owner. Composting areas shall be constructed in a manner so the materials deposited on the compost pile will not be windblown or scatter to other premises. Composting areas shall be no greater than five feet in height and shall not have a maximum ground or base area of more than 100 square feet. All existing compost areas shall comply with these regulations regarding location and size on or before November 1, 1990. 
(12)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than the residential franchised scavenger to remove landscape waste stickers placed on garbage containers containing landscape waste intended for separate collection and disposal at a composting facility. 
(Code 1975, § 13-3; Ord. No. O-80-30, § 2, 7-3-1980; Ord. No. O-90-39, § 1, 6-7-1990; Ord. No. O-90-50, § 1, 7-19-1990; Ord. No. O-93-39, § 5, 6-17-1993) 
Secs. 50-33-50-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SCAVENGERS 

Sec. 50-61. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the terms used herein are defined as follows: 
    Commercial scavenger: A person, firm or corporation which has entered into a franchise contract with the village to collect, remove and dispose of garbage and refuse from each multifamily building, commercial or industrial establishment and recyclable materials from multifamily buildings that have curbside collection in the village except for those customers served by the residential scavenger. 
    Residential scavenger: A person, firm, or corporation which has entered into a franchise contract with the village to collect, remove, and dispose of garbage, refuse, and recyclable materials from all single-family dwelling units, duplexes, triplexes, the Church Street Station townhouses, the Fremont Junction Homeowners' Association, Hartford Square Homeowners' Association, Larkspur Homeowners' Association, Olde Salem Homeowners' Association, Rainbow Pointe Sacramento Homeowners' Association, Rainbow Pointe West Homeowners' Association, Savannah Subdivision, Tall Oaks Townhouses, and the Tanglewood Homeowners' Association. 
(Code 1975, § 13-5; Ord. No. O-90-39, § 3, 6-7-1990; Ord. No. O-93-39, § 6, 6-17-1993; Ord. No. O-04-17, § 1, 3-18-2004; Ord. No. O-04-63, § 1, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. O-07-05, § 1, 4-5-2007) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-62. - Limitation on the number of. 
    The village shall issue an exclusive franchise for a residential scavenger and an unlimited number of nonexclusive franchises for commercial scavenger for collection, recycling and disposal services in the village. 
(Code 1975, § 13-6; Ord. No. O-90-39, § 3, 6-7-1990) 
Sec. 50-63. - Franchise contract-Residential scavenger. 
    The residential scavenger shall enter into a franchise contract with the village based on the residential scavenger's experience in providing curbside scavenger and recycling services to those customers described in section 50-61, its equipment, employees, disposal sites and recycling facilities for such rates as provided in the franchise contract. 
(Code 1975, § 13-7; Ord. No. O-90-39, § 3, 6-7-1990) 
Sec. 50-64. - Same-Commercial scavenger. 
    The commercial scavenger shall enter into a franchise contract with the village with the terms and conditions as established by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1975, § 13-8; Ord. No. O-90-39, § 3, 6-7-1990) 
Sec. 50-65. - Commercial scavenger curbside recycling program requirements. 
(a)  All customers residing in multifamily buildings with curbside garbage and refuse collection service and served by a commercial scavenger as defined in section 50-61 shall have a curbside recycling program on or before November 1, 1990. 
(b)  The commercial scavenger shall offer a curbside recycling program similar to the program offered by the residential scavenger with the collection of the following recyclable materials: glass bottles and jars, aluminum cans, tin/steel/bi-metal cans, newspapers, all PETE #1 plastic containers, all #2 HDPE plastic containers, plastic bags, six- and 12-pack beverage rings, Kraft paper bags, magazines, catalogs and phone books. 
(c)  The commercial scavenger shall collect the recyclable materials on not less than a once-a-week basis on the same day as normal garbage collection. 
(d)  The commercial scavenger shall provide one recycling container of at least 14-gallon capacity to each customer in the service area. The commercial scavenger shall replace recycling containers that are lost or stolen. 
(e)  The commercial scavenger shall provide for the collection of recyclable materials with a separate vehicle. 
(f)  The commercial scavenger shall transport the recyclable materials collected to a processing facility approved by the village manager. 
(g)  The commercial scavenger shall submit a quarterly report to the village manager, including the number of dwelling units served and the volume by type and tons of recyclable materials collected. 
(Code 1975, § 13-9; Ord. No. O-90-39, § 3, 6-7-1990; Ord. No. O-93-39, §§ 7-10, 6-17-1993) 
Sec. 50-66. - Regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to collect, remove or dispose of garbage or refuse anywhere in the village from 7:00 p.m. until 7:00 a.m. the next day. 
(b)  No person shall operate a scavenger vehicle in the village unless that scavenger vehicle is covered by a liability insurance policy in accordance with the current franchise contract as a commercial or residential scavenger. 
(Ord. No. O-99-32, § 1, 6-17-1999) 
Secs. 50-67-50-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ENFORCEMENT LIENS 

Sec. 50-91. - Generally. 
(a)  When the owner of property refuses or neglects to remove garbage or refuse including construction debris or refuses or neglects to properly grade his property in compliance with the regulations of this Code, the village may take the following enforcement actions. 
(b)  The owner of the property or the person in whose name the general taxes for the last preceding year were paid shall be given reasonable notice of the above violation(s) and that failure to abate such violation shall result in the village's expenses to abate becoming a lien on the property. Notice shall not be less than three days for refuse violations, two days for garbage violations and 30 days for grading violations. 
(c)  If the owner does not abate the violation during the notice period, the village manager or his designee may proceed to abate such violation keeping an account of the expenses of the abatement which shall include an administrative fee of the greater of $25.00 or ten percent of the cost of abatement. All expenses, including interest at the rate of ten percent per year, shall be charged to and paid by such owner. 
(d)  The expenses for abatement shall become a lien upon the property effected superior to all subsequent liens and encumbrances except tax liens, if within one year after such removal expense is incurred, the village files notice of lien in the office of the recorder in the county in which such real estate is located.
