    No license or license fee shall be required for any vehicle used to deliver foodstuffs from any establishment which is licensed and inspected as a food store or food service establishment in the village or licensed by another municipality; but all provisions of this chapter, shall be complied with in connection with such vehicles. 
(Code 1975, § 16-116; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 2, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-243. - Regulations. 
(a)  Cleanliness. All vehicles delivering foodstuffs shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned each day after their use. 
(b)  Waste accumulations prohibited. It shall be unlawful to permit stale food, decaying matter or any other waste material or product to accumulate in or on any such vehicle. 
(c)  Carrying unwrapped foodstuffs. If unwrapped foodstuffs are transported in any such vehicle, such goods shall be carried in a portion or compartment of the vehicle which is screened and protected against dust and insects. 
(Code 1975, § 16-117; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 2, 10-18-1984) 
Secs. 58-244-58-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - AUTOMATIC FOOD VENDING MACHINES 

Sec. 58-251. - License required. 
    No person shall install, keep or maintain an automatic food vending machine in the village, or permit the installation, keeping, maintenance or use upon his premises of an automatic food vending machine, without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1975, § 16-120; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 2, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-252. - Adoption of regulations. 
    The greater standards (most restrictive standards) of the latest edition of the Rules and Regulations Pertaining to Sanitary Vending of Food and Beverages, as published by the Illinois Department of Public Health (Part 743 of 77 Illinois Administrative Code), published in pamphlet form, together with the following sections of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, 2005 Food Code, with such subsequent editions or amendments to either, are adopted as the regulations governing the sanitation procedures and controls for the storage, preparation and display of food sold within vending machines and food or beverage vending vehicle as the regulations of the village. 
    The sections of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, 2005 Food Code, referenced above are as follows: 
(1)  Vended potentially hazardous food. Potentially hazardous food dispensed through a vending machine shall be in the package in which it was placed at the food establishment or food processing plant at which it was prepared. 
Refrigerated, ready to eat, potentially hazardous food prepared in a food establishment and dispensed through a vending machine with an automatic shutoff control shall be discarded if it exceeds a temperature and time combination as specified in the food code. 
(2)  Condiments. Condiments at a vending machine location shall be in individual packages or provided in dispensers that are filled at an approved location, such as the food establishment that provides food to the vending machine location, a food processing plant that is regulated by the agency that has jurisdiction over the operation, or a properly equipped facility that is located on the site of the vending machine location. 
(3)  Vending machine, vending stage closure . The dispensing compartment of a vending machine including a machine that is designed to vend prepackaged snack food that is not potentially hazardous such as chips, party mixes, and pretzels shall be equipped with a self-closing door or cover if the machine is: 
a.  Located in an outside area that does not otherwise afford the protection of an enclosure against the rain, windblown debris, insects, rodents, and other contaminants that are present in the environment; or 
b.  Available for self-service during hours when it is not under the full-time supervision of a food employee. 
(4)  Can openers on vending machines. Cutting or piercing parts of can openers on vending machines shall be protected from manual contact, dust, insects, rodents, and other contamination. 
(5)  Vending machines, automatic shut-off. 
a.  A machine vending potentially hazardous food shall have an automatic control that prevents the machine from vending food: 
1.  If there is a power failure, mechanical failure, or other condition that results in an internal machine temperature that cannot maintain food temperature as specified in the food code. 
2.  If a condition specified under subsection (5)a.1. of this section occurs, until the machine is serviced and restocked with food that has been maintained at temperatures in the food code. 
b.  When the automatic shut off within a machine vending potentially hazardous food is activated: 
1.  In a refrigerated vending machine, the ambient temperature may not exceed any time/temperature as specified in the food code. 
2.  In a hot holding vending machine, the ambient temperature may not be less than 135 degrees F for more than 120 minutes immediately after the machine is filled, serviced, or restocked. 
(6)  Vending machines, liquid waste products. 
a.  Vending machines designed to store beverages that are packaged in containers made from paper products shall be equipped with diversion devices and retention pans or drains for container leakage. 
b.  Vending machines that dispense liquid food in bulk shall be: 
1.  Provided with an internally mounted waste receptacle for the collection of drip, spillage, overflow, or other internal wastes; and 
2.  Equipped with an automatic shutoff device that will place the machine out of operation before the waste receptacle overflows. 
c.  Shutoff devices specified under subsection (6)b.2. of this section shall prevent water or liquid food from continuously running if there is a failure of a flow control device in the water or liquid food system or waste accumulation that could lead to overflow of the waste receptacle. 
(7)  Vending machine doors and openings. 
a.  Vending machine doors and access opening covers to food and container storage spaces shall be tight-fitting. 
b.  Vending machine service connection openings through an exterior wall of a machine shall be closed by sealants, clamps, or grommets so that the openings are no larger than 1/16 of an inch. 
(8)  Outdoor food vending areas, overhead protection. Except for machines that vend canned beverages, if located outside, a machine used to vend food shall be provided with overhead protection. 
(Code 1975, § 16-121; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 2, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-95-84, § 5, 12-8-1995; Ord. No. O-13-07, § 1, 2-21-2013) 
Sec. 58-253. - Machine maintenance. 
    There shall be posted in a conspicuous place on each machine the name, address and telephone number of the person responsible for the maintenance of such machine. 
(Code 1975, § 16-122; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 2, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-254. - Unwholesome food. 
    No licensee shall offer for sale, or keep for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for human consumption which is spoiled, tainted or unwholesome and unfit for human consumption for any reason, or violate any rule or regulation as provided in the sanitary vending of food and beverages rules and regulations as adopted in section 58-252. 
(Code 1975, § 16-123; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 2, 10-18-1984) 
Secs. 58-255-58-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - FOOD OR BEVERAGE VENDING VEHICLES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 62. 

Sec. 58-271. - Definitions. 
(a)  Food or beverage vending vehicle: A vehicle from which the retail sale of food or beverage for human consumption is conducted on private property. 
(b)  Owner: The title holder of a food or beverage vending vehicle. 
(c)  Vending: The act of selling, or offering to sell, any food or beverage, for human consumption from a food or beverage vending vehicle on private property. 
(d)  Reserved. 
(e)  Retail sale: The sale of food or beverage to the consumer thereof. 
(f)  Vehicle: Every motor vehicle which is mechanically propelled and designed to transport one or more persons. 
(g)  Vendor: Any person who physically operates a food or beverage vending vehicle or any person who physically conducts vending from such a vehicle. 
(Code 1975, § 16-130; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 2, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-95-84, § 2, 12-8-1995; Ord. No. O-13-07, § 1, 2-21-2013) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-272. - Food vending vehicle equipment. 
    All food or vending vehicles shall have the following equipment: 
(1)  A litter or trash container, visible and available to customers of the vending vehicle. In addition thereto, each licensee shall clean up any debris or litter which may occur as a result of the vendor's business prior to leaving any given area of sale. 
(2)  Equipment that will keep all potentially hazardous food on the vehicle at a temperature below 41 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(3)  If providing hot potentially hazardous foods, equipment that will keep all such foods at 135 degrees Fahrenheit or above. 
(Code 1975, § 16-131; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 2, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-95-84, § 4, 12-8-1995; Ord. No. O-13-07, § 1, 2-21-2013) 
Sec. 58-273. - Prohibitions on conducting the business of vending from a vehicle. 
    The following shall not be performed from a vending vehicle: 
(1)  Vending from a vehicle on a public roadway. 
(2)  Emitting any noise intended to advertise the presence of the vehicle, while it is moving. 
(3)  Vending before 10:00 a.m., or after sunset on any day. 
(Code 1975, § 16-132; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 2, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-94-26, §§ 5, 6, 6-2-1994; Ord. No. O-95-84, § 3, 12-8-1995; Ord. No. O-13-07, § 1, 2-21-2013) 
Sec. 58-274. - Operators or vendors not to be afflicted with or carrier of infection or contagious disease. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or who is the carrier of any infections or contagious disease to conduct vending. 
(Code 1975, § 16-133; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 2, 10-18-1984) 
Secs. 58-275-58-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ANTIQUE DEALERS, CANVASSERS, PAWNBROKERS AND DEALERS IN SECONDHAND ARTICLES[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate secondhand and junk stores, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 

Sec. 58-301. - Definitions. 
(a)  Canvasser: Any person who shall canvass for the purpose of buying any junk or any other like commodity for any junk dealers or for sale to such junk dealer or to another. 
(b)  Dealer: Any person, firm partnership, corporation, and any principal, employee, agent or servant thereof, regularly engaged for 30 days or more from one location in or conducting business for the purchase, sale, barter, exchange or the pawn of junk, antiques, secondhand articles, coins, gold, silver, platinum, gems and semiprecious stones. 
(c)  Engages in or conducting business: The purchase, sale, barter or exchange of any item of property defined in (a) and (b) above, including the advertising therefor and including such business conducted by an established dealer in a permanent location and including any temporary, transient or itinerant business. 
(d)  Itinerant dealer: Any dealer as defined herein who engages in any temporary or transient business conducted in a shop, room, hotel room or other premises rented for any duration of one to 30 consecutive days or used on a temporary basis. 
(e)  Pawnbroker: Any person who shall in any manner lend or advance money or other valuable things, other than securities or written evidence of indebtedness, or who deals in the purchasing of personal property or other valuable things on condition of selling the same back to the seller at a stipulated price. 
(f)  Secondhand articles: Any item of personal property or object of value, previously owned or used, which is not purchased or sold as new. Secondhand articles do not include property purchased by one licensed, established merchant from another within or without the village in the normal course of business. 
(g)  General sales dealer: Any dealer who conducts business in any secondhand article. 
(h)  Limited sales dealer : 
(1)  Any dealer who does not conduct business in the following secondhand articles including but not limited to jewelry coins, precious metals, gold, silver, platinum, gems, semiprecious gems, electronic equipment, radios, televisions, video or audio receivers, or appliances. 
(2)  A limited sales dealer shall be required to provide evidence acceptable to the village clerk that it is complying with the restrictions of a limited sales dealer. 
(Code 1975, § 16-139; Ord. No. O-82-48, § 2, 7-1-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 4, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-84-68, § 1, 12-20-1984; Ord. No. O-86-02, § 1, 1-2-1986; Ord. No. O-90-41, § 3, 6-7-1990; Ord. No. O-11-08, § 1, 5-5-2011) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-302. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any persons to engage in any activity subject to regulation by this article without first obtaining a permit as specified herein. Such permit shall be added to any required business license. 
(Code 1975, § 16-140; Ord. No. O-82-48, § 2, 7-1-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 4, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-303. - Application for permit. 
    Applicants for a permit under this article, whether a person, firm or corporation, shall file a written, sworn application on a form provided by the village clerk, signed by the applicant if an individual, by all partners if a partnership and by the president if a corporation, with the village clerk showing: 
(1)  The name or names of the principals, agents, and employees of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the village; the local address or addresses of such person or persons while engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such person or persons; the capacity in which such person or persons will act (as proprietor, agent, employee or otherwise); the name and address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will be carried on if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state it is incorporated. 
(2)  The fingerprints of the principals, agents and employees of pawnbrokers and dealers. 
(3)  Evidence provided by the applicant to the satisfaction of the chief of police that: 
a.  The applicant has not been convicted of receiving stolen goods, burglary, robbery, or any felony in the federal or state courts, within the five years immediately preceding filing the application; 
b.  No fraud, misrepresentation or false statement of material or relevant facts is contained in the application submitted by the applicant; or 
c.  The applicant has not engaged in a fraudulent transaction or enterprise within the five years immediately preceding filing the application. 
(4)  The place or places in the village where it is proposed to carry on the applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that said business shall be conducted. 
(5)  The place or places, including any other permanent place of business of the applicant, where the applicant within the six months next preceding the date of said application conducted an activity subject to the regulations hereof, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office, street address, and town, village, or city of any building or office in which said business was conducted. 
(6)  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers. 
(7)  Whether or not the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business have been convicted within the last five years of a felony, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal or state law, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor. 
(8)  Credentials from the person, firm or corporation for which the applicant proposes to do business, authority for the applicant to act as such representative. 
(9)  Such other information as to the identity or character of the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the chief of police may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public good. 
(10)  The application shall state thereon that "It is unlawful for any person to make a false statement on this application." Any false statement made on the application form will void the application and constitute a misdemeanor punishable as provided by law. 
(Code 1975, § 16-139; Ord. No. O-82-48, § 2, 7-1-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 4, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-84-68, § 1, 12-20-1984; Ord. No. O-86-02, § 1, 1-2-1986; Ord. No. O-90-41, § 3, 6-7-1990; Ord. No. O-11-08, § 2, 5-5-2011) 
Sec. 58-304. - Issuance of permit. 
    The village clerk shall, within 30 days following the date of the filing of the application, issue the applicant a permit hereunder provided that the chief of police has first given his written report that the applicant has qualified for said permit. 
(Code 1975, § 16-143; Ord. No. O-82-48, § 2, 7-1-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, §§ 3, 4, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-305. - Record of transactions. 
    Every pawnbroker, dealer and itinerant dealer for each secondhand article received or transferred shall enter into a computerized recordkeeping system approved and designated by the chief of police in the English language, at the time of each transaction within the village in the course of his business, an accurate account of each transaction except as to the sale of garbage or refuse. The record shall set forth a digital photograph as well as an accurate description of the goods, articles or things purchased, including the manufacturer, model, serial number and any such number or marking that is engraved, etched or written upon the property bartered, exchanged or received, the name, residence, driver's license number and description of the person selling, bartering or exchanging the same and the permit number if the goods can be purchased, sold, bartered or exchanged only under a permit issued by the village clerk. The description of the person required by this section shall consist of the hair color, sex, approximate height, weight, date of birth and any distinguishing features of such person. Such computerized recordkeeping system and property received shall at all reasonable times be available at such dealer's place of business and shall be open to the inspection of any police officer of the village. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to exhibit to any police officer of the village any record required to be kept pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1975, § 16-144; Ord. No. O-82-48, § 2, 7-1-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 4, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-90-41, § 2, 6-7-1990; Ord. No. O-11-08, §§ 3, 4, 5-5-2011) 
Sec. 58-306. - Reports to police. 
    Every pawnbroker and/or dealer shall provide to the chief of police, via the computerized recordkeeping system approved and designated by the chief of police, a legible and accurate description of every article or thing required to be entered in the computerized recordkeeping system provided for under the preceding section. Computerized recordkeeping entries containing all required information shall be received by the chief of police within the same business day of purchase, barter, or exchange of each item. Each entry shall include a description of the person selling, bartering, exchanging or receiving the same including the hair color, sex, approximate height, weight, date of birth, driver's license number and any distinguishing features, together with a digital photograph as well as an accurate description of the goods, articles or things purchased, including the manufacturer, model, serial number and any such number or marking that is engraved, etched or written upon the property bartered, exchanged or received. 
(Code 1975, § 16-145; Ord. No. O-82-48, § 2, 7-1-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 4, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-11-08, §§ 3, 4, 5-5-2011) 
Sec. 58-307. - Inspection of premises. 
    Every pawnbroker and/or dealer shall admit to his premises at any reasonable time any police officer to examine his computerized recordkeeping system user interface as well as articles purchased or received which are within such premises. 
(Code 1975, § 16-146; Ord. No. O-82-48, § 2, 7-1-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 4, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-11-08, §§ 3, 4, 5-5-2011) 
Sec. 58-308. - Articles to be retained. 
    No pawnbroker or dealer shall sell, melt, change the form of, or dispose of any article received by him, of which he is required to make record and report under this article, within seven days after taking possession of such article or within seven days of entering the required information into the designated computerized recordkeeping system. All such articles shall be retained in his possession at the location specified in the permit required herein during the seven-day period. 
(Code 1975, § 16-147; Ord. No. O-82-48, § 2, 7-1-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 4, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-11-08, §§ 3, 4, 5-5-2011) 
Sec. 58-309. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No pawnbroker or dealer shall have in his place of business or in his possession, or shall have acquired and resold, bartered or exchanged, any article which is proved to have been stolen, the account and report of which he has not kept and reported as herein prescribed. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker and/or dealer in the course of his business or occupation to acquire, by purchase, barter, exchange or otherwise, any goods from any person under 18 years of age. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker and/or dealer to acquire, by purchase, barter, exchange or otherwise, goods bearing evidence of a serial number which has been tampered with or scratched or obliterated in any manner unless such person immediately contacts the police department of the village. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker and/or dealer to accept, buy or exchange any articles prior to examining the identifying credentials of the person pawning, selling or exchanging said articles. 
(Code 1975, § 16-148; Ord. No. O-82-48, § 2, 7-1-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 4, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-11-08, §§ 3, 4, 5-5-2011) 
Secs. 58-310-58-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - AUTOMATIC DRY CLEANING MACHINES[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate laundries, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8; Drycleaner Environmental Response Trust Fund, 415 ILCS 135/1 et seq. 

Sec. 58-331. - Definition. 
    An "automatic dry cleaning machine," as the term is used in this article, shall be construed to include and mean any device or apparatus for the cleaning of clothes or fabrics, and designed to be used or operated by any but the owner, or an employee of the owner thereof, which machine or device makes use of or contains perchloroethylene or any other chemical solvent or substance which may cause harm to human beings by reason of inhalation or contact. 
(Code 1963, § 24.802; Code 1975, § 16-149; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 5, 10-18-1984) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-332. - Installation regulations. 
(a)  Enclosure. Each machine covered by this article shall be completely encased by a cabinet and shall be vented with intake at the top and the outlet at or near the bottom of such machine. Groups of machines may be entirely enclosed or supported on all open sides by an enclosure topped with a hood vented as provided for each individual machine. 
(b)  Minimum exhaust flow. The exhaust system must maintain a minimum flow of 100 cubic feet per minute face velocity through the loading door whenever the door is open. 
(c)  Discharging stack. The discharging stack for the machines and for the room in which the machines are located shall extend at least two feet above the level of any window which can be opened, located within 50 feet of the outlet of the stack, and shall be at least 50 feet away from any fresh air intake leading to any premises. 
(d)  Locking device. The machines must be so constructed as to prevent the loading door from being opened during the normal cycle of operation. Each machine shall be equipped with a transparent door or port to allow visual examination of the status of the cleaning cycle. 
(e)  Water system connections. Any connection of such machine with the water supply system must be equipped with an air gap or vacuum breaker in the line upstream from the consider with no control valves downstream from such gap or breaker. Wastewater shall be discharged through an air gap. 
(f)  Room ventilation. The room in which such machine is installed shall be ventilated so that there shall be a minimum flow of air per machine from the area to which the public is admitted of at least 500 cubic feet per machine per minute in a room where there are no more than three machines installed; 400 cubic feet per minute where there are no more than eight machines installed; 375 cubic feet per minute where there are no more than 16 machines installed; and 360 cubic feet per minute where there are more than 17 machines installed. For this purpose, each cleaning cell shall be considered as one machine. 
(g)  Leakage prevention. Each machine must be so designed and constructed as to prevent the leakage of liquids, gas or vapors. 
(Code 1963, § 24.804; Code 1975, § 16-150; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 5, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-333. - Operation regulations. 
(a)  To be in good condition. No automatic dry cleaning machine shall be operated unless all the equipment described in section 58-332 is properly installed and in good operating working condition. 
(b)  Attendant. No establishment for which a license is required under this article shall be open for business, and it shall be unlawful to admit the public or customers into the room where such machines are located unless there is on duty in the establishment at all times a competent person in charge of the establishment and in charge of the operation of such machines. 
(c)  Warning signs. There shall be warning signs posted in places of each observation warning of the dangers in the event leakage of liquids, gas or vapor occurs. 
(d)  Disposal of residue-containing solvent. It shall be unlawful to permit any residue-containing solvent to flow into the sewer system of the village; tightly covered metal containers may be used for temporary storage of such waste outside the building. Such containers shall bear labels indicating the contents and dangers involved in handling and shall be locked if in an unenclosed place. 
(e)  Information to be posted. At least one legible sign shall be maintained in a place available to customers giving the name, address and telephone number of the owner of the establishment and of the service department or agency responsible for the proper maintenance of the machines. 
(Code 1963, § 24.805; Code 1975, § 16-151; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 5, 10-18-1984) 
Secs. 58-334-58-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BUS SERVICES 

Sec. 58-351. - Definitions. 
    Words or phrases as used in this article shall be defined as provided in the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1975, § 16-152; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-352. - License required; exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of operating a scheduled bus service for the transportation of persons within the corporate limits of the village without first having secured a license therefor. 
    Notwithstanding any language contained in this section to the contrary, no license shall be required for the following: 
(a)  The business of operating a scheduled school bus service within the corporate limits of the village; 
(b)  The business of operating a scheduled bus service for the transportation of persons within the corporate limits of the village, where such bus service is otherwise being regulated by the Illinois Commerce Commission and/or the Interstate Commerce Commission. 
(Code 1975, § 16-153; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-353. - Applications for licenses. 
    Applications for all licenses to operate a bus service for the transportation of persons shall be made in writing to the village clerk. Each application shall contain: 
(a)  Name and address of applicant. 
(1)  If applicant is a partnership, list names and addresses of all partners. 
(2)  If applicant is a corporation, give the names and addresses of the registered agent and all officers, directors and stockholders of more than ten percent of the stock. 
(3)  If applicant is a wholly owned subsidiary of another partnership or corporation, give the information listed in either (1) or (2) for the parent partnership or corporation. 
(b)  A list of the names and addresses of all governmental units and all agencies or authorities organized thereunder that license and/or franchise the applicant for the operation of a bus service for the transportation of persons. 
(c)  A brief summary of the qualifications the applicant feels qualify him for a license to operate a bus service for the transportation of persons. 
(d)  A copy of the applicant's most recent financial statements, including but not limited to: Balance sheet, profit and loss statement and statement of changes in financial condition, for the most recent fiscal year available. 
(e)  A listing of fares, routes, schedules and the location of all proposed boarding locations and stops under which the applicant proposes to operate. 
(f)  A list of the type of equipment which the applicant proposes to utilize during the term of the license, which shall consist of such full and complete description or information as the clerk may require, and the certificate of safety for each vehicle as required in section 5/13-101 of chapter 625 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes (625 ILCS 5/13-101), as amended. 
    Each application shall contain such additional information as may be needed for the proper guidance of the village officials in the issuing of the license. All applications shall be signed by the applicant or its duly authorized representative and verified by oath or affidavit. 
(Code 1975, § 16-154; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-354. - Fee period. 
    The annual fee, payable in advance, for such licenses shall be $100.00 plus $50.00 for each bus operated. Whenever the number of buses so operated shall be increased during the license year, the licensee shall notify the clerk of such change and shall pay the additional fee, prorated for the balance of the license year. 
    Such fee shall be in lieu of any other vehicle fee required by this Code including parking fees for parking in the Municipal Commuter Parking Lot. The village clerk shall issue suitable tags or stickers for the number of buses covered by each license. Such tag or sticker shall be displayed in the right front windshield on each bus while it is in use. 
    The licensee shall notify the clerk of the motor number and state license number of each bus operated and of the corresponding village tag or sticker number. 
(Code 1975, § 16-155; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-355. - Investigations. 
    Upon the receipt of an application for a license to engage in the business of operating a bus service for the transportation of persons the village manager or his designated representative may cause such investigation or inspections to be made in conformance with article I, as the village manager or his designated representative shall deem necessary or appropriate. 
(Code 1975, § 16-156; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-356. - Issuance of license. 
    All licenses shall be issued in conformance with article I of this chapter. 
(Code 1975, § 16-157; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-357. - Routes. 
(a)  The issuance of a license shall be deemed to be approval of those routes specified in the application for license. Upon the issuance of a license under this article, the licensee shall file with the village clerk a map or diagram showing the routes served. Each street, road or highway shall be identified and any public transportation service within two miles of the route(s) shall be shown or mentioned. 
(b)  Should any licensee desire to make any changes in its routes, the licensee shall first submit a revised route plan to the village board and receive its approval prior to placing said revised route plan into effect. Residents, carriers or other operators and interested individuals shall be given an opportunity to voice approval or objections to the proposed route change. 
(Code 1975, § 16-158; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-358. - Location of stops. 
    The location of all bus stops shall be subject to regulation and approval by the village manager or his designated representative. 
(Code 1975, § 16-159; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-359. - Regulation of operators. 
    No person shall operate any bus unless such person has a valid license with a proper classification to permit the operation of such vehicle. 
(Code 1975, § 16-160; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-360. - Traffic regulations. 
    Unless otherwise provided by the village, operations conducted under the provisions of this article shall be exempt from compliance with village vehicle or axle weight restrictions on village streets. However, each licensee shall observe all speed restrictions and other traffic regulations imposed by the village, within the village. 
(Code 1975, § 16-161; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-361. - Maintenance of public ways. 
    The village reserves the right to maintain the streets, alleys, public ways and facilities located within its corporate limits in such a manner as the village shall, in its exclusive discretion, determine. The village shall not be liable to any licensee for any interruption in service or for interference with the operation of any licensee's bus transportation system arising in any manner, directly or indirectly, out of the use or maintenance by the village of the streets, alleys, public ways and facilities located within the corporate limits of the village. 
(Code 1975, § 16-162; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-362. - Emergency route changes. 
(a)  In extraordinary circumstances and on a temporary basis, a licensee may deviate from its authorized routes without formal approval of a route change. Deviations, however, shall be limited to: 
(1)  A temporary closing of a road by virtue of construction, paving or weather conditions. 
(2)  The temporary establishment of one-way traffic on any road. 
(b)  In the event of a temporary deviation of a route, a licensee shall make every effort to notify passengers of the change and to resume the regular route operations at the earliest practicable moment. 
(c)  Whenever any licensee has cause to believe that any temporary route change will become permanent, the licensee shall apply for a permanent route change as specified in section 58-357. 
(Code 1975, § 16-163; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-363. - Insurance. 
    Any licensee operating a bus transportation service under this article shall indemnify, protect and save harmless the village, its officers, employees and agents, from and against liability, losses, physical damage to property, and bodily injury or death to persons, including payments made under any workmen's compensation law, which may arise out of the licensee's operation of its bus transportation service within or without the limits of the village. Each licensee shall further indemnify and hold harmless the village from and against any liability or losses sustained as a direct or indirect result of the action of the licensee's agents or employees or in any way arising out of the granting of this license. Each licensee shall carry insurance in an insurance company approved by the village, said insurance company having a Best Reporting Service rating of "AAA" or better, said insurance to be utilized to protect the licensee and the village as their interest may appear from and against all claims, demands, actions, judgments, costs, expenses and liabilities including without limitation attorney's fees which may arise or result directly or indirectly from or by reason of any such liability, loss, injury or damage. In addition, each licensee shall secure said indemnity by obtaining contract insurance. Said insurance policy shall be in sufficient funds to insure licensee and the village and in any event, said insurance shall be sufficient to insure against liability to persons and property (including insurance against personal injury, loss of life, and loss of or destruction of property) in the case of each vehicle operated by a licensee or used in providing the services in an amount not less than $500,000.00 per person; $1,000,000.00 per occurrence; and umbrella liability insurance coverage of not less than $2,000,000.00. Said policy shall contain a provision requiring the insured to notify the village not less than ten days prior to cancellation or change of any policy. The village, its officers, officials, agents and employees shall appear as additional named insureds under each policy. Within ten days after the date thereof, licensee shall provide the village with certificates of an insurance for each policy. Each licensee shall also carry such insurance as may be necessary to protect it and the village from all claims under the workmen's compensation laws in effect that may be applicable to the licensee. All insurance required by this article shall be and remain in full force and effect for the entire period of this article. The policies of insurance, or a certified copy or copies thereof, shall be approved by the village attorney of the village and shall be deposited with and kept on file by the village clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 16-164; Ord. No. O-81-62, § 1, 9-17-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 6, 10-18-1984) 
Secs. 58-364-58-380. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - CANVASSERS AND SOLICITORS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, adopted Mar. 18, 2004, amended article IX in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article IX, §§ 58-381-58-396, pertained to canvassers and solicitors. For complete derivation, see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of hawkers and peddlers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5; Solicitation for Charity Act, 225 ILCS 460/0.01 et seq.; Transient Merchant Act, 225 ILCS 465/1 et seq. 

Sec. 58-381. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this article to protect against criminal activity, including fraud and burglary, minimize the unwelcome disturbance of residents and the disruption of privacy, and to otherwise preserve the public health, safety, and welfare by regulating, controlling, and licensing door-to-door solicitors and peddlers. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-382. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases and their derivations, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Canvasser means any person who attempts to make personal contact with a resident at his/her residence without prior specific invitation or appointment from the resident, for the primary purpose of (1) attempting to enlist support for or against a particular religion, philosophy, ideology, political party, issue, or candidate, even if incidental to such purpose the canvasser accepts the donation of money for or against such cause, or (2) distributing a handbill or flyer advertising a noncommercial event or service. 
(2)  Charitable means and includes the words patriotic, philanthropic, social service, health, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic, cultural, or fraternal, either actual or purported. 
(3)  Contributions means and includes the words alms, money, subscription, property, or any donations under the guise of loan or money or property. 
(4)  Peddler means any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence in the village, not having been invited by the occupant thereof, carrying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, or personal property of any nature and offering the same for sale. This definition also includes any person who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as part of the scheme to evade the provisions of this article. Peddler does NOT include a person who distributes handbills or flyers for a commercial purpose, advertising an event, activity, good, or service that is offered to a resident for purchase at a location away from his/her residence or at a time different from the time of visit. 
(5)  Peddling includes all activities ordinarily performed by a peddler as indicated under paragraph (4) of this section. 
(6)  Person means a natural person or any firm, corporation, association, club, society, or other organization. 
(7)  Solicitor means any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence in the village, not having been invited by the occupant thereof, for the purpose taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, merchandise, wares, or other personal property of any nature for future delivery, or for services to be performed in the future. This definition also includes any person who, without invitation, goes upon private property, to request contribution of funds or anything of value, or sell goods or services for political, charitable, religious, or other noncommercial purposes. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-383. - Permit requirements and exemptions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person 18 years of age or older to engage in peddling or solicitation activities within the village without first obtaining a permit issued by the village clerk; provided, however, that the following are exempted from the provisions of this section. 
(1)  Any solicitation made upon premises owned or occupied by an organization upon whose behalf the solicitation is made; 
(2)  Any communication by an organization soliciting contributions solely from persons who are members of the organization at the time of such solicitation; 
(3)  Any solicitation in the form of a collection at a regular meeting, assembly, or service of a charitable person; or 
(4)  Any solicitation for the relief of any individual specified by name at the time of the solicitation where the solicitor represents in each case that the entire amount collected shall be turned over to the named beneficiary. 
(5)  A "canvasser" as defined in section 58-382. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-384. - Permit for sponsoring juvenile peddlers. 
(a)  No person under the age of 18 shall be permitted to engage in peddling except as provided in this section. 
(b)  A permit shall be obtained by a sponsoring person, company, or organization for the conduct of any peddling or solicitation activities involving, in whole or in part, a sales force of one (1) or more persons under 18 years of age. 
(c)  The sponsor shall be responsible for supervising and controlling the conduct of all persons, including juveniles, peddling under the sponsor's permit. 
(d)  The sponsor shall provide to each individual in its sales force a badge or other easily-readable form of identification which identifies the name of the sponsor and the name of the individual. The sponsor shall require all individuals in its sales force to wear such identification so that it is clearly visible at all times when the individuals are peddling or soliciting. 
(e)  The sponsor shall comply with the requirements of the State of Illinois Child Labor Law (820 ILCS 205/1 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-385. - Permit application. 
    Every person subject to the provisions of this article shall file with the village clerk an application in writing on a form to be furnished by the village, which shall provide the following information: 
(1)  Proof of age, address, and identification of the applicant including social security number, to be provided through the applicant's driver's license, articles of incorporation (for sponsors), or another legally-recognized form of identification and make and license number of the applicant's motor vehicles used during the peddling or solicitation activities. 
(2)  A brief description of the business or activity to be conducted; 
(3)  The dates, hours, and location for which the right to peddle or solicit is desired; 
(4)  If employed, the name, address, and telephone number of the employer; or if acting as an agent, the name, address, and telephone number of the principal who is being represented, with credentials in written form establishing the relationship and the authority of the employee or agent to act for the employer or principal, as the case may be; 
(5)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony, misdemeanor, or ordinance violation (other than traffic violations), the nature of the offense or violation, the penalty or punishment imposed, the date when and place where such offense occurred, and other pertinent details thereof; 
(6)  Proof of possession of any license or permit which, under federal, state, or local laws or regulations, the applicant is required to have in order to conduct the proposed businesses, or which, under any such law or regulation, would exempt the applicant from the licensing requirements of this article; and 
(7)  Two photographs of the applicant which shall have been taken within 60 days immediately prior to the date of filing of the application. The photographs shall show the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-386. - Fees. 
    At the time the application is filed with the village clerk, the applicant shall pay a fee to cover the cost to the village of processing the application and investigating the facts stated therein. The permit fee shall be $25.00 for each solicitor or peddler. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004; Ord. No. O-13-06, § 8, 1-24-2013) 
Sec. 58-387. - Application review and permit issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application, the village clerk, or authorized representative, shall review the application as deemed necessary to ensure the protection of the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
(b)  If the village clerk finds the application to be satisfactory, the village clerk shall endorse his approval on the application and shall, upon payment of the prescribed fee, deliver the required permit to the applicant. 
(c)  The permit shall show the name, address, and photograph of the permittee, the class of permit issued, the kind of goods or services to be sold or delivered, the date of issuance, and the length of time that the permit shall be in effect. The permit shall also show the permit number and identifying description of any vehicle to be used in carrying on the business for which the permit is issued. 
(d)  A record of all permits issued shall be maintained by the village clerk for a period of two years. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-388. - Denial of permit. 
(a)  Upon the village clerk's review of the application, the village clerk may refuse to issue a permit to the applicant under this article for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The location and time of solicitation or peddling would endanger the safety and welfare of the solicitors, peddlers, or their customers; 
(2)  An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application; 
(3)  The applicant has been convicted of a felony or class A misdemeanor, the nature of which is related to the applicant's fitness to engage in door-to-door activities under this article. The applicant shall be of good character and reputation without a conviction related to fraud, dishonesty, deceit, misrepresentation, sexual misconduct, trafficking in controlled substances, violent acts against persons or property, or offense involving moral turpitude. 
(4)  In reviewing fitness under subsection (a)(3) of this section, the following shall be considered: 
a.  The extent and nature of the applicant's past criminal activity; 
b.  The age of the applicant at the time of the commission of the crime; 
c.  The amount of time that has elapsed since the applicant's last criminal activity; 
d.  The conduct and work activity of the applicant prior to and following the criminal activity; 
e.  Evidence of the applicant's rehabilitation or rehabilitative effort while incarcerated or following release; and 
f.  Other evidence of the applicant's present fitness. 
(5)  There is no proof as to the authority of the applicant to serve as an agent to the principal; or 
(6)  The applicant has been denied a permit under this chapter within the immediate past year, unless the applicant can and does show to the satisfaction of the village clerk that the reasons for such earlier denial no longer exist. 
(b)  The village clerk's disapproval and the reasons for disapproval shall be noted on the application, and the applicant shall be notified that his application is disapproved and that no permit will be issued. Notice shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the application form, or at the applicant's last known address. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004; Ord. No. O-07-21, § 1, 8-2-2007) 
Sec. 58-389. - Permit expiration. 
    All permits issued under the provisions of this article shall expire 60 days from the date of issuance, unless an earlier expiration date is noted on the permit. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-390. - Identification badges. 
(a)  At the same time the permit is issued, the village clerk shall issue to each permittee a badge, which shall be worn by the permittee in such a way as to be conspicuous at all times while the permittee is soliciting or peddling in the village. 
(b)  A canvasser, otherwise exempt from the provisions of this article, may request the issuance of an identification badge from the village for the purpose of assuring village residents of the canvasser's good faith. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-391. - Permit exhibition. 
    Every person required to obtain a permit under the provisions of this article shall exhibit the permit when requested to do so by any prospective customer or police department employee. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-392. - Transfer prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than the permittee to use or wear any permit or badge issued under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-393. - Entry upon premises unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, whether licensed or unlicensed, while conducting the business of a canvasser, peddler, or solicitor, to enter upon any residential premises in the village where the owner, occupant, or person legally in charge of the premises has: 
(1)  Posted, at the entry to the premises, or at the entry to the principal building on the premises, a sign bearing the words "No Peddlers," "No Solicitors," or words of similar import; or 
(2)  Filed a "No Solicitation Registration Form" with the village on a form furnished by the village for that purpose. The village will maintain a "No Solicitation" list of those persons who wish to restrict solicitation on their property by canvassers, peddlers, and solicitors. The "No Solicitation" list shall be a public document, and a copy of the list shall be provided to each recipient of a permit to engage in solicitation. If a canvasser chooses not to apply for an identification card, it will be the responsibility of that canvasser to obtain a copy of the "No Solicitation" list. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-394. - Hours of solicitation. 
    No person, while conducting the activities of a peddler or solicitor, whether licensed or unlicensed shall enter upon any private property, knock on doors, or otherwise disturb persons in their residences between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-395. - Permit revocation. 
    Any permit issued under this article may be revoked or suspended, after notice and hearing, for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for a permit; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made by the permittee in the course of conducting solicitation or peddling activities; 
(3)  Conducting peddling or solicitation activities contrary to the provisions contained in the permit; 
(4)  Conviction for any crime involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting peddling or solicitation activities in such a manner as to create a public nuisance, constitute a breach of the peace, or endanger the health, safety, or general welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-396. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by the action or decision of the village clerk to deny, suspend, or revoke a permit applied for under the provisions of this article shall have the right to appeal such action or decision to the village president within 15 days after the notice of the action or decision has been mailed to the person's address as shown on the permit application form, or to his last known address. 
(b)  An appeal shall be taken by filing with the village clerk a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal. 
(c)  The village clerk shall transmit the written statement to the village president within ten days of its receipt, and the village president shall set a time and place for a hearing on the appeal as provided in this chapter. 
(d)  A hearing shall be set not later than 20 days from the date of receipt of the appellant's written statement. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-397. - Claims of exemption. 
    Any person claiming to be legally exempt from the regulations set forth in this article, or from the payment of a permit fee, shall cite to the village clerk the statute or other legal authority under which exemption is claimed and shall present to the village clerk proof of qualification for such exemption. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 58-398. - Charitable street solicitation. 
(a)  Commercial street solicitation. It shall be unlawful to engage in commercial solicitation on any street or highway right-of-way within the village. 
(b)  Charitable street solicitation. It shall be unlawful to engage in charitable solicitation on street or highway right-of-way within the village before the hour of 7:00 a.m. or later than the hour of 6:00 p.m. during the months of September through March or before the hour of 6:00 a.m. or after the hour of 8:00 p.m. during the months of April through August. 
(c)  Further limitations on charitable street solicitation. 
(1)  The soliciting agency shall be registered with the attorney general as a charitable organization as provided by the Solicitation for Charity Act (225 ILCS 460/0.01 et seq.) and engaged in a statewide fund-raising activity. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in charitable solicitation on any street or highway within the village for more than a period of two consecutive days or more than two such two-day periods a year. 
(3)  No vehicles of the solicitors or related to the solicitation shall be permitted to be parked within the village rights-of-way. 
(4)  Applications shall be submitted not less than seven days before the requested solicitation event. 
(5)  The village reserves the right to impose any condition or restriction on the solicitation to take into account the orderly flow of traffic and prevent interference with official traffic control devices, as determined by the chief of police or his designee taking into account road conditions, accident rates, traffic volumes, or other unsafe conditions. 
(6)  A certificate of insurance shall also be provided from an insurance company licensed to do business in Illinois, insuring the solicitors and organizations for liability for damages causally related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent. The certificate must state that it shall not be cancelled during the period of solicitation and will provide at least the following coverage: 
Personal injury: $500,000.00 per person; $1,000,000.00 per occurrence. 
Property damage: $100,000.00 
(7)  It shall be unlawful to solicit on any highway or street within the village except at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a full stop. 
(8)  It shall be unlawful for any individual to solicit on any highway, street, or sidewalk within the village who is under 16 years of age and who is not wearing a high-visibility vest. 
(9)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit on any highway or street without a solicitation permit. 
(Ord. No. O-04-16, § 1, 3-18-2004) 
Secs. 58-399-58-410. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - CHILD CARE CENTERS[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference- Child Care Act, 225 ILCS 10/1 et seq. 

Sec. 58-411. - Minimum requirements for premises. 
    A child care center may be located only on premises which meet the requirements set forth in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 16-181; Ord. No. O-81-2, § 3, 2-5-1981; Ord. No. O-83-55, § 1, 9-15-1983; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 8, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-412. - Compliance with licensing standards. 
    In addition to the requirements set forth herein any premises wherein a child care center use is either proposed, or is now or hereafter established shall comply with the licensing standards of the Office of Child Development, Illinois Department of Children and Family Services. 
(Code 1975, § 16-182; Ord. No. O-81-2, § 3, 2-5-1981; Ord. No. O-83-55, § 1, 9-15-1983; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 8, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-413. - Outdoor recreation area. 
    Every child care center use shall provide, either on the premises where such use is proposed, or on nearby premises an outdoor recreation area which meets the following requirements: 
(a)  The area shall be enfenced and be landscaped as required. 
(b)  The area shall have a minimum size which is equal to 75 square feet per child for one-half of the number of children which may lawfully be located within the child care center premises. 
(c)  The area shall be safely enclosed to protect any children from traffic and any other hazards. 
(d)  There shall be provided a protective surface for the apparatus area such as, but not limited to, grass, P-gravel and/or mulching. There shall also be provided a surface that is suitable for children's wheeled vehicles and pull toys. 
(e)  There shall be open and sheltered areas to permit children to enjoy activities in either sun or shade and to protect them from excessive exposure. 
(f)  Upon approval by the Office of Child Development, Illinois Department of Children and Family Services and the Park District, a local public park or playground area may be used for off-premises play or recreation by the center. The children shall be closely supervised both during play and transport to and from the area. 
(g)  If the child care center proposes to locate the outdoor recreation area on adjacent property, it must be evidenced to the village that the child care center controls the use of the adjacent property. Any loss of control of the use of such adjacent property shall be the basis for termination of the child care center use if lawful replacement outdoor recreation area cannot be provided. 
(h)  The fencing and screening requirements applicable to an outdoor recreation area shall be waived if such area is located within a public park. 
(Code 1975, § 16-184; Ord. No. O-81-2, § 3, 2-5-1981; Ord. No. O-83-55, § 1, 9-15-1983; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 8, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-88-47, § 2, 7-21-1988) 
Sec. 58-414. - Yard requirements. 
(a)  When any new building is constructed for a child care center the area bulk requirements of the district shall be complied with. In addition, one side yard shall be not less than 15 feet to provide for vehicular access to the rear yard if said yard has to be used to meet the off-street parking requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Any proposed child care center which is to be located on a zoning lot adjacent to a residential zoning district shall have a side yard with a width of not less than 20 feet on the side of the lot adjacent to such residential district. 
(Code 1975, § 16-185; Ord. No. O-81-2, § 3, 2-5-1981; Ord. No. O-83-55, § 1, 9-15-1983; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 8, 10-18-1984; Ord. No. O-88-47, § 3, 7-21-1988) 
Secs. 58-415-58-430. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND CENTERS[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
State Law reference- Coin-operated Amusement Device and Redemption Machine Tag Act, 35 ILCS 510/1 et seq.; municipal tax on coin-operated devices, 65 ILCS 5/11-55-1 et seq. 

Sec. 58-431. - Definitions. 
(a)  Coin-operated amusement device: The term "amusement device" as used herein means apparatus used by a consumer which in return for the payment of a fee provides the user with diversion or amusement by physical or mental competition conducted in accordance with prescribed rules or conditions. This includes such devices as marble machines, pinball machines, electronic games, skill ball, mechanical grab machines and all similar games, operations or devices however designated. 
(b)  Coin-operated amusement center: The term "coin-operated amusement center" as used herein means any establishment which has more than three coin-operated amusement devices located on the premises. 
(c)  Proprietor: Any person, who, as the owner, lessee or proprietor has under his control any establishment, place or premises in or at which such device is placed or kept for use or play, or on exhibition for the purpose of use or play by persons other than the owner or proprietor of such device and his immediate family. 
(d)  Coin-operated amusement center-restaurant: The term "coin-operated amusement center-restaurant" as used herein means any establishment whose primary use is a restaurant with an accessory use of more than three coin-operated amusement devices which occupy at least 40 percent and not more than 50 percent of the total square footage of the restaurant establishment. The total square footage of the establishment shall be calculated by excluding those areas of the facility devoted to food preparation, storage, sanitation and office. Such devices shall be located in areas separated from main eating areas by walls. 
(Code 1975, § 16-186; Ord. No. O-81-67, § 1, 10-15-1981; Ord. No. O-82-22, § 1, 3-4-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 9, 10-18-1984) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-432. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate a coin-operated amusement center, or coin-operated amusement center-restaurant without first having obtained a license as is herein provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, install, maintain or operate any coin-operated amusement device for use by the public and for which a fee is charged without first having obtained a license for each device as is herein provided. 
(c)  There shall be issued in the Village of Hanover Park no more than four licenses for coin-operated amusement centers and one license for coin-operated amusement center-restaurant, to be in effect at any one time. 
(Code 1975, § 16-187; Ord. No. O-81-67, § 1, 10-15-1981; Ord. No. O-82-22, §§ 2, 3, 3-4-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 9, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-433. - License fees. 
(a)  The annual license fee for coin-operated amusement centers and coin-operated amusement center-restaurants shall be $500.00. The annual license fee for a coin-operated amusement device is $75.00 per device. The license fee per device shall be in addition to the business license fee if required. The license fee for a coin-operated amusement center-restaurant shall be in addition to the business license fee charged for a restaurant. 
(b)  No fee for a coin-operated amusement device shall be charged where the licensee is a municipal corporation and a fee of $10.00 shall be charged for licensees who are not-for-profit corporations as defined in section 105/101.80 of the General Not for Profit Corporation Act of 1986 (805 ILCS 105/101.01 et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1975, § 16-188; Ord. No. O-81-67, § 1, 10-15-1981; Ord. No. O-82-22, § 4, 3-4-1982; Ord. No. O-84-11, § 2, 3-1-1984; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 9, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-434. - Application for license. 
    Any person desiring the license required in and by this article shall make application for that purpose to the village clerk on a form to be provided by the village and shall state: 
(a)  The name and address of the applicant, and if a firm, corporation, partnership or association, the principal officers thereof and their addresses. 
(b)  The address of the premises where the licensed device or devices are to be operated, together with the character of the business as carried on at such place. 
(c)  The trade name, general description and total number of devices to be licensed. 
(d)  The name and address of the owner of the device if other than the proprietor. 
(Code 1975, § 16-189; Ord. No. O-81-67, § 1, 10-15-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 9, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-435. - Regulations for coin-operated amusement centers. 
(a)  Hours of operation. It shall be unlawful for any coin-operated amusement center to be open to the public at any time other than the following: 
Sunday through Thursday: 9:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. 
Friday and Saturday: 9:00 a.m. to midnight. 
(b)  Attendant on duty. An attendant (over 21 years of age) shall be on the premises at all times in which the business is open to the public and shall be in such a position as to have a clear view of all the amusement devices and activity taking place on the premises. 
(c)  Noise restrictions. It shall be unlawful for the licensee hereunder to permit such noise, either by mechanical means or noise on the part of the patrons which shall cause a disturbance of the peace to the adjacent and surrounding uses. 
(d)  Sidewalk obstructions. The licensee shall provide adequate and orderly parking for all bicycles and shall keep the storefront unobstructed so that the sidewalks are clear and open to pedestrian traffic. 
(e)  Sale of food, beverages or cigarettes. It shall be unlawful to sell any food, beverages, or cigarettes on the premises of a coin-operated amusement center. 
(f)  Prohibited amusement center locations. No coin-operated amusement center shall be located within 100 feet of any church, school or licensed liquor establishment where alcoholic beverages are consumed on the premises. 
(g)  Curfew sign posted. All coin-operated amusement centers shall post in a conspicuous place at the location a sign specifying curfew restrictions. 
(h)  Inducements to play coin-operated amusement devices. No coin-operated amusement device shall provide a monetary reward for skill in operation thereof, nor shall gambling of any kind be permitted in connection with any coin-operated amusement device. No coin-operated amusement device shall be equipped with a so-called "knock-off button" or other mechanism which releases or cancels free play. 
(Code 1975, § 16-190; Ord. No. O-81-67, § 1, 10-15-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 9, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-436. - Regulations for coin-operated amusement centers-restaurants. 
(a)  Hours of operation. The coin-operated amusement device area of the coin-operated amusement center-restaurant establishment shall have the same hours of business operation as the restaurant to service the restaurant patrons. The coin-operated amusement device area shall only be open to patrons of the restaurant, not the general public. 
(b)  Attendant on duty. An attendant (over 21 years of age) shall be in the amusement area at all times in which the business is open to the public and shall be in such a position as to have a clear view of all the amusement devices and activity taking place in the amusement area. 
(c)  Noise restrictions. It shall be unlawful for the licensee hereunder to permit such noise, either by mechanical means or noise on the part of the patrons which shall cause a disturbance of the peace to the adjacent and surrounding uses. 
(d)  Sidewalk obstructions. The licensee shall provide adequate and orderly parking for all bicycles and shall keep the premises unobstructed so that the sidewalks are clear and open to pedestrian traffic. 
(e)  Consumption of food, beverages or cigarettes. The consumption of food, beverages or cigarettes shall be prohibited in those areas of the restaurant designated for coin-operated amusement devices. 
(f)  Prohibited center locations. No coin-operated amusement center-restaurant shall be located within 100 feet of any church or school building. 
(g)  Inducements to play coin-operated amusement devices. It shall be unlawful for any proprietor of any amusement device to pay or give or promise to pay or give to any customer using such device any U.S. currency, token or anything of value for use in conjunction with such device for free play or as an inducement or reward for playing such device; provided, however, that this section shall not be deemed to prohibit the award of free use of the device upon the achievement of a predetermined score or result. The satisfaction of such an award for free use of the device shall not be converted by the proprietor to cash or other thing of value. 
(Code 1975, § 16-190.5; Ord. No. O-82-22, § 5, 3-4-1982; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 9, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-437. - Increasing the number of devices. 
    In the event a proprietor, licensed under the provisions of this article, desires, after the expiration of any portion of any license year, to increase the number of devices to be used in his establishment to a number within established limitation if any, he shall surrender his license to the village clerk who shall issue a new license showing the number of devices licensed thereunder, upon payment of the proper license fee therefor. 
(Code 1975, § 16-191; Ord. No. O-81-67, § 1, 10-15-1981; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 9, 10-18-1984) 
Secs. 58-438-58-450. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - DRY CLEANERS[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate laundries, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8; Drycleaner Environmental Response Trust Fund Act, 415 ILCS 135/1 et seq. 

Sec. 58-451. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    Dry cleaning. "Dry cleaning" means the process of cleaning fabrics by immersion and agitation, or by immersion only, in volatile solvents, including but not in way of limitation, solvents or petroleum distillate type, the coal tar distillate type and the chlorinated hydrocarbon type and processes incidental thereto, including but without limitation, spotting, cleaning, wet cleaning and finishing. 
    Dry cleaning establishment. "Dry cleaning establishment" shall mean and include any structure, store, building or other place where the service of dry cleaning, dyeing, spotting or finishing any fabric is rendered for hire, or is sold, resold or offered for sale or resale. 
    Fabric. "Fabric" means any article of wearing apparel, household furnishings, rugs, textiles, fur and leather. 
    Finishing. "Finishing" shall mean the process of pressing or reshaping any fabric, which is designed to restore as nearly as possible the shape, dimensions and contour of such fabric. 
    Spotting. "Spotting" shall mean the process designed to remove spots or stains which remain in a fabric after it has been subjected to the other processes of dry cleaning. 
(Code 1963, § 24.701; Code 1975, § 16-192; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 10, 10-18-1984) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-452. - License-Required. 
    No person shall conduct, operate or maintain any dry cleaning establishment in the village without first securing a license therefor as herein required. 
(Code 1963, § 24.702; Code 1975, § 16-193; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 10, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-453. - Same-Application; prerequisites to issuance. 
    Applications for dry cleaning establishment licenses shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall be referred to the building inspector. The building inspector shall investigate or cause to be investigated the premises intended to be used and shall report the result of the investigation to the president and board of trustees of the village before the issuance of a license. No such license shall be issued to any person not complying with all of the provisions of this article, with the provisions of the building code, and with all ordinances relating to flammable liquids. 
(Code 1963, § 24.702; Code 1975, § 16-194; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 10, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-454. - Building; premises. 
    No dry cleaning establishment shall be operated in a frame building. Such establishment shall be kept free from flammable wastes so far as possible, and it shall be unlawful to maintain or permit a stove or open flame of any kind on the premises. Smoking in such premises is hereby prohibited, and appropriate signs to that effect shall be posted in conspicuous places in the establishment. The premises must be kept free from rats, mice and vermin. No person afflicted with a contagious or venereal disease shall be employed in any dry cleaning establishment. 
(Code 1963, § 24.704; Code 1975, § 16-195; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 10, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-455. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police or other official designated by the president and board of trustees to inspect or cause to be inspected every establishment licensed under this article at least once every six months. Any violation of this article or other ordinances relating to dry cleaners, premises or flammable liquids shall be reported to the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1963, § 24.705; Code 1975, § 16-196; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 10, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-456. - Fire hazards. 
    The chief of the fire department of the fire district having jurisdiction over the area shall have the right to enter any building or premises situated in the village and occupied by any dry cleaning establishment in order to examine the same and to determine whether or not such building and premises, or any material, chemical or compound kept therein, or used thereon, or any article or fabric dry cleaned, spotted, dyed or finished, as received, used, kept, maintained or stored on such premises or building conforms to the fire ordinances and regulations of the village or constitutes a fire hazard within the village. 
(Code 1963, § 24.706; Code 1975, § 16-197; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 10, 10-18-1984) 
Secs. 58-457-58-470. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - GASOLINE SERVICE STATIONS 

Sec. 58-471. - Definition. 
(a)  A "service station" is any place of business where gasoline or any highly volatile fuels for motor vehicles or internal combustion engines are sold or offered for sale at retail and dispensed into fuel tanks of motor vehicles. 
(b)  This definition shall include also a private storage and dispensing of such products for the same purpose as those served by a service station, whether the storage is maintained for the use or benefit of the owner, lessee, agents or employees of either, or of any others. 
(c)  The requirements governing service stations shall also govern underground storage maintained at general storage plants and places other than service stations, so far as applicable. 
(Code 1963, § 23.202; Code 1975, § 16-198; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 11, 10-18-1984) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-472. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a service station in the village without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1963, § 23.201; Ord. No. O-64-135, 7-10-1964; Ord. No. O-65-177, 12-2-1965; Code 1975, § 16-199; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 11, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-473. - Nonbusiness stations exempted from fee requirement. 
    Any person maintaining or operating any storage tank for gasoline for the use of automobiles for the owner, lessee, employees or agents of such person shall comply with all the provisions of this article other than the requirement for the payment of a fee. 
(Code 1963, § 23.203; Code 1975, § 16-200; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 11, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-474. - Bulk sales. 
    No motor fuels shall be dispensed at any service station except into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles, when such tanks are connected with the carburation system of such vehicles; provided, however, that individual sales of up to five gallons may be made in metal receptacles when painted red and labeled in full conformity with the Gasoline Receptacle Labeling Act (430 ILCS 20/0.01 et seq.), as amended, such individual sales to be limited to five gallons to any one person. 
(Code 1963, § 23.204; Code 1975, § 16-201; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 11, 10-18-1984) 
Sec. 58-475. - Signs. 
    No gasoline service station within the village shall post signs stating the price of gasoline sold at such station unless the prices shown on such signs or advertising are the same as and identical with the prices shown on the gasoline pumps at such service station and are the actual prices charged for such gasoline at such service stations. 
(Code 1963, § 23.224; Ord. No. O-71-10, § 1, 3-18-1971; Code 1975, § 16-219; Ord. No. O-84-52, § 11, 10-18-1984) 
Secs. 58-476-58-490. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - SELF-SERVICE STATIONS 

Sec. 58-491. - Definitions. 
(a)  Motor fuel means all volatile and inflammable liquids produced, blended or compounded for the purpose of, or which are suitable or practicable for operating motor vehicles. It includes those liquids commonly known as gasoline. 
(b)  Motor vehicle means motorcycle and motor vehicle as defined in section 1-146 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.) (except for vehicles propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires) which are propelled by an internal combustion engine which uses motor fuel. 
(c)  Approved self-service motor fuel dispensing devices means a fixed device designed and equipped so as to allow control of the flow of motor fuels to and into the fuel tanks of a motor vehicle and to prevent leakage or accidental discharge of motor fuel. Each device shall have a muzzle which automatically closes when not manually held open and shall not have a hold open latch. All dispensing devices must be of the type approved by the rules and regulations of the state fire marshal, and meet the minimum requirements of the applicable provisions of the National Fire Prevention Association.
