Sec. 62-11-1328. - Alley parking. 
    No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic; and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1328; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-11-1329. - Parking in cab and bus zones. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or other than a taxicab in a taxicab zone when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1329; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-97-37, § 2, 9-4-1997) 
Sec. 62-11-1330. - Removal of illegally parked vehicles generally and vehicles which create a traffic hazard, etc., authorized. 
(a)  The police department, and all authorized personnel thereof, are hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away by a commercial towing service, any vehicle illegally parked in any place where such vehicle creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, blocks the use of a fire hydrant, or obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any emergency vehicle, any vehicle which has been illegally parked in any public street or other public place for a period of 24 consecutive hours, or for such other period of time where towing is authorized pursuant to the provisions of this Code, and any vehicle parked or left standing within a tow-away zone. 
(b)  Any vehicle so towed away shall be stored on any village property or in a public garage or parking lot. The restoration to the owner or operator of any vehicle and the collection of any fee charged in connection with the towing and/or storage of any such vehicle shall occur in the manner and form provided by law. 
(c)  Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of subsection (a) hereof shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 and not more than $500.00, and each day a violation exists or continues shall be deemed a separate offense hereunder. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1330; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-97-27, § 2, 6-5-1997; Ord. No. O-97-33, § 1, 6-19-1997) 
Sec. 62-11-1331. - Tow-away zones. 
    It is unlawful for any person to park or stand any vehicle on any of the following designated streets posted with an official sign during the hours when parking or standing is prohibited and [such vehicles] may be removed and towed away as provided in section 62-11-1330: 
  
Muirfield Court. 
(Ord. No. O-97-27, § 3, 6-5-1997; Ord. No. O-97-33, § 2, 6-19-1997) 
Sec. 62-11-1332. - Regulations on park property. 
(a)  No person shall park any vehicle, except a vehicle owned or leased by a park district, on any park property, including, without limitation, any parking lot owned and/or operated by the district, between the hours of midnight and 5:30 a.m. without a permit from the park district. It shall also be unlawful for any person to permit a vehicle owned or leased or in control of such person to be parked upon any park property between the hours above set forth without a permit from the district. 
(b)  No person shall park in any manner at anytime as to partially or totally block, restrict, or impede another parked vehicle, normal traffic flow, road, driveway, sidewalk, doorway, or recreational area. 
(Ord. No. O-05-09, § 2, 3-3-2005) 
Sec. 62-11-1333. - Reserved. 
Subdivision A. - Commuter Parking Facilities 

Sec. 62-11-1334. - Locations; designations. 
(a)  Location. The municipal commuter parking facilities are those off-street parking facilities owned or operated by the village generally located south of Lake Street and north of Ontarioville Road serving METRA's Hanover Park Station. 
(b)  Designations. The municipal commuter parking facility shall be designated and signed into daily metered, daily permit and monthly permit parking areas. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in any municipal commuter parking facility in violation of any of the regulations of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1334; Ord. No. O-91-04, § 1, 1-17-1991; Ord. No. O-91-10, § 5, 4-4-1991; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-95-86, § 2, 12-22-1995) 
Sec. 62-11-1335. - Hours of operation. 
    The municipal commuter parking facility shall be open and the regulations enforced on a 24-hour basis each day with each day commencing at 12:00 a.m. and ending at 11:59 p.m. except that no daily fee or permit shall be required for parking on Sunday and a daily meter parking fee shall permit parking for 24 hours from the time of purchase. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1335; Ord. No. O-91-04, § 1, 1-17-1991; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-10-28, § 1, 11-4-2010) 
Sec. 62-11-1336. - Parking fees. 
(a)  Daily meter fee. The daily meter fee shall be $1.75 for each parking space. The daily meter fee shall be paid by depositing $1.75 in the designated meter in a slot corresponding to the particular parking space in the daily meter parking area. Up to seven consecutive days in the same parking space in the daily parking area is permitted by paying $1.75 per day in advance for the designated parking space. The vehicle must be parking only in the parking space identified and paid for as shown on the parking receipt. 
(b)  Daily parking fee. The daily parking fee shall be $1.75 for each parking space. 
(c)  Monthly permit parking fee. The monthly permit parking fee shall be $35.00 for each parking space. Monthly parking permits may be purchased in advance. 
(d)  Yearly permit fee discount. The single purchase of a yearly permit purchased between October 1 and December 31 for the succeeding calendar year shall be $385.00 per parking space. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1336; Ord. No. O-91-04, § 1, 1-17-1991; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-92-19, § 1, 4-2-1992; Ord. No. O-92-71, § 1, 10-1-1992; Ord. No. O-93-18, §§ 1, 2, 4-15-1993; Ord. No. O-10-17, § 1, 8-5-2010; Ord. No. O-10-28, § 1, 11-4-2010; Ord. No. O-13-06, § 10, 1-24-2013; Ord. No. O-17-30, § 1, 10-5-2017) 
Sec. 62-11-1337. - Parking space regulations. 
    It is unlawful for any person to park or permit his vehicle [to] be parked: 
(1)  In any designated driveway, no parking area, fire lane or any other place where vehicle parking is prohibited. 
(2)  In any parking space which is marked by an appropriate sign as being reserved for handicapped parking unless such vehicle bears any of the following designating the same to be a vehicle owned or operated by a handicapped individual or a disabled veteran: 
a.  The decal issued by an Illinois township; 
b.  A special permit issued by the village; or 
c.  A State of Illinois registration plate for the handicapped or disabled veteran. 
(3)  When the vehicle is not entirely within the designated parking space. 
(4)  When the vehicle exceeds 20 feet in length in any one parking space. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1337; Ord. No. O-91-04, § 1, 1-17-1991; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-11-1338. - Permit parking. 
(a)  Daily and monthly parking permits shall be purchased in person or by mail on a first come, first served basis at the office of the village clerk. Permits are only valid for the day or month for which it is issued and valid only in either the daily or monthly parking areas. 
(b)  All permit sales are final, and no refunds shall be given. 
(c)  Permits shall be paid in cash, by check or by money order. Any check returned or dishonored for any reason shall result in the issuer being subject to the provisions of section 2-348, and the permits purchased shall be void. 
(d)  A permit does not entitle the holder to any specific parking space in the area designated for permit parking. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person except the village clerk and village employees to sell, offer to sell or otherwise transfer any parking permit. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1338; Ord. No. O-91-04, § 1, 1-17-1991; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-11-1339. - Daily meter fee parking regulations. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to park or the owner of any vehicle to permit a vehicle driven or owed by him to be parked in a daily meter fee parking space without immediately depositing the daily meter fee in the meter for that parking space. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to park or the owner of any vehicle to permit a vehicle owned by him to be parked in a daily meter fee parking space for a period longer than the legal parking period to which he is entitled by the depositing of funds as hereinbefore provided. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to deposit as the meter fee any slug substitute for a United States coin or any deceptive payment to avoid paying in accordance with the payment requirements. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person to deface, tamper with, open, willfully break or destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter, parking fee machinery or damage its supporting structure. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1339; Ord. No. O-91-04, § 1, 1-17-1991; Ord. No. O-91-10, § 4, 4-4-1991; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-10-28, § 1, 11-4-2010) 
Sec. 62-11-1340. - Permit parking regulations. 
    It is unlawful for any person to park or permit his vehicle to be parked: 
(1)  In the daily permit parking area without properly displaying a daily permit or in the monthly permit parking area without properly displaying a monthly permit during the entire time the vehicle is parked in the permit parking areas. 
(2)  Without properly displaying the entire permit in clear view hanging from the rearview mirror with the side showing its number facing the front of the vehicle. 
(3)  Notwithstanding sections 62-11-1336, 1339, and this 1340, parking of a vehicle in the area described below will be permitted without a permit but only after 3:00 p.m. and before 11:00 p.m. on a daily basis on Monday through Thursday, and after 3:00 p.m. on Friday and permitted all day Saturday and Sunday, except no vehicle shall be parked without a permit after 11:00 p.m. Sunday until 3:00 p.m. Monday. 
"The westernmost lot located north of Liberty Street and south of the railroad tracks." 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1340; Ord. No. O-91-04, § 1, 1-17-1991; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-93-18, § 3, 4-15-1993; Ord. No. O-14-16, § 1, 5-15-2014) 
Sec. 62-11-1341. - Additional penalties; towing and booting. 
    The following alternative penalties shall be applicable in addition to the provisions of article XVII: 
(1)  If any vehicle is parked in violation of sections 62-11-1334 through 62-11-1340 or if a vehicle is parked in a parking space which is marked by an appropriate sign as being reserved for handicapped parking only unless such vehicle bears any of the following designating the same to be a vehicle owned or operated by a handicapped individual or a disabled veteran: 
a.  A decal issued by an Illinois township; or 
b.  A special permit issued by the village; or 
c.  A State of Illinois registration plate for the handicapped or for a disabled veteran; 
the vehicle shall be towed and subject to subsection 62-11-1330 hereof. 
(2)  A municipal commuter parking facility shall be considered as a public parking lot and subject to section 62-17-108 regarding immobilization of vehicles for violations. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1341; Ord. No. O-91-04, § 1, 1-17-1991; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-11-1342. - Sales prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale or give away for commercial purposes any food, beverage, confection or other item for human consumption; or any product, food or merchandise within the municipal commuter parking facilities except as approved by the village. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1342; Ord. No. O-95-86, § 1, 12-22-1995) 
Sec. 62-11-1343. - Handbills on motor vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, including persons who obtain a handbill permit, to distribute handbills, circulars, pamphlets, cards or any other advertising matter by placing the same in or upon any motor vehicle unless the occupant of the vehicle is willing to accept it. 
(Code 1975, § 3-71; Ord. No. O-93-02, § 1, 1-21-1993; Ord. No. O-04-16, § 2, 3-18-2004) 
Sec. 62-11-1344. - Reserved. 
Subdivision B. - Hanover Square Municipal Parking Lot 

Sec. 62-11-1345. - Description; regulations; penalty. 
(a)  Generally. The Hanover Square Municipal Parking Lot shall be those off-street parking facilities generally located adjacent to the Hanover Square shopping center located south of Walnut Avenue, West of Barrington Road, North of Maple Avenue and east of Pine Street as legally described in exhibit E of the Park 'N Shop Redevelopment Agreement approved by Ordinance Number O-86-73 on December 29, 1986. 
    The Hanover Square Municipal Parking Lot is divided into: 
(1)  Main parking area. The main parking area shall be those portions of the Hanover Square Municipal Parking Lot excluding the rear service area. 
(2)  Rear service area. The rear service area shall be those off-street parking and loading facilities that are west of the principal Hanover Square commercial building and east of Pine Tree Street, and north of the first driveway entrance into the main parking area from Pine Tree Street north of Maple Avenue. 
(b)  Late night parking. It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in the main parking area between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(c)  Gross weight. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or move on, upon or across the main parking lot when the gross weight of the vehicle and its load exceeds 10,000 pounds. 
(d)  No parking: 
(1)  No person shall park any vehicle in the Hanover Square Municipal Parking Lot except in a designated parking space. 
(2)  No person shall park or stand any vehicle in the 30-foot-wide aisle from Maple Avenue to Walnut Avenue adjacent and parallel to the eastern front of the principal Hanover Square commercial building in the main parking area. 
(e)  Loading zone. It shall be unlawful for any person to stand or park a vehicle in the rear service area longer than is necessary for the loading or unloading of the vehicle but not to exceed 30 minutes. 
(f)  Permit parking. It shall be unlawful for any person to park in a designated parking space in the rear service area without displaying a Hanover Square parking permit in plain view on the rear window of the vehicle. The permit shall be issued by the village clerk to the developer as designated in the Park 'N Shop Redevelopment Agreement. Application for the permit shall be made on a form provided by the village clerk describing the vehicle to receive the permit. Transfer of a permit shall be by application to the village clerk. There shall be no fee for the permit and its term shall be the same as for a business license. 
(g)  Penalty. In addition to other penalties provided for in this chapter the police department and all authorized personnel thereof, are hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away by a commercial towing service any vehicle parked in violation of the regulations of this section. 
(h)  Parking zones. It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle for longer than 15 minutes in the three spaces facing easterly across from 6610 Barrington Road. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1345; Ord. No. O-88-02, § 3, 1-9-1988; Ord. No. O-89-04, § 1, 1-19-1989; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991) 
Secs. 62-11-1346-62-11-1349. - Reserved. 
Sec. 62-11-1350. - Astor Avenue parking facility. 
    It is unlawful for any person to park or the owner of any vehicle to permit a vehicle owned by that person to be parked in the Astor Avenue parking facility without displaying a valid village Astor Avenue parking permit in clear view hanging from the rearview mirror. The Astor Avenue parking facilities are those designated off-street parking spaces located in the Astor Avenue right-of-way between Briarwood Avenue and Irving Park Road. 
(Ord. No. O-00-14, § 1, 5-18-2000) 
Secs. 62-11-1351-62-11-1514. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BICYCLES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate the operation of bicycles, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(8); bicycles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1501 et seq. 

Sec. 62-11-1515. - Destruction, removal, etc., of serial number prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to destroy remove, alter, permanently cover, or deface the manufacturer's serial number on any bicycle. It shall be unlawful for any person to own or have custody of a bicycle in which the manufacturer's serial number has been destroyed, removed, altered, permanently covered or defaced. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1515; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 6(B), 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-18-21, § 1; 6-21-2018) 
Sec. 62-11-1516. - Registrations of bicycles. 
    The Hanover Park Police Department may utilize a third-party web-based registration program as a tool to locate and identify stolen or lost bicycles. The registration application shall include the name of the owner, address, telephone number, make, model, type, size, color and serial number of the bicycle. 
(Ord. No. O-18-21, § 2, 6-21-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-18-21, § 2, adopted June 21, 2018, amended § 62-11-1516 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 62-11-1516 pertained to licensing of bicycles and derived from Code 1975, § 17-11-1516; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 6(B), adopted Sep. 19, 1991. 
Sec. 62-11-1517. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-18-21, § 3, adopted June 21, 2018, repealed § 62-11-1517, which pertained to attachment of permanent license number to bicycle; removal and derived from Code 1975, § 17-11-1517; and Ord. No. O-91-49, § 6(B), adopted Sep. 19, 1991. 
Sec. 62-11-1518. - Rental agencies. 
    A rental agency shall not rent or offer any bicycle for rent within the Village of Hanover Park unless the bicycle is registered on line with the on-line registry that village currently utilizes. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1518; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 6(B), 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-18-21, § 4, 6-21-2018) 
Sec. 62-11-1519. - Special traffic regulations for bicycles. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle in the Village of Hanover Park in violation of the following provisions: 
(1)  Reckless driving. No driver of a bicycle shall operate a bicycle in a reckless manner. 
(2)  Speed. No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. 
(3)  Riding on handlebars or frames. No driver of a bicycle shall carry any other person upon the handlebars or frame of such vehicle. This restriction is not applicable to carrying other persons on a bicycle containing special equipment designed for such purpose. 
(4)  Carrying packages. No driver of a bicycle shall carry any package or article which interferes with or prevents the safe operation of a bicycle. 
(5)  Clinging to motor vehicles. No driver of a bicycle shall attach the same or himself to any motor vehicle located or moving upon a public roadway or public path. 
(6)  Passing of school buses. Persons operating bicycles upon a roadway shall stop for school buses loading or unloading children regardless of the direction from which the bicycle driver is approaching such bus. 
(7)  Driving on private property. No person shall operate a bicycle on private property without the consent of the owner of such property. 
(8)  Condition of bicycle and necessary equipment. No person shall drive a bicycle which is not in safe operating order or which does not have affixed thereto the required equipment specified herein. 
(9)  Reserved. 
(10)  Parking. 
(a)  No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than against the curb or on a sidewalk in such a way as to obstruct pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(b)  No bicycle shall be parked within four feet of a building located within a district zoned commercial; nor shall any bike be parked within four feet of any window or door or any building open to the public. 
(c)  No bicycle shall be parked in such a manner as to obstruct the ingress or egress from a building. 
(11)  Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and not use the roadway. 
(12)  Persons riding on bicycle paths shall ride right of the center of the path in the direction they are proceeding. 
(13)  The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway, or building shall upon approaching a sidewalk area extending across any alley way, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on such sidewalk or sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on such roadway. 
(14)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating a bicycle to engage in any type of trick or unsafe riding, except at a duly-authorized exhibition. 
(15)  Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1519; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 6(B), 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-02-50, § 1, 11-21-2002; Ord. No. O-18-21, § 5, 6-21-2018) 
Sec. 62-11-1520. - Special traffic regulations for persons on skates and skateboards. 
    No person shall skate or ride upon a skateboard in the village in violation of the following regulations: 
(1)  Any person on skates or a skateboard on a roadway shall obey the instruction of official traffic signals and signs unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(2)  No person on skates or a skateboard on the roadway shall operate in a reckless manner. 
(3)  Every person on skates or a skateboard on a roadway shall ride as near as possible to the righthand side of the roadway and exercise due care when passing a standing vehicle. 
(4)  Whenever a person on skates or a skateboard is operating upon a sidewalk, the person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian. 
(5)  No person on skates or a skateboard shall attach himself to any motor vehicle located or moving upon a public roadway. 
(6)  No person on skates or a skateboard shall be upon the roadway between sunset and sunrise. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1520; Ord. No. O-89-23, § 1, 5-4-1989; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 6(B), 9-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-11-1521. - Toy vehicles prohibited on roadways. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person upon a coaster, sled, toy vehicle or other similar device to go upon any roadway except while crossing the street in a crosswalk and, when so crossing, shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11-1521; Ord. No. O-89-23, § 2, 5-4-1989; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 6(B), 9-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-11-1522. - Motor-driven scooters. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, a "motor-driven scooter" is defined as any electric or gas-driven wheeled scooter, cycle, or other vehicle for which the State of Illinois does not issue a title document, and does not issue license plates or registration documents. 
(b)  No person shall operate a motor-driven scooter upon any public street, sidewalk, parking lot, bike path, park, or on any other public property. 
(c)  The following shall be exempt from the prohibitions contained in this section: 
(1)  Any police vehicle, fire vehicle, municipal vehicle, park district vehicle, county vehicle, or forest preserve district vehicle driven by an employee in the course of his or her duties. 
(2)  Motorized wheelchairs. For purposes of this section, a motorized wheelchair means any motorized vehicle designed for and used by a person with disabilities. 
(3)  Electric personal assistance mobility devices, as defined in Section 5/1-117.7 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for a parent or legal guardian to allow a minor under his or her direct control or with his or her consent to violate this section. 
(Ord. No. O-05-05, § 1, 1-20-2005)

ARTICLE XIV. - MISCELLANEOUS LAWS 

Sec. 62-14-001. - Operation of neighborhood electric vehicles on village streets, roadways, and highways. 
(a)  As used in this section, "neighborhood electric vehicle" means a self-propelled, electronically-powered four-wheeled motor vehicle which is capable of attaining in one mile a speed of more than 20 miles per hour, but not more than 25 miles per hour, and which conforms to federal regulations under Title 49 C.F.R. Part 571.500. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, it is unlawful for any person to drive or operate a neighborhood electric vehicle upon any street, highway, or roadway not under jurisdiction of the Village of Hanover Park. A neighborhood electric vehicle may be operated only on village streets where the posted speed limit is 35 miles per hour or less. This subsection (b) does not prohibit a neighborhood electric vehicle from crossing a road or street at an intersection where the road or street has a posted speed limit of more than 35 miles per hour. 
(c)  A person may not operate a neighborhood electric vehicle upon any street, highway, or roadway in this village unless he or she has a valid Illinois driver's license issued in his or her name by the Secretary of State. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (e), no person operating a neighborhood electric vehicle shall make a direct crossing upon or across any highway under the jurisdiction of the state, toll road, interstate highway, or controlled access highway in this state. 
(e)  A person may make a direct crossing at an intersection controlled by a traffic light or four-way stop sign upon or across a highway under the jurisdiction of the state if the speed limit on the highway is 35 miles per hour or less at the place of crossing. 
(f)  No neighborhood electric vehicle may be operated on a roadway unless, at a minimum, it has the following: brakes, a steering apparatus, tires, a rearview mirror, red reflectorized warning devices in the front and rear, a slow-moving emblem (as required of other vehicles in Section 12-709 of the Illinois Vehicle Code) on the rear of the neighborhood electric vehicle, a headlight that emits a white light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the front, a tail lamp that emits a red light visible from at least 100 feet from the rear, brake lights, and turn signals. When operated on a roadway, a neighborhood electric vehicle shall have its headlight and tail lamps lighted as required by Section 12-201 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(g)  A person who drives or is in the actual physical control of a neighborhood electric vehicle on a roadway while under the influence is subject to Sections 11-500 through 11-502 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(h)  A person who owns, operates, or is in actual physical control of a neighborhood electric vehicle is subject to all provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(Ord. No. O-08-49, § 1, 8-21-2008) 
Sec. 62-14-002. - Prohibiting motorized vehicles on bicycle paths. 
(a)  No person shall operate any motorized vehicle (self propelled vehicle) upon any Bicycle Path. Signs giving reasonable notice of the foregoing regulation shall be posted. 
(b)  Any police vehicle, fire vehicle, village vehicle or park district vehicle driven by an employee in the course of his/her duties shall be permitted to use the bicycle path when it is necessary in the performance of those duties. 
(c)  Motorized wheelchairs shall be permitted on the bike path. 
(Ord. No. O-10-22, § 1, 8-19-2010) 
ARTICLE XV. - SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD[8]

(Code 1975, § 17-15-099; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 13, 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-94-32, § 10, 6-16-1994; Ord. No. O-17-08, § 1, 3-2-2017) 
Secs. 62-15-100-62-15-109. - Reserved. 
Sec. 62-15-110. - Permits for overweight and/or overdimension vehicles. 
(a)  The village, with respect to any street or highway under its jurisdiction, may upon application to the public works department and good cause being shown therefore, issue a special permit authorizing the applicant to operate or move a vehicle or combination of vehicles of a size or weight of vehicle or load exceeding the maximum specified in the Illinois Vehicle Code, specifically 625 ILCS 5/15-111(a) (weight), 15-102 (width), 15-103 (height) and 15-107 (length). The applicant shall furnish, at minimum, the following information in the special permit application: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner or lessee of the vehicle; 
(2)  Applicant's name; 
(3)  Type of permit request whether it be for a single trip (five calendar days), round trip (ten calendar days), quarterly (90 calendar days) or annual (365 calendar days); 
(4)  Description of the vehicle or vehicles and load to be operated or moved; 
(5)  The number of axles of the vehicle or combination of vehicles and the weight of such axles; 
(6)  Gross weight of vehicle; 
(7)  The width, length, and height of the vehicle, including load; 
(8)  Requested routing over village streets and to specific location, including the point of origin and destination, and; 
(9)  Except for an application to move directly across a highway, a statement by the applicant that the load to be moved by such vehicle or combination of vehicles cannot reasonably be dismantled or disassembled. 
(b)  Permits are valid only for the dates specified on the permit and for the specific vehicle, load, and routing as established by the director of public works or his designee. No substitution of vehicle, load, or routing is permitted without expressed written permission by the director of public works or his designee and carried in the vehicle to which the permit applies. Revisions to permits are at the discretion of the director of public works or his designee. 
(c)  The director of public works or his designee is authorized to approve the permit application. Upon approval, the director of public works shall issue a permit allowing travel of the oversize and/or overweight vehicle over village streets. The permit, issued either on forms provided by the village or using an electronic permit service, shall be specific and contain, at minimum: 
(1)  Permit number; 
(2)  The date the permit is valid and the date the permit expires; 
(3)  Whether the permit is single, round trip, quarterly, or annual; 
(4)  The description of object or vehicle to be moved; 
(5)  Authorized gross weight, axle weights, width, length, and height; 
(6)  The authorized routing over village streets including the origin and termination point within the village; and 
(7)  The date and signature, written or electronic, of the director of public works or his designee. 
    In addition, the permit shall specify general conditions that the permittee must comply with that are consistent and reasonable for the protection of the general public and village streets. The director of public works shall establish the general conditions of the permit and is authorized to amend such conditions as needed. A copy of all permits issued will be provided to the police department for information and enforcement purposes. 
(d)  It is the duty of the permittee to read and understand the permit provisions upon receipt. Undertaking of the permit is deemed prima facie evidence of acceptance of the permit and that: 
(1)  The permittee is in compliance with all operational requirements; 
(2)  All dimension and weight limitations specified in the permit will not be exceeded; 
(3)  All operation, registration, and license requirements have been complied with; 
(4)  All financial responsibilities, obligations, and other legal requirements have been met; and 
(5)  The permittee assumes all responsibility for injury or damage to persons or to public or private property, including his own, or to the object being transported, caused directly or indirectly by the transportation or movement of vehicles and objects authorized under the permit. The permittee agrees to hold the village harmless from all suits, claims, damages, or proceedings of any kind and to indemnify the village for any claim it may be required to pay arising from the movement. 
(e)  The permit shall be carried in the vehicle, in either paper or electronic form, to which the permit applies at all times while operating on streets within the village and shall be exhibited upon demand to any enforcement officer, police officer, or other authorized official of the village. 
(f)  Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a village permit whether it be by size, weight, or general provisions, and either or both the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty and either or both the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation.

Sec. 62-15-111. - Village axle weight. 
    Except on Barrington Road, Irving Park Road, Lake Street, Schick Road from County Farm Road east to the corporate limits, Army Trail Road, County Farm Road south of Schick Road and Wise Road no vehicle or combination of vehicles equipped with pneumatic tires shall be operated, unladen or with load, upon the highways of this Village when the gross weight on the road surface through any single axle thereof exceeds 5,000 pounds. The above-described axle load limits shall not apply to vehicles operating under the authority of a permit issued in accordance with section 62-15-110 of this Code, or making a delivery or picking up a load but only when the vehicle is driven on such street for not more than the minimum distance necessary for that purpose. The maximum fine for a violation of this paragraph shall not exceed the penalty as established in 625 ILCS 5/15-316(e). 
(Code 1975, § 17-15-111; Ord. No. O-86-66, §§ 8-13, 12-4-1986; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 13, 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-17-08, § 1, 3-2-2017; Ord. No. O-18-25, § 2, 7-19-2018) 
Sec. 62-15-112. - Village gross weight. 
    Except on Barrington Road, Irving Park Road, Lake Street, Schick Road from County Farm Road east to the corporate limits, Army Trail Road, County Farm Road south of Schick Road and Wise Road the gross weight of vehicles and combination of vehicles including the weight of the vehicle or combination and its load on any street in the Village, except those provided for above shall not exceed 10,000 pounds. The above-described vehicle load limits shall not apply to vehicles operating under the authority of a permit issued in accordance with section 62-15-110 of this Code, or making a delivery or picking up a load but only when the vehicle is driven on such street for not more than the minimum distance necessary for that purpose. The maximum fine for a violation of this paragraph shall not exceed the penalty as established in 625 ILCS 5/15-316(e). 
(Code 1975, § 17-15-112; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 13, 9-19-1991; Ord. No. O-17-08, § 1, 3-2-2017; Ord. No. O-18-25, § 2, 7-19-2018)

ARTICLE XVII. - ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 

Secs. 62-17-001-62-17-099. - Reserved. 
Sec. 62-17-100. - Penalties generally. 
    Unless another penalty is specifically provided by this Code for violation of any particular section or chapter, any person convicted of an offense under this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00. A person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any violation of any provision of this chapter is committed, continued or permitted by any such person, provided, that the filing of such civil action, whether in the Circuit Court or by administrative adjudication, shall preclude incarceration or imprisonment. 
(Code 1975, § 17-17-100; Ord. No. O-82-61, § 2, 8-19-1982; Ord. No. O-13-36, § 1, 12-19-2013) 
Sec. 62-17-101. - Release on bail. 
    Every person arrested for a violation of this chapter shall be released upon bail being furnished in the proper amount according to the procedures prescribed by the Illinois Revised Statutes as amended. 
(Code 1975, § 17-17-101; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 14, 9-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-17-102. - Owner of vehicle prima facie responsible for violations. 
    Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of any of the provisions of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be prima facie responsible for such violation and subject to the penalties therefor. 
(Code 1975, § 17-17-102; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 9, 9-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-17-103. - Penalties-Parking tickets. 
A.  Any person accused of a violation of sections 62-11-1300 to 62-11-1400 may settle and compromise the claim pursuant to section 62-17-104 and prior to such person being issued a complaint or notice to appear. 
B.  Tickets issued under this section shall be as a courtesy in lieu of arrest. If the person accused of the violation does not settle the claim, a complaint or notice to appear will be issued for that violation, and the person shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 62-17-100. 
(Code 1975, § 17-17-103; Ord. No. O-84-30, § 2, 5-17-1984; Ord. No. O-91-49, § 15, 9-19-1991) 
Sec. 62-17-104. - Same-Parking violations; settlement of penalties; authorization and procedure. 
    The following procedure regarding early payment of parking violations is hereby authorized: 
A. Payments received by mail shall be credited as paid on the date received by the village. 
B.  Any owner or operator who is issued a complaint for a violation of the following sections of this Code may early pay that complaint by paying to the village after notice of violation on or before ten days after the date of issuance not counting the date of issuance the early payment amount in column A. Payments received by mail shall be credited as paid on the date received by village. The following table provides the minimum (Column B) and maximum (Column C) fines.
